{'sentences': [u"The World's Columbian Exposition (the official shortened name for the World's Fair: Columbian Exposition, also known as The Chicago World's Fair and Chicago Columbian Exposition) was a world's fair held in Chicago in 1893 to celebrate the 400th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's arrival in the New World in 1492.", u'The centerpiece of the Fair, the large water pool, represented the long voyage Columbus took to the New World.', u'Chicago bested New York City; Washington, D.C.; and St. Louis for the honor of hosting the fair.', u"The Exposition was an influential social and cultural event and had a profound effect on architecture, sanitation, the arts, Chicago's self-image, and American industrial optimism.", u'The layout of the Chicago Columbian Exposition was, in large part, designed by John Wellborn Root, Daniel Burnham, Frederick Law Olmsted and Charles B. Atwood It was the prototype of what Burnham and his colleagues thought a city should be.', u'It was designed to follow Beaux Arts principles of design, namely French neoclassical architecture principles based on symmetry, balance, and splendor.', u'The color of the material generally used to cover the buildings facades gave the fairgrounds its nickname, the White City.', u'Many prominent architects designed its 14 "great buildings".', u'Artists and musicians were featured in exhibits and many also made depictions and works of art inspired by the exposition.', u'The exposition covered more than 600 acres (2.4 km2), featuring nearly 200 new (but purposely temporary) buildings of predominantly neoclassical architecture, canals and lagoons, and people and cultures from 46 countries.', u'More than 27 million people attended the exposition during its six-month run.', u"Its scale and grandeur far exceeded the other world's fairs, and it became a symbol of the emerging American Exceptionalism, much in the same way that the Great Exhibition became a symbol of the Victorian era United Kingdom.", u'Dedication ceremonies for the fair were held on October 21, 1892, but the fairgrounds were not actually opened to the public until May 1, 1893.', u'The fair continued until October 30, 1893.', u'In addition to recognizing the 400th anniversary of the discovery of the New World by Europeans, the fair also served to show the world that Chicago had risen from the ashes of the Great Chicago Fire, which had destroyed much of the city in 1871.', u'On October 9, 1893, the day designated as Chicago Day, the fair set a world record for outdoor event attendance, drawing 751,026 people.', u'The debt for the fair was soon paid off with a check for $1.5 million (equivalent to $39,572,222 in 2015).', u'Chicago has commemorated the fair with one of the stars on its municipal flag.', u'== Planning and organization ==\n\nMany prominent civic, professional, and commercial leaders from around the United States participated in the financing, coordination, and management of the Fair, including Chicago steel tycoon Charles H. Schwab, Chicago railroad and manufacturing magnate John Whitfield Bunn, and Connecticut banking, insurance, and iron products magnate Milo Barnum Richardson, among many others.', u'The fair was planned in the early 1890s during the Gilded Age of rapid industrial growth, immigration, and class tension.', u"World's fairs, such as London's 1851 Crystal Palace Exhibition, had been successful in Europe as a way to bring together societies fragmented along class lines.", u"The first American attempt at a world's fair in Philadelphia in 1876, drew crowds but was a financial failure.", u"Nonetheless, ideas about distinguishing the 400th anniversary of Columbus' landing started in the late 1880s.", u'Civic leaders in St. Louis, New York City, Washington DC and Chicago expressed an interest in hosting a fair to generate profits, boost real estate values, and promote their cities.', u'Congress was called on to decide the location.', u"New York's financiers J. P. Morgan, Cornelius Vanderbilt, and William Waldorf Astor, among others, pledged $15 million to finance the fair if Congress awarded it to New York, while Chicagoans Charles T. Yerkes, Marshall Field, Philip Armour, Gustavus Swift, and Cyrus McCormick, offered to finance a Chicago fair.", u"What finally persuaded Congress was Chicago banker Lyman Gage, who raised several million additional dollars in a 24-hour period, over and above New York's final offer.", u'The exposition corporation and national exposition commission settled on Jackson Park and an area around it as the fair site.', u'Daniel H. Burnham was selected as director of works, and George R. Davis as director-general.', u"Burnham emphasized architecture and sculpture as central to the fair and assembled the period's top talent to design the buildings and grounds including Frederick Law Olmsted for the grounds.", u'The temporary buildings were designed in an ornate Neoclassical style and painted white, resulting in the fair site being referred to as the \u201cWhite City\u201d.', u"The Exposition's offices set up shop in the upper floors of the Rand McNally Building on Adams Street, the world's first all-steel-framed skyscraper.", u"Davis's team organized the exhibits with the help of G. Brown Goode of the Smithsonian.", u'The Midway was inspired by the 1889 Paris Universal Exposition, which included ethnological "villages".', u'Civil rights leaders protested the refusal to include an African American exhibit.', u'Frederick Douglass, Ida B.', u'Wells, Irvine Garland Penn, and Ferdinand Lee Barnet coauthored a pamphlet entitled "The Reason Why the Colored American is not in the World\'s Columbian Exposition - The Afro-American\'s Contribution to Columbian Literature" addressing the issue.', u'The exhibition included a number of exhibits put on by black individuals and approved by white organizers of the fair, including exhibits by the sculptor Edmonia Lewis, a painting exhibit by scientist George Washington Carver, and a statistical exhibit by John Imogen Howard.', u'It also included blacks in white exhibits, such as Nancy Green\'s portrayal of the character, "Aunt Jemima" for the R. T. Davis Milling Company.', u'== Description ==\n\nThe fair opened in May and ran through October 30, 1893.', u'Forty-six nations participated in the fair (it was the first world\'s fair to have national pavilions), constructing exhibits and pavilions and naming national "delegates" (for example, Haiti selected Frederick Douglass to be its delegate).', u'The Exposition drew nearly 26 million visitors.', u'The exposition was located in Jackson Park and on the Midway Plaisance on 630 acres (2.5 km2) in the neighborhoods of South Shore, Jackson Park Highlands, Hyde Park and Woodlawn.', u'Charles H. Wacker was the Director of the Fair.', u'The layout of the fairgrounds was created by Frederick Law Olmsted, and the Beaux-Arts architecture of the buildings was under the direction of Daniel Burnham, Director of Works for the fair.', u'Renowned local architect Henry Ives Cobb designed several buildings for the exposition.', u'The Director of the American Academy in Rome, Francis Davis Millet, directed the painted mural decorations.', u'Indeed, it was a coming-of-age for the arts and architecture of the "American Renaissance", and it showcased the burgeoning neoclassical and Beaux-Arts styles.', u"== Attractions ==\n\nThe World's Columbian Exposition was the first world's fair with an area for amusements that was strictly separated from the exhibition halls.", u'This area, developed by a young music promoter, Sol Bloom, concentrated on Midway Plaisance and introduced the term "midway" to American English to describe the area of a carnival or fair where sideshows are located.', u'It included carnival rides, among them the original Ferris Wheel, built by George Washington Gale Ferris Jr..', u'This wheel was 264 feet (80 m) high and had 36 cars, each of which could accommodate 40 people.', u'The importance of the Columbian Exposition is highlighted by the use of rueda de Chicago ("Chicago wheel") in many Latin American countries such as Costa Rica and Chile in reference to the Ferris wheel.', u"One attendee, George C. Tilyou, later credited the sights he saw on the Chicago midway for inspiring him to create America's first major amusement park, Steeplechase Park in Coney Island, NY.", u"The fair included life-size reproductions of Christopher Columbus' three ships, the Ni\xf1a, Pinta, and Santa Maria.", u"These were intended to celebrate the 400th anniversary of Columbus' discovery of the Americas.", u'The ships, a joint project of the governments of Spain and the United States, were constructed in Spain and then sailed to America for the exposition.', u'The ships were a very popular exhibit.', u'Eadweard Muybridge gave a series of lectures on the Science of Animal Locomotion in the Zoopraxographical Hall, built specially for that purpose on Midway Plaisance.', u'He used his zoopraxiscope to show his moving pictures to a paying public.', u'The hall was the first commercial movie theater.', u'The "Street in Cairo" included the popular dancer known as Little Egypt.', u'She introduced America to the suggestive version of the belly dance known as the "hootchy-kootchy", to a tune said to have been improvised by Sol Bloom (and now more commonly associated with snake charmers) which he had composed when his dancers had no music to dance to.', u'Bloom did not copyright the song, putting it straight into the public domain.', u'Also included was the first moving walkway or travelator.', u'It had two different divisions: one where passengers were seated, and one where riders could stand or walk.', u'It ran in a loop down the length of a lakefront pier to a casino.', u'Although denied a spot at the fair, Buffalo Bill Cody decided to come to Chicago anyway, setting up his Wild West show just outside the edge of the exposition.', u'Nearby, historian Frederick Jackson Turner gave academic lectures reflecting on the end of the frontier which Buffalo Bill represented.', u'The electrotachyscope of Ottomar Ansch\xfctz was demonstrated, which used a Geissler tube to project the illusion of moving images.', u'Louis Comfort Tiffany made his reputation with a stunning chapel designed and built for the Exposition.', u'This chapel has been carefully reconstructed and restored.', u'It can be seen in at the Charles Hosmer Morse Museum of American Art.', u"Architect Kirtland Cutter's Idaho Building, a rustic log construction, was a popular favorite, visited by an estimated 18 million people.", u"The building's design and interior furnishings were a major precursor of the Arts and Crafts movement.", u'Among the other attractions at the fair, several products that are well known today were introduced.', u'These products included Juicy Fruit Gum, Cream of Wheat, and Pabst Blue Ribbon beer, among many others.', u"=== Anthropology ===\nThere was an Anthropology Building at the World's Fair.", u'Nearby, "The Cliff Dwellers" featured a rock and timber structure that was painted to recreate Battle Rock Mountain in Colorado, a stylized recreation of American Indian cliff dwelling with pottery, weapons and other relics on display.', u'There was also an Eskimo display.', u'There were also birch bark wigwams of the Penobscot tribe.', u'=== Rail ===\nThe John Bull locomotive was displayed.', u'It was only 62 years old, having been built in 1831.', u'It was the first locomotive acquisition by the Smithsonian Institution.', u'The locomotive ran under its own power from Washington, DC, to Chicago to participate, and returned to Washington under its own power again when the exposition closed.', u'In 1981 it was the oldest surviving operable steam locomotive in the world when it ran under its own power again.', u'A Baldwin 2-4-2 locomotive was showcased at the exposition, and subsequently the 2-4-2 type was known as the Columbia\nAn original frog switch and portion of the superstructure of the famous 1826 Granite Railway in Massachusetts could be viewed.', u'This was the first commercial railroad in the United States to evolve into a common carrier without an intervening closure.', u'The railway brought granite stones from a rock quarry in Quincy, Massachusetts, so that the Bunker Hill Monument could be erected in Boston.', u'The frog switch is now on public view in East Milton Square, Massachusetts, on the original right-of-way of the Granite Railway.', u'=== Country and state exhibition buildings ===\nForty-six countries had pavilions at the exposition.', u'Norway participated by sending the Viking, a replica of the Gokstad ship.', u'It was built in Norway and sailed across the Atlantic by 12 men, led by Captain Magnus Andersen.', u'In 1919 this ship was moved to Lincoln Park.', u'It was relocated in 1996 to Good Templar Park in Geneva, Illinois, where it awaits renovation.', u'United States states also had their own pavilions.', u'The work of noted feminist author Kate McPhelim Cleary was featured during the opening of the Nebraska Day ceremonies at the fair, which included a reading of her poem "Nebraska".', u'Four United States territories also had pavilions: Arizona, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Utah.', u'Visitors to the Louisiana Pavilion were each given a seedling of a cypress tree.', u'This resulted in the spread of cypress trees to areas where they were not native.', u'Cypress trees from those seedlings can be found in many areas of West Virginia, where they flourish in the climate.', u'The Illinois was a detailed, full-scale mockup of an Indiana-class battleship, constructed as a naval exhibit.', u'=== Guns and artillery ===\n\nThe German firm Krupp had a pavilion of artillery, which apparently had cost one million dollars to stage, including a coastal gun of 42 cm in bore (16.54 inches) and a length of 33 calibres (45.93 feet, 14 meters).', u'A breech-loaded gun, it weighed 120.46 long tons (122.4 metric tons).', u'According to the company\'s marketing: "It carried a charge projectile weighing from 2,200 to 2,500 pounds which, when driven by 900 pounds of brown powder, was claimed to be able to penetrate at 2,200 yards a wrought iron plate three feet thick if placed at right angles."', u'Nicknamed "The Thunderer", the gun had an advertised range of 15 miles; on this occasion John Schofield declared Krupps\' guns "the greatest peacemakers in the world".', u"This gun was later seen as a precursor of the company's World War I Dicke Berta howitzers.", u'=== Religions ===\nThe 1893 Parliament of the World\u2019s Religions, which ran from September 11 to September 27, marked the first formal gathering of representatives of Eastern and Western spiritual traditions from around the world.', u'According to Eric J. Sharpe, Tomoko Masuzawa, and others, the event was considered radical at the time, since it allowed non-Christian faiths to speak on their own behalf; it was not taken seriously by European scholars until the 1960s.', u'=== Moving walkway ===\nAlong the banks of the lake, patrons on the way to the casino were taken on a moving walkway, the first of its kind open to the public, called The Great Wharf, Moving Sidewalk, it allowed people to walk along or ride in seats.', u'=== Horticulture ===\nHorticultural exhibits at the Horticultural Hall included cacti and orchids as well as other plants in a greenhouse.', u'== Architectures ==\n\n\n=== White City ===\n\nMost of the buildings of the fair were designed in the neoclassical architecture style.', u'The area at the Court of Honor was known as The White City.', u'Facades were made not of stone, but of a mixture of plaster, cement, and jute fiber called staff, which was painted white, giving the buildings their "gleam".', u'Architecture critics derided the structures as "decorated sheds".', u'The buildings were clad in white stucco, which, in comparison to the tenements of Chicago, seemed illuminated.', u'It was also called the White City because of the extensive use of street lights, which made the boulevards and buildings usable at night.', u"In 1892, working under extremely tight deadlines to complete construction, director of works Daniel Burnham appointed Francis Davis Millet to replace the fair's official director of color, William Pretyman.", u'Pretyman had resigned following a dispute with Burnham.', u'After experimenting, Millet settled on a mix of oil and white lead whitewash that could be applied using compressed air spray painting to the buildings, taking considerably less time than traditional brush painting.', u"Joseph Binks, maintenance supervisor at Chicago's Marshall Field's Wholesale Store, who had been using this method to apply whitewash to the subbasement walls of the store, got the job to paint the Exposition buildings.", u'Claims this was the first use of spray painting may be apocryphal since journals from that time note this form of painting had already been in use in the railroad industry from the early 1880s.', u'=== Role in the City Beautiful Movement ===\n\nThe White City is largely credited for ushering in the City Beautiful movement and planting the seeds of modern city planning.', u'The highly integrated design of the landscapes, promenades, and structures provided a vision of what is possible when planners, landscape architects, and architects work together on a comprehensive design scheme.', u'The White City inspired cities to focus on the beautification of the components of the city in which municipal government had control; streets, municipal art, public buildings and public spaces.', u'The designs of the City Beautiful Movement (closely tied with the municipal art movement) are identifiable by their classical architecture, plan symmetry, picturesque views, axial plans, as well as their magnificent scale.', u'Where the municipal art movement focused on beautifying one feature in a city, the City Beautiful movement began to make improvements on the scale of the district.', u"The White City of the World's Columbian Exposition inspired the Merchants Club of Chicago to commission Daniel Burnham to create the Plan of Chicago in 1909, which became the first modern comprehensive city plan in America.", u'=== Great Buildings ===\n\nThere were fourteen main "great buildings" centered around a giant reflective pool called the Grand Basin.', u'Buildings included:\nThe Administration Building, designed by Richard Morris Hunt\nThe Agricultural Building, designed by Charles McKim of McKim, Mead & White\nThe Manufactures and Liberal Arts Building, designed by George B.', u'Post.', u'If this building were standing today, it would rank second in volume and third in footprint on list of largest buildings (130,000m2, 8,500,000m3).', u'It exhibited works related to literature, science, art and music.', u"The Mines and Mining Building, designed by Solon Spencer Beman\nThe Electricity Building, designed by Henry Van Brunt and Frank Maynard Howe\nThe Machinery Hall, designed by Robert Swain Peabody of Peabody and Stearns\nThe Woman's Building, designed by Sophia Hayden\nThe Transportation Building, designed by Adler & Sullivan\nThe Fisheries Building designed by Henry Ives Cobb\nForestry Building designed by Charles B. Atwood\nHorticultural Building designed by Jenney and Mundie\nAnthropology Building designed by Charles B. Atwood\n\n\n=== Transportation Building ===\n\nLouis Sullivan's polychrome proto-Modern Transportation Building was an outstanding exception to the prevailing style, as he tried to develop an organic American form.", u'Years later, in 1922, he wrote that the classical style of the White City had set back modern American architecture by forty years.', u"As detailed in Erik Larson's popular history The Devil in the White City, extraordinary effort was required to accomplish the exposition, and much of it was unfinished on opening day.", u'The famous Ferris Wheel, which proved to be a major attendance draw and helped save the fair from bankruptcy, was not finished until June, because of waffling by the board of directors the previous year on whether to build it.', u'Frequent debates and disagreements among the developers of the fair added many delays.', u"The spurning of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show proved a serious financial mistake.", u'Buffalo Bill set up his highly popular show next door to the fair and brought in a great deal of revenue that he did not have to share with the developers.', u'Nonetheless, construction and operation of the fair proved to be a windfall for Chicago workers during the serious economic recession that was sweeping the country.', u"=== Surviving structures ===\n\nAlmost all of the fair's structures were designed to be temporary; of the more than 200 buildings erected for the fair, the only two which still stand in place are the Palace of Fine Arts and the World's Congress Auxiliary Building.", u'From the time the fair closed until 1920, the Palace of Fine Arts housed the Field Columbian Museum (now the Field Museum of Natural History, since relocated); in 1933 (having been completely rebuilt in permanent materials), the Palace building re-opened as the Museum of Science and Industry.', u"The second building, the World's Congress Building, was one of the few buildings not built in Jackson Park, instead it was built downtown in Grant Park.", u"The cost of construction of the World's Congress Building was shared with the Art Institute of Chicago, which, as planned, moved into the building (the museum's current home) after the close of the fair.", u'Three other significant buildings survived the fair.', u'The first is the Norway pavilion, a recreation of a traditional wooden stave church which is now preserved at a museum called Little Norway in Blue Mounds, Wisconsin.', u'The second is the Maine State Building, designed by Charles Sumner Frost, which was purchased by the Ricker family of Poland Spring, Maine.', u'They moved the building to their resort to serve as a library and art gallery.', u'The Poland Spring Preservation Society now owns the building, which was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974.', u'The third is the Dutch House, which was moved to Brookline, Massachusetts.', u'The 1893 Viking ship that was sailed to the Exposition from Norway by Captain Magnus Andersen, is located in Geneva, Illinois.', u'The ship is open to visitors on scheduled days April through October.', u'The main altar at St. John Cantius in Chicago, as well as its matching two side altars, are reputed to be from the Columbian Exposition.', u'Since many of the other buildings at the fair were intended to be temporary, they were removed after the fair.', u'The White City, so impressed visitors (at least before air pollution began to darken the fa\xe7ades) that plans were considered to refinish the exteriors in marble or some other material.', u'These plans were abandoned in July 1894, when much of the fair grounds was destroyed in a fire.', u'=== Other architecture at the Fair ===\n\n\n== Visitors ==\nHelen Keller, along with her mentor Anne Sullivan and Dr. Alexander Graham Bell, visited the fair in summer of 1893.', u'Keller described the fair in her autobiography "The Story of My Life".', u'Early in July, a Wellesley College English teacher named Katharine Lee Bates visited the fair.', u'The White City later inspired the reference to "alabaster cities" in her poem "America the Beautiful".', u"The exposition was extensively reported by Chicago publisher William D. Boyce's reporters and artists.", u"There is a very detailed and vivid description of all facets of this fair by the Persian traveler Mirza Mohammad Ali Mo'in ol-Saltaneh written in Persian.", u"He departed from Persia on April 20, 1892, especially for the purpose of visiting the World's Columbian Exposition.", u'Pierre de Coubertin visited the fair with his friends Paul Bourget and Samuel Jean de Pozzi.', u'He devotes the first chapter of his book " Souvenirs d\'Am\xe9rique et de Gr\xe8ce " (1897) to the visit.', u'Swami Vivekananda visited the fair to attend the Parliament of the World\'s Religions and delivered his famous speech "Sisters and brothers of America!".', u'== Souvenirs ==\n\nExamples of exposition souvenirs can be found in various American museum collections.', u'One example, copyrighted in 1892 by John W. Green, is a folding hand fan with detailed illustrations of landscapes and architecture.', u'Charles W Goldsmith produced a set of ten postcard designs, each in full colour, showing the buildings constructed for the exhibition.Columbian Exposition coins were also minted for the event.', u"== Assassination and end of fair ==\nThe fair ended with the city in shock, as popular mayor Carter Harrison, Sr. was assassinated by Patrick Eugene Prendergast two days before the fair's closing.", u'Closing ceremonies were canceled in favor of a public memorial service.', u'Jackson Park was returned to its status as a public park, in much better shape than its original swampy form.', u'The lagoon was reshaped to give it a more natural appearance, except for the straight-line northern end where it still laps up against the steps on the south side of the Palace of Fine Arts/Museum of Science & Industry building.', u'The Midway Plaisance, a park-like boulevard which extends west from Jackson Park, once formed the southern boundary of the University of Chicago, which was being built as the fair was closing (the university has since developed south of the Midway).', u'The university\'s football team, the Maroons, were the original "Monsters of the Midway".', u'The exposition is mentioned in the university\'s alma mater: "The City White hath fled the earth,/But where the azure waters lie,/A nobler city hath its birth,/The City Gray that ne\'er shall die."', u'== Electricity at the fair ==\n\nThe effort to power the Fair with electricity, which became a demonstration piece for Westinghouse Electric and the alternating current system they had been developing for many years, took place at the end of what has been called the War of the currents between DC and AC.', u'Westinghouse initially did not put in a bid to power the Fair but agreed to be the contractor for a local Chicago company that put in a low bid of US$510,000 to supply an alternating current based system.', u'Edison General Electric, which at the time was merging with the Thomson-Houston Electric Company to form General Electric, put in a US$1,720,000 bid to power the Fair and its planned 93,000 incandescent lamps with direct current.', u'After the Fair committee went over both proposals Edison General Electric re-bid their costs at $554,000 but Westinghouse under bid them by 70 cents per lamp to get the contract.', u'Westinghouse could not use the Edison incandescent lamp since the patent belonged to General Electric and they had successfully sued to stop use of all patent infringing designs.', u'Since Edison specified a sealed globe of glass in his design Westinghouse found a way to sidestep the Edison patent by quickly developing a lamp with a ground glass stopper in one end, based on a Sawyer-Man "stopper" lamp patent they already had.', u'The lamps worked well but were short lived, requiring a small army of workmen to constantly replace them.', u'Westinghouse Electric had severely underbid the contract and struggled to supply all the equipment specified including twelve 1,000 horsepower single phase AC generators and all the lighting and other equipment required.', u'They also had to fend off a last minute lawsuit by General Electric claiming the Westinghouse Sawyer-Man based stopper lamp infringed on the Edison incandescent lamp patent.', u'The International Exposition held an Electricity Building which was devoted to electrical exhibits.', u'A statue of Benjamin Franklin was displayed at the entrance.', u"The exposition featured interior and exterior light and displays as well as displays of Thomas Edison's kinetoscope, search lights, a seismograph, electric incubators for chicken eggs, and Morse code telegraph.", u'All the exhibits were from commercial enterprises.', u'Participants included General Electric, Brush, Western Electric, and Westinghouse.', u'The Westinghouse Company displayed several polyphase systems.', u'The exhibits included a switchboard, polyphase generators, step-up transformers, transmission line, step-down transformers, commercial size induction motors and synchronous motors, and rotary direct current converters (including an operational railway motor).', u'The working scaled system allowed the public a view of a system of polyphase power which could be transmitted over long distances, and be utilized, including the supply of direct current.', u'Meters and other auxiliary devices were also present.', u'Part of the space occupied by the Westinghouse Company was devoted to demonstrations of electrical devices developed by Nikola Tesla including a two-phase induction motor, and generators to power the system.', u'Tesla demonstrated a series of electrical effects, some which were in previous lectures performed in America and Europe.', u'This included using high-voltage, high-frequency alternating current to light a wireless gas-discharge lamp.', u'Also at the Fair, the Chicago Athletic Association Football team played one of the very first night football games against West Point (the earliest being on September 28, 1892 between Mansfield State Normal and Wyoming Seminary).', u'Chicago won the game 14-0.', u'The game lasted only 40 minutes, compared to the normal 90 minutes.', u'== Music at the fair ==\n\n\n=== Musicians ===\n\nJoseph Douglass, classical violinist, who achieved wide recognition after his performance there and became the first African-American violinist to conduct a transcontinental tour and the first to tour as a concert violinist.', u'Sissieretta Jones, a soprano known as "the Black Patti" and an already-famous opera singer.', u'A paper on African-American spirituals and shouts by Abigail Christensen was read to attendees.', became widely known for his piano playing at the fair.', u'=== Other music and musicians ===\nJohn Philip Sousa\u2032s Band played for the Exposition dedication celebration in Chicago, 10 October through 21 October 1892.', u'The first Indonesian music performance in the United States was at the exposition.', u'The gamelan instruments used in the performance were later placed in the Field Museum of Natural History.', u'A group of hula dancers led to increased awareness of Hawaiian music among Americans throughout the country.', u'Stoughton Musical Society, the oldest choral society in the United States, presented the first concerts of early American music at the exposition.', u'The first eisteddfod (a Welsh choral competition with a history spanning many centuries) held outside Wales was held in Chicago at the exposition.', u'A 250-voice Mormon Tabernacle Choir competed in the Eisteddfod taking the second place prize of $1000.', u'This was the first appearance of the Choir Frontier thesis.', u'The Pledge of Allegiance was first performed at the exposition by a mass of school children lined up in military fashion.', u'Contribution to Chicago\'s nickname, the "Windy City".', u"Some argue that Charles Anderson Dana of the New York Sun coined the term related to the hype of the city's promoters.", u'Other evidence, however, suggests the term was used as early as 1881 in relation to either Chicago\'s "windbag" politicians or to its weather.', u"=== Commemorations ===\nUnited States Mint offered its first commemorative coins: a quarter and half dollar\nThe United States Post Office Department produced its first picture postcards and Commemorative stamp set\n\n\n=== Edibles and potables ===\nCream of Wheat\nMilton Hershey bought a European exhibitor's chocolate manufacturing equipment and added chocolate products to his caramel manufacturing business\nJuicy Fruit gum\nQuaker Oats\nShredded Wheat\nPabst Blue Ribbon\nAunt Jemima pancake mix was widely popularized by spokesperson Nancy Green's pancake cooking and story telling performances.", u'=== Inventions and manufacturing advances ===\n\nA device that made plates for printing books in Braille, unveiled by Frank Haven Hall, who met Helen Keller and her teacher Anne Sullivan at the exhibit.', u'Moving walkway, or travelator\nThe third rail giving electric power to elevated trains led directly to its first continuing US use.', u'The "clasp locker," a clumsy slide fastener and forerunner to the zipper was demonstrated by Whitcomb L. Judson\nElongated coins (the squashed penny)\nFerris Wheel\nFirst fully electrical kitchen including an automatic dishwasher\nPhosphorescent lamps (a precursor to fluorescent lamps)\nJohn T. Shayne & Company, the local Chicago furrier helped America gain respect on the world stage of manufacturing\n\n\n=== Organizations ===\nCongress of Mathematicians, precursor to International Congress of Mathematicians\nInterfaith dialogue (the Parliament of the World\u2019s Religions)\n\n\n=== Performances ===\nThe poet and humorist Benjamin Franklin King, Jr. first performed at the exposition.', u'== Later years ==\nThe exposition was one influence leading to the rise of the City Beautiful movement.', u'Results included grand buildings and fountains built around Olmstedian parks, shallow pools of water on axis to central buildings, larger park systems, broad boulevards and parkways and, after the start of the 20th century, zoning laws and planned suburbs.', u"Examples of the City Beautiful movement's works include the City of Chicago, the Columbia University campus, and the National Mall in Washington D.C.\nAfter the fair closed, J.C. Rogers, a banker from Wamego, Kansas, purchased several pieces of art that had hung in the rotunda of the U.S. Government Building.", u'He also purchased architectural elements, artifacts and buildings from the fair.', u'He shipped his purchases to Wamego.', u'Many of the items, including the artwork, were used to decorate his theater, now known as the Columbian Theatre.', u'Memorabilia saved by visitors can still be purchased.', u'Numerous books, tokens, published photographs, and well-printed admission tickets can be found.', u'While the higher value commemorative stamps are expensive, the lower ones are quite common.', u'So too are the commemorative half dollars, many of which went into circulation.', u'Although not available for purchase, The George Washington University maintains a small collection of exposition tickets for viewing and research purposes.', u"The collection is currently cared for by GWU's Special Collections Research Center, located in the Estelle and Melvin Gelman Library.", u"When the exposition ended the Ferris Wheel was moved to Chicago's north side, next to an exclusive neighborhood.", u'An unsuccessful Circuit Court action was filed against the owners of the wheel to have it moved.', u"The wheel stayed there until it was moved to St. Louis for the 1904 World's Fair.", u"== See also ==\n\nList of world expositions\nList of world's fairs\nBenjamin W. Kilburn, stereoscopic view concession and subsequent views of the Colombian World's Exposition.", u"Herman Webster Mudgett, serial killer associated with the 1893 World's Fair\nSt. John Cantius in Chicago, whose main altar, as well as its matching two side altars, reputedly originate from the 1893 Columbian Exposition\nSpectacle Reef Light\nWorld's Largest Cedar Bucket\nFairy lamp, candle sets popularized at Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee were used to illuminate an island at the Expo\nMedia about the fair\n1893: A World's Fair Mystery, an interactive fiction by Peter Nepstad that recreates the Exposition in detail\nAgainst the Day, a fictional novel that takes place during the Exposition during the first act.", u"Devil in the White City, a non-fiction book intertwining the true tales of the architect behind the 1893 World's Fair and serial killer H. H. Holmes\nExpo: Magic of the White City, a documentary film about the exposition\nJimmy Corrigan, the Smartest Kid on Earth, a graphic novel set in part at the Chicago World's Columbian Exposition of 1893\nWonder of the Worlds, an adventure novel where Nikola Tesla, Mark Twain and Houdini pursue Martian agents who have stolen a powerful crystal from Tesla at the Columbia Exposition\n\n\n== References and notes ==\nGeneral\nCrawford, Richard (2001).", u"America's Musical Life: A History.", u'W. {'sentences': [u'Tony Sheridan (Anthony Esmond Sheridan McGinnity; 21 May 1940 \u2013 16 February 2013) was an English rock and roll singer-songwriter and guitarist.', u'He was best known as an early collaborator of the Beatles (though the record was labelled as being with "The Beat Brothers"), one of two non-Beatles (the other being Billy Preston) to receive label performance credit on a record with the group, and the only non-Beatle to appear as lead singer on a Beatles recording which charted as a single.', u'== Biography ==\nSheridan was born in Norwich, Norfolk, where he grew up at 2 Hansell Road in Thorpe St Andrew and attended the City of Norwich School.', u"In his early life, Sheridan was influenced by his parents' interest in classical music, and by age seven, he had learned to play the violin.", u'He eventually came to play guitar, and in 1956, formed his first band.', u'He showed enough talent that he soon found himself playing in London\'s "Two I\'s" club for some six months straight.', u'In 1958, aged 18, he began appearing on Oh Boy, made by the ITV contractor ABC, playing electric guitar on such early rock classics as "Blue Suede Shoes", "Glad All Over", "Mighty Mighty Man" and "Oh Boy!".', u'He was soon employed backing a number of singers, reportedly including Gene Vincent and Conway Twitty while they were in England.', u"In 1958 Johnny Foster sought to recruit Sheridan as a guitar player in Cliff Richard's backing band (soon renamed the Shadows), but after failing to find him at the 2i's Coffee Bar opted for another guitarist who was there, Hank Marvin.", u'Early in 1960, he performed in a tour of the UK, along with Vincent and Eddie Cochran.', u'On 16 April, Vincent and Cochran rebuffed his request to ride along with them to the next venue, but he thereby escaped the road accident which would leave Cochran dead and Vincent badly injured.', u'Sheridan played guitar for Cherry Wainer on her recording of "Happy Organ".', u'Despite these successes, his penchant for being late, showing up without his guitar, etc., soon got him a reputation for having gone a bit "haywire", and cost him much of his professional standing in England.', u'Providentially, an offer for a gig came from Bruno Koschmider\'s "Kaiserkeller" club in Hamburg, Germany for an English group to play there.', u'Sheridan and others (including Colin "Melander" Crawley) joined an ad hoc group promptly dubbed "The Jets" and were put on the ship headed for Hamburg.', u'As fate would have it, legal woes (i.e.', u'lack of proper papers) caused "The Jets" to not last long, but Sheridan (and now-friend Colin "Melander" Crawley) were soon back onstage in Hamburg.', u'While performing in Hamburg between 1960 and 1963, Sheridan employed various backup bands, most of which were really "pickup bands", or simply an amalgam of various musicians, rather than a group proper (though almost always including now bassist Colin "Melander" Crawley).', u'However, in 1961, the young Beatles (with their line-up at the time of John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Pete Best) who had met and admired Sheridan during their first visit to Hamburg in 1960, and who openly worked with him on their second visit, became even closer.', u'The Beatles sometimes backed Sheridan, who, in turn, often joined the Beatles during their own sets backing them on guitar.', u"They even visited Sheridan's home and had jamming sessions in the back garden \nWhen German Polydor producer/A and R man Bert Kaempfert saw the pairing on stage, he suggested that Sheridan and the Beatles make some recordings together.", u'Kaempfert viewed Sheridan as the one with "star" potential, and though they signed the Beatles to play on Sheridan\'s records their contract with them stipulated that the four Beatles (Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Best) were insured to play on a minimum of two songs.', u"Of the seven songs recorded during Sheridan's two-day-long sessions for Polydor in June 1961, it should be pointed out that at times the band behind Sheridan would be down to only two Beatles, and that conversely only on their two solo songs do all four Beatles play (minus Sheridan), while Sheridan plays on all of his tracks.", u"John Lennon's rhythm guitar is heard only on the two Beatle solo tracks (though his voice is heard in background vocals on Sheridan's tracks).", u'These sessions produced Sheridan\'s "My Bonnie" and "The Saints", and the Beatles\' "Ain\'t She Sweet" and "Cry for a Shadow" (formerly titled "Beatle Bop"), plus three other songs.', u"Polydor's beliefs in Sheridan's coming stardom were so strong that they buried the two solo Beatle tracks until much later.", u'Both John Lennon and Tony Sheridan swore that there were several other Beatle tracks that were recorded during the two-day session, but they have not resurfaced.', u'In 1962, after a series of singles (the first of which, "My Bonnie"/"The Saints" made it to number 5 in the German chart), the record was released in America on Decca with a black label and also in a pink label for demo play.', u'The record has the distinction of being one of the most expensive collectible 45 rpm with the black label in mint condition selling for $15,000 in 2007 and the pink label selling for $3000.', u"Ringo Starr briefly played in Sheridan's backing band during very early 1962, before returning to Rory Storm and the Hurricanes.", u"Starr was reportedly unhappy with Sheridan performing songs he had not rehearsed with his band (other musicians made the same complaint, as well as about Sheridan's penchant for fist-fights).", u'Also in 1962, Polydor released the album My Bonnie across Germany.', u'The word "Beatles" was judged to sound too similar to the Hamburgisch dialect word "Pidels" (pronounced "peedles"), the plural of a slang term for penis, hence the album was credited to "Tony Sheridan and the Beat Brothers".', u'Amusingly, that very unintentional-naughty-pun was one thing that so many young German fans had found amusing but enchanting.', u'After the Beatles had gained fame, the album was re-released in the United Kingdom, with the credit altered to "Tony Sheridan and the Beatles".', u"The Beatles' Hamburg studio recordings, as well as some live recordings from the same period, have been reissued many times.", u"In the mid-1960s, Sheridan's musical style underwent a drastic transformation, away from his rock and roll roots and towards a more blues- and jazz-oriented sound.", u'Though these recordings were praised by some, many fans of his earlier work felt wildly disappointed.', u'This change was presaged by liner notes from his 1964 album Just a Little Bit of Tony Sheridan in which his musical preferences are listed as "jazz and classical" rather than rock.', u'The liner notes also mention his wanting to visit the southern US "to hear at first hand the original negro music and experience the atmosphere that has been instrumental in creating negro jazz and the spiritual, for which he has a great liking."', u'Polydor continued releasing Sheridan singles through 1966 (though they only ever released two albums by him).', u'By 1967, Sheridan had become disillusioned with his Beatle-brought fame.', u'As he was more concerned by the Vietnam War and the thought of further Communist aggression, as such Sheridan agreed to perform for the Allied troops.', u'While in Vietnam however, the band that he had assembled was fired upon and one of the members was killed.', u'For his work entertaining the Allies, Sheridan was made an honorary Captain of the United States Army.', u'Due to the repeated shellings encountered there, Sheridan henceforth suffered a great sensitivity to the sounds of any kind of explosions, even fireworks.', u'With his Polydor contract gone Sheridan did what he could to survive.', u"In the early '70's he managed to cut a single as a pop duo teamed with Carole Bell, and they toured Europe together with fair success.", u'Following that phase he returned to playing in Germany (usually Hamburg) or London.', u'The mid-1970s, saw him deejaying a West German radio programme of blues music, which was well received.', u'Somehow he then managed to record an entire live album of early rock classics, a number of which had been part of his and the young Beatles early live act but of which had never gotten recorded.', u"Fortuitously in 1978 a record producer in America heard Sheridan's early Polydor recordings (with and without the young Beatles), and was enthralled by Tony's singing and playing.", u'Immediately Sheridan was offered and wisely accepted the offer to come and record a whole studio album in Los Angeles.', u"Making the entire thing sweeter was the fact that Elvis' (now out of work) TCB Band was hired to play on the album along with top bassist (and former Hamburg friend) Klaus Voormann.", u'A fine album of rock classics plus a few country tunes resulted, but with no major label release, it was doomed to direct TV sales.', u'Thus the possible prospect of a long American career in Las Vegas evaporated.', u"In 1978, the Star Club was reopened, and Sheridan performed there along with Elvis Presley's TCB Band.", u"In 1991, Joe Sunseri, Sheridan biographer and then-manager, completed Nobody's Child: The Tony Sheridan Story.", u'However, due to a falling-out, the biography remained unpublished.', u'A biography of Sheridan, titled The Teacher (ISBN 0957528507), was eventually published in 2013 by Norfolk author Alan Mann, a childhood-friend of Sheridan.', u'This book was essentially an email question and answer interview.', u"While repeated probings by the author did bring out Sheridan's one time of two weeks spent in an English jail, aside from that the author unfortunately takes Sheridan's memory of things at total face value.", u'On 13 August 2002, Sheridan released Vagabond, a collection largely of his own material, but also including a new cover version of "Skinny Minnie", a song he had years earlier recorded for his first album.', u'Tony played guitar and sang for the Argentinian rock musician Charly Garcia.', u'The album was called Influencia and it was released in 2002.', u'In 2015, Colin "Melander" Crawley - Sheridan\'s former bassist, published another biography, Tony Sheridan - The One The personal life though it's known that he was married three times, lastly to the very young Anna Sievers, and previously to Rosi Heitmann and to Hazel Byng.", u'His friend and former bassist Colin {'sentences': [u'Non-denominated postage is postage intended to meet a certain postage rate that retains full validity for that intended postage rate even after the rate is increased.', u'It does not show a monetary value, or denomination, on the face.', u'In many English-speaking countries, it is called non-value indicator (NVI) postage.', u'Invented to reduce the cost of printing large issues of low-value stamps to "top-up" old issues, NVI stamps are used worldwide, including in the United States and some European countries.', u'== UPU approval ==\nThe Universal Postal Union approved the use of non-denominated stamps on international mail in 1995.', u'== Canada ==\nCanada\'s NVI was called the "Permanent" stamp, which is a trademarked term.', u'It was originally marked by a white capital "P" overlaid on a red maple leaf, which is itself within a white circle.', u'Later releases, such as the 2009 Silver Dart commemorative, varied the colours.', u'In that example, the Maple Leaf around the "P" is white and the "P" is dropped out.', u'The circle does not appear.', u'In announcing its decision to adopt non-denominated postage in 2006, Canada Post noted that it had to print more than 60 million one-cent stamps following the last price increase in 2005.', u'The Canadian NVI program was essentially equivalent to the American NVI program, as both covered regular domestic first-class mail.', u'One Canada Post NVI stamp covers the cost of mailing a standard letter up to 30 g within Canada.', u'On 11 December 2013, Canada Post unveiled its Five-point Action Plan, which temporarily removed "Permanent" stamps from sale, although they remained valid for postage.', u'On March 31, the regular domestic stamp price increased from CA$0.63 to CA$0.85 (roll & bundle issued stamps) and up to $1.00 for single stamp purchase, beginning on 31 March 2014.', u'Sale of "Permanent" stamps resumed on that day at the new rate.', u'== Ireland ==\nAn Post issue "N" stamps at the current domestic posting rate, which allow posting to both the Republic and Northern Ireland.', u'These are generally available in post offices, yet not commonly sold.', u'"E" stamps were briefly available, which allowed posting to anywhere in the European Union, but have not been sold in many years.', u'== The Netherlands ==\nPostNL now issues all first-class stamps as NVIs, which simply bear a large numeral \u201c1\u201d that varies to match the typography used for each particular issue.', u'Stamps meeting the first-class rate to Europe additionally bear the marking \u201cEuropa\u201d, and those to foreign destinations outside of Europe bear the marking \u201cWereld\u201d (\u201cWorld\u201d).', u'== Belgium ==\nSame as The Netherlands\n\n\n== New Zealand ==\nNew Zealand Post started issuing the Kiwistamp in 2009.', u'One stamp will always be worth the required postage of a Standard Post medium domestic letter.', u'Customers may use multiple Kiwistamps or mix them with denominated stamps to make up the required postage for bigger domestic or international mail.', u'== Singapore ==\nSingapore has two NVIs today: 1st Local and 2nd Local.', u'The first Singapore NVIs were issued in 1995; almost every issue had a "For Local Addresses Only" stamp.', u'Later, in 2004, a new NVI denomination was released: "2nd Local".', u'Since then almost all issues have "1st Local" stamps, and some have "2nd Local" stamps, rather than the previous "For Local Addresses Only".', u'1st Local stamps are valid for standard letters within Singapore up to 20 g, and 2nd Local stamps are valid for standard letters within Singapore up to 40 g.\n\n\n== Russia ==\nRussian Post sells envelopes and postcards with pre-printed non-denominated stamps for domestic mail, A for regular domestic mail, B for postcards, and D for registered mail.', u'== Scandinavia ==\n\n\n=== \xc5land ===\nThe \xc5land Islands use the following NVI denominations: Lokalpost (domestic, within \xc5land only), Inrikes (Finland), Europa (Europe), V\xe4rlden (the world), 1 klass (1st class), 2 klass (2nd class), and Julpost (Christmas mail).', u'The current values of non-denominated \xc5land postage stamps, or no-value indicator (NVI) is: Lokalpost (domestic, within \xc5land only): \u20ac0.75, Inrikes (Finland): \u20ac0.95, Europa (Europe): \u20ac0.95, V\xe4rlden (the world): \u20ac1.00, 1 klass (1st class): \u20ac0.75, 2 klass (2nd class): \u20ac0.60 and Julpost (Christmas mail): \u20ac0.55.', u"=== Finland ===\nFinland's first NVI stamp (ikimerkki) was issued on 2.3.1992.", u'There are two denominations, one valid for domestic 1st class, or overnight, domestic letter of up to 50 g and the other for similar 2nd class letter.', u'The stamps may be combined for more expensive tariffs.', u'=== Sweden ===\nSweden currently issues three forms of NVI valid for letters within Sweden of up to 20 g. These stamps may be combined when the weight of a letter exceeds 20 g. For up to 100 g \u2013 use two stamps; for up to 250 g \u2013 use 4 stamps; 500 g \u2013 6 stamps; 1 kg \u2013 8 stamps; 2 kg \u2013 12 stamps.', u'These charges only apply to regular letters \u2013 surcharges apply to bulkier letters.', u'The Swedish name for NVI stamps is "val\xf6rl\xf6sa frim\xe4rken".', u'Brev: first class overnight delivery within Sweden.', u"Brev ('letter') or Brev Inrikes ('letter domestic') is printed on the stamps.", u'Price as of January 2009 - 6 SEK;\nEkonomibrev: second class (up to three days for delivery) within Sweden.', u'Price as of January 2009 - 5.50 SEK.', u'Note: Economy Mail should be marked with a B to the left of the stamp;\nF\xf6reningsbrev: rate for not-for-profit organizations.', u'Price as of January 2009 - 5.00 SEK.', u'Not-for-profit problem of fast-changing rates.', u'The British Post Office has issued "non-value indicated" Machins using textual inscriptions "1ST" and "2ND" to indicate class of service rather than a numeric value.', u'It has since introduced a number of variations including those for worldwide and European use, for different weights, and for postcards.', u'== United States ==\n\n\n=== Letter-denominated stamps ===\nIn past years, non-denominated postage issued by the United States differed from the issues of other countries, in that the stamps retained their original monetary value.', u'Some stamps, such as those intended for local or bulk mail rate, were issued without denomination.', u'This practice began in 1975, when there was uncertainty as to the timing and extent of a rate increase from ten cents for the first ounce of first class postage as the end of the year approached.', u'Christmas stamps were released without denomination, giving the United States Postal Service flexibility to refrain from reprinting hundreds of millions of stamps in a new denomination.', u'The rate increase, to thirteen cents (US$0.13), occurred just after Christmas.', u'The United States also issued stamps with letter denomination, beginning from A, B, etc., during postal rate changes.', u'After reaching the letter "H", this practice was discarded in favor of simply indicating the class of postage (e.g., first class) for which the stamp was intended.', u'=== Forever stamps ===\nIn 2006, the US Postal Service applied for permission to issue a stamp similar to non-denominated stamps in the UK, termed the "forever stamp", for first-class postage.', u'On March 26, 2007, the US Postal Service unveiled the first such stamp, which went on sale April 12, 2007, for 41 cents (US$0.41), the so-called "Liberty Bell" stamp, which is marked "USA FIRST-CLASS FOREVER".', u'On October 21, 2010, the second Forever Stamp, featuring pinecones on evergreen trees, was issued for the holiday season.', u'Coils of Forever stamps were first issued on December 1, 2010, in the se-tenant format with Lady Liberty and the Flag design.', u'A re-design, announced June 16, 2011, featured four American scientists: Melvin Calvin, chemist; Asa Gray, botanist; Maria Goeppert Mayer, physicist; and Severo Ochoa, biochemist.', u'These stamps are always sold at the current first-class postage rate.', u"They are always valid for the full first-class postage regardless of any rate increases since the stamps' purchase (e.g., unused forever stamps purchased in April 2007 therefore are valid for the current first-class postage rate, despite having been purchased for 41 cents).", u'In 2011, all first-class stamps were made to be forever stamps.', u'In 2015 the concept of forever stamps was expanded into all other types of stamps-postcard, additional ounce, non-machinable surcharge, two ounce and three ounce and these stamps have their intended purpose printed on them instead of a number.', u'Some fundraising (or semipostal) stamps have had this feature for years.', u'For example, the breast cancer research stamp was issued in 1998.', u'Forever Stamps can be used for international mail if additional postage is attached.', u'Alternatively, in the beginning of 2013, the USPS introduced a Global Forever stamp, for first-class one-ounce international mail.', u'In October of the same year, another Global Forever stamp with a Christmas motif was issued.', u'Two new stamps were issued the following year.', u'For collectors all four were also printed in small numbers without die cuts, and so were imperforated.', u'Another Global Forever issue, showing the Moon, followed in 2016.', u'This was only issued with die cuts.', u'== See also ==\nDenomination Congressional mandate, to deliver rapidly, combined-arms task forces on land, at sea, and in the air.', u'The U.S. Marine Corps is one of the four armed service branches in the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) and one of the seven uniformed services of the United States.', u'The current Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the highest-ranking military officer in the U.S. armed forces, is a Marine Corps general.', u'The Marine Corps has been a component of the U.S. Department of the Navy since 30 June 1834, working closely with naval forces for training, transportation, and logistics.', u'The USMC operates posts on land and aboard sea-going amphibious warfare ships around the world.', u"Additionally, several of the Marines' tactical aviation squadrons, primarily Marine Fighter Attack squadrons, are also embedded in Navy carrier air wings and operate from the Navy's nuclear-powered aircraft carriers.", u'Two battalions of Continental Marines were formed on 10 November 1775 in Philadelphia as a service branch of infantry troops capable of fighting for independence both at sea and on shore.', u'The role of the Corps has since grown and evolved, expanding to aerial warfare and earning popular titles such as, "America\'s third air force", and, "second land army".', u'The United States Marine Corps has distinguished itself as it has served in the majority of American wars and armed conflicts, from its inception to the modern era, and attained prominence in the 20th century when its theories and practices of amphibious warfare proved prescient and ultimately formed the cornerstone of the Pacific theater of World War II.', u"By the mid-20th century, the U.S. Marine Corps had become a major theorist of and the world's dominant practitioner of amphibious warfare.", u'Its ability to rapidly respond on short notice to expeditionary crises gives it a strong role in the implementation and execution of American foreign policy.', u'As of 2016, the USMC has around 182,000 active duty members and some 38,500 reserve Marines.', u'It is the smallest of the U.S. Armed Forces within the U.S. DoD.', u'== Mission ==\nThe USMC serves as an expeditionary force-in-readiness.', u'As outlined in 10 U.S.C.', u'\xa7 5063 and as originally introduced under the National Security Act of 1947, it has three primary areas of responsibility:\nThe seizure or defense of advanced naval bases and other land operations to support naval campaigns;\nThe development of tactics, technique, and equipment used by amphibious landing forces in coordination with the Army and Air Force; and\nSuch other duties as the President may direct.', u"This last clause, while seemingly redundant given the President's position as Commander-in-chief, is a codification of the expeditionary responsibilities of the Marine Corps.", u'It derives from similar language in the Congressional acts "For the Better Organization of the Marine Corps" of 1834, and "Establishing and Organizing a Marine Corps" of 1798.', u'In 1951, the House of Representatives\' Armed Services Committee called the clause "one of the most important statutory \u2013 and traditional \u2013 functions of the Marine Corps."', u'It noted that the Corps has more often than not performed actions of a non-naval nature, including its famous actions in Tripoli, the War of 1812, Chapultepec, and numerous counter-insurgency and occupational duties (such as those in Central America), World War I, and the Korean War.', u'While these actions are not accurately described as support of naval campaigns nor as amphibious warfare, their common thread is that they are of an expeditionary nature, using the mobility of the Navy to provide timely intervention in foreign affairs on behalf of American interests.', u'In addition to its primary duties, the Marine Corps conducts Visit, Board, Search, and Seizure (VBSS) operations, as well as missions in direct support of the White House and the State Department.', u'The Marine Band, dubbed the "President\'s Own" by Thomas Jefferson, provides music for state functions at the White House.', u'Marines from Ceremonial Companies A & B, quartered in authority of the 1946 Foreign Service Act, the Marine Security Guards of the Marine Embassy Security Command provide security for American embassies, legations, and consulates at more than 140 posts worldwide.', u'The relationship between the Department of State and the U.S. Marine Corps is nearly as old as the corps itself.', u'For over 200 years, Marines have served at the request of various between the Department of State and the Secretary of the Navy on December 15, 1948, and 83 Marines were deployed to overseas missions.', u'During the first year of the MSG program, 36 detachments were deployed worldwide.', u"=== Historical mission ===\nThe Marine Corps was founded to serve as an infantry unit aboard naval vessels and was responsible for the security of the ship and its crew by conducting offensive and defensive combat during boarding actions and defending the ship's officers from mutiny; to the latter end, their quarters on ship were often strategically positioned between the officers' quarters and the rest of the vessel.", u'Continental Marines manned raiding parties, both at sea and ashore.', u"America's first amphibious assault landing occurred early in the Revolutionary War on 3 March 1776 as the Marines gained control of Fort Montague and Fort Nassau, a British ammunition depot and naval port in New Providence, the Bahamas.", u'The role of the Marine Corps has expanded significantly since then; as the importance of its original naval mission declined with changing naval warfare doctrine and the professionalization of the naval service, the Corps adapted by focusing on formerly secondary missions ashore.', u'The Advanced Base Doctrine of the early 20th century codified their combat duties ashore, outlining the use of Marines in the seizure of bases and other duties on land to support naval campaigns.', u'Throughout the late 19th and 20th centuries, Marine detachments served aboard Navy cruisers, battleships and aircraft carriers.', u"Marine detachments (generally one platoon per cruiser, a company for battleships or carriers) served in their traditional duties as a ship's landing force, manning the ship's weapons and providing shipboard security.", u"Marine detachments were augmented by members of the ship's company for landing parties, such as in the First Sumatran Expedition of 1832, and continuing in the Caribbean and Mexican campaigns of the early 20th centuries.", u'Marines would develop tactics and techniques of amphibious assault on defended coastlines in time for use in World War II.', u'During World War II, Marines continued to serve on capital ships.', u'They often were assigned to man anti-aircraft batteries.', u'When gun cruisers were retired by the 1960s, the remaining Marine detachments were only seen on battleships and carriers.', u'Its original mission of providing shipboard security finally ended in the 1990s as the battleships were retired and nuclear weapons were withdrawn from deployment on aircraft carriers.', u'=== Capabilities ===\n\nThe Marine Corps fulfills a vital role in national security as an amphibious, expeditionary, air-ground combined arms task force, capable of forcible entry from the air, land, and sea.', u'It is capable of asymmetric warfare with conventional, irregular, and hybrid forces.', u'While the Marine Corps does not employ any unique combat arms, as a force it can rapidly deploy a combined-arms task force to almost anywhere in the world within days.', u'The basic structure for all deployed units is a Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) that integrates a ground combat element, an aviation combat element and a logistics combat element under a common command element.', u"While the creation of joint commands under the Goldwater\u2013Nichols Act has improved inter-service coordination between each branch, the Corps' ability to permanently maintain integrated multi-element task forces under a single command provides a smoother implementation of combined-arms warfare principles.", u'The close integration of disparate Marine units stems from an organizational culture centered on the infantry.', u'Every other Marine capability exists to support the infantry.', u'Unlike some Western militaries, the Corps remained conservative against theories proclaiming the ability of new weapons to win wars independently.', u'For example, Marine aviation has always been focused on close air support and has remained largely uninfluenced by air power theories proclaiming that strategic bombing can single-handedly win wars.', u'This focus on the infantry is matched with the doctrine of "Every Marine [is] a rifleman", a focus of Commandant Alfred M. Gray, Jr., emphasizing the infantry combat abilities of every Marine.', u'All Marines, regardless of military specialization, receive training as a rifleman; and all officers receive additional training as infantry platoon commanders.', u'For example, at Wake Island, when all of the Marine aircraft were shot down, pilots continued the fight as ground officers, leading supply clerks and cooks in a final defensive effort.', u'As a result, a large degree of initiative and autonomy is expected of junior Marines, particularly the NCOs (corporals and sergeants), as compared with many other military organizations.', u'The Marine Corps emphasizes authority and responsibility downward to a greater degree than the other military services.', u'Flexibility of execution is implemented via an emphasis on "commander\'s intent" as a guiding principle for carrying out orders; specifying the end state but leaving open the method of execution.', u'The amphibious assault techniques developed for World War II evolved, with the addition of air assault and maneuver warfare doctrine, into the current "Operational Maneuver from the Sea" doctrine of power projection from the seas.', u'The Marines are credited with the development of helicopter insertion doctrine and were the earliest in the American military to widely adopt maneuver-warfare principles which emphasize low-level initiative and flexible execution.', u"In light of recent warfare that has strayed from the Corps' traditional missions, it has renewed an emphasis on amphibious capabilities.", u'The Marine Corps relies on the Navy for sealift to provide its rapid deployment capabilities.', u'In addition to basing a third of the Fleet Marine Force in Japan, Marine Expeditionary Units (MEU) are typically stationed at sea.', u'This allows the ability to function as first responders to international incidents.', u'The United States Army maintains light infantry units capable of rapid worldwide deployment, but those units do not match the combined-arms integration of an MAGTF and lack the logistics that the Navy provides.', u'Therefore, the Marine Corps is often assigned to non-combat missions such as the evacuation of Americans from unstable countries and providing humanitarian relief during natural disasters.', u'In larger conflicts, Marines act as a stopgap, to get into and hold an area until larger units can be mobilized.', u'The Corps performed this role in World War I and the Korean War, where Marines were the first significant combat units deployed from the United States and held the line until the country could mobilize for war.', u'To aid rapid deployment, the Maritime Pre-Positioning System was developed: fleets of container ships are positioned throughout the world with enough equipment and framework for Marine counter-insurgency operations from Vietnam to Iraq and Afghanistan while the Tentative Landing Operations Manual established the doctrine for the amphibious operations of World the Continental Marines of the American Revolutionary War, formed by Captain Samuel Nicholas by a resolution of the Second Continental Congress on 10 November 1775, to raise two battalions of Marines.', u"That date is regarded and celebrated as the date of the Marine Corps' birthday.", u'At the end of the American Revolution, both the Continental Navy and Continental Marines were disbanded in April 1783.', u'The institution itself would not be resurrected until 11 July 1798.', u'At that time, in preparation for the Quasi-War with France, Congress created the United States Marine Corps.', u'Marines had been enlisted by the War Department as early as August 1797 for service in the new-build frigates authorized by the Congressional "Act to provide a Naval Armament" of 18 March Tripoli has been immortalized in the Marines' hymn and the Mameluke Sword carried by Marine officers.", u'During the War of 1812, Marine naval detachments took part in some of the great frigate duels that characterized the war, which were the first and last engagements of the conflict.', u"Their most significant contribution, however, was holding the center of General Jackson's defensive line at the Battle of New Orleans, the final major battle and most one-sided engagement of the war.", u'With widespread news of the battle and the capture of the HMS Cyane, HMS Levant and HMS Penguin, the final engagements between British and American forces, the Marines had acquired a well-deserved reputation as expert marksmen, especially in defensive and ship-to-ship actions.', u'After the war, the Marine Corps fell into a malaise that ended with the appointment of Archibald Henderson as its fifth Commandant in 1820.', u'Under his tenure, the Corps took on expeditionary duties in the Caribbean, the Gulf of Mexico, Key West, West Africa, the Falkland Islands, and Sumatra.', u"Commandant Henderson is credited with thwarting President Jackson's attempts to combine and integrate the Marine Corps with the Army.", u'Instead, Congress passed the Act for the Better Organization of the Marine Corps in 1834, stipulating that the Corps was part of the Department of the Navy as a sister service to the Navy.', u'This would be the first of many times that the existence of the Corps was challenged.', u'Commandant Henderson volunteered the Marines for service in the Seminole Wars of 1835, American Civil War to World War I ===\nThe remainder of the 19th century was marked by declining strength and introspection about the mission of the Marine Corps.', u"The Navy's transition from sail to steam put into question the need for Marines on naval ships.", u'Meanwhile, Marines served as a convenient resource for interventions and landings to protect American lives and interests overseas.', u'The Corps was involved in over 28 separate interventions in the 30 years from the end of the American Civil War to the end of 19th century, with 148 U.S. Marines killed in action
