{'sentences': [u'Vietnam (UK /\u02ccvj\u025bt\u02c8n\xe6m, -\u02c8n\u0251\u02d0m/, US /\u02ccvi\u02d0\u0259t\u02c8n\u0251\u02d0m, -\u02c8n\xe6m/; Vietnamese: Vi\u1ec7t Nam [vi\u0259t\u02e8 n\xe6m\u02e7]), officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (SRV; Vietnamese: C\u1ed9ng h\xf2a X\xe3 h\u1ed9i ch\u1ee7 ngh\u0129a Vi\u1ec7t Nam ( listen)), is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia.', u"With an estimated 90.5 million inhabitants as of 2014, it is the world's 14th-most-populous country, and the eighth-most-populous Asian country.", u'Vietnam is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and Malaysia across the South China Sea to the southeast.', u'Its capital city has been Hanoi since the reunification of North and South Vietnam in 1975.', u'Vietnam was part of Imperial China for over a millennium, from 111 BC to AD 939.', u'An independent Vietnamese state was formed in 939, following a Vietnamese victory in the Battle of B\u1ea1ch \u0110\u1eb1ng River.', u'Successive Vietnamese royal dynasties flourished as the nation expanded geographically and politically into Southeast Asia, until the Indochina Peninsula was colonized by the French in the mid-19th century.', u'Following a Japanese occupation in the 1940s, the Vietnamese fought French rule in the First Indochina War, eventually expelling the French in 1954.', u'Thereafter, Vietnam was divided politically into two rival states, North and South Vietnam.', u'Conflict between the two sides intensified in what is known as the Vietnam War.', u'The war ended with a North Vietnamese victory in 1975.', u'Vietnam was then unified under a communist government but remained impoverished and politically isolated.', u"In 1986, the government initiated a series of economic and political reforms which began Vietnam's path towards integration into the world economy.", u'By 2000, it had established diplomatic relations with all nations.', u"Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world, and, in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies.", u'Its successful economic reforms resulted in its joining the World Trade Organization in 2007.', u'It is also a historical member of the Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie.', u"Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.", u'== Etymology ==\n\nThe name Vi\u1ec7t Nam (Vietnamese pronunciation: [vi\u0259\u0300t na\u02d0m]) is a variation of Nam Vi\u1ec7t (Chinese: \u5357\u8d8a; pinyin: N\xe1nyu\xe8; literally Southern Vi\u1ec7t), a name that can be traced back to the Tri\u1ec7u Dynasty of the 2nd century BC.', u'The word Vi\u1ec7t originated as a shortened form of B\xe1ch Vi\u1ec7t (Chinese: \u767e\u8d8a; pinyin: B\u01ceiyu\xe8), a word applied to a group of peoples then living in southern China and Vietnam.', u'The form "Vietnam" (\u8d8a\u5357) is first recorded in the 16th-century oracular poem S\u1ea5m Tr\u1ea1ng Tr\xecnh.', u'The name has also been found on 12 steles carved in the 16th and 17th centuries, including one at Bao Lam Pagoda in Haiphong that dates to 1558.', u"In 1802, Nguy\u1ec5n Ph\xfac \xc1nh established the Nguy\u1ec5n dynasty, and in the second year, he asked the Qing Emperor Jiaqing to confer him the title 'King of Nam Viet/Nanyue'(\u5357\u8d8a in Chinese), but the Grand Secretariat of Qing dynasty pointed out that the name Nam Viet/Nanyue includes regions of Guangxi and Guangdong in China, and 'Nguy\u1ec5n Ph\xfac \xc1nh only has Annam, which is simply the area of our old Jiaozhi (\u4ea4\u8dbe), how can they be called Nam Viet/Nanyue?'", u"Then, as recorded, '(Qing dynasty) rewarded Yuenan/Vietnam(\u8d8a\u5357) as their nation's name, ..., to also show that they are below the region of Baiyue/Bach Viet'.", u'Between 1804 and 1813, the name was used officially by Emperor Gia Long.', u"It was revived in the early 20th century by Phan B\u1ed9i Ch\xe2u's History of the Loss of Vietnam, and later by the Vietnamese Nationalist Party.", u'The country was usually called Annam until 1945, when both the imperial government in Hu\u1ebf and the Viet Minh government in Hanoi adopted Vi\u1ec7t Nam.', u'== History ==\n\n\n=== Prehistory and ancient history ===\n\nArchaeological excavations have revealed the existence of humans in what is now Vietnam as early as the Paleolithic age.', u'Homo erectus fossils dating to around 500,000 BC have been found in caves in L\u1ea1ng S\u01a1n and Ngh\u1ec7 An provinces in northern Vietnam.', u'The oldest Homo sapiens fossils from mainland Southeast Asia are of Middle Pleistocene provenance, and include isolated tooth fragments from Tham Om and Hang Hum.', u'Teeth attributed to Homo sapiens from the Late Pleistocene have also been found at Dong Can, and from the Early Holocene at Mai Da Dieu, Lang Gao and Lang Cuom.', u'By about 1000 BC, the development of wet-rice cultivation and bronze casting in the Ma River and Red River floodplains led to the flourishing of the \u0110\xf4ng S\u01a1n culture, notable for its elaborate bronze drums.', u"At this time, the early Vietnamese kingdoms of V\u0103n Lang and \xc2u L\u1ea1c appeared, and the culture's influence spread to other parts of Southeast Asia, including Maritime Southeast Asia, throughout the first millennium BC.", u'=== Dynastic Vietnam ===\nThe H\u1ed3ng B\xe0ng dynasty of the H\xf9ng kings is considered the first Vietnamese state, known in Vietnamese as V\u0103n Lang.', u'In 257 BC, the last H\xf9ng king was defeated by Th\u1ee5c Ph\xe1n, who consolidated the L\u1ea1c Vi\u1ec7t and \xc2u Vi\u1ec7t tribes to form the \xc2u L\u1ea1c, proclaiming himself An D\u01b0\u01a1ng V\u01b0\u01a1ng.', u'In 207 BC, a Chinese general named Zhao Tuo defeated An D\u01b0\u01a1ng V\u01b0\u01a1ng and consolidated \xc2u L\u1ea1c into Nanyue.', u'However, Nanyue was itself incorporated into the empire of the Chinese Han dynasty in 111 BC after the Han\u2013Nanyue War.', u'For the next thousand years, what is now northern Vietnam remained mostly under Chinese rule.', u'Early independence movements, such as those of the Tr\u01b0ng Sisters and Lady Tri\u1ec7u, were only temporarily successful, though the region gained a longer period of independence as V\u1ea1n Xu\xe2n under the Anterior L\xfd dynasty between AD 544 and 602.', u'By the early 10th century, Vietnam had gained autonomy, but not sovereignty, under the Kh\xfac family.', u'In AD 938, the Vietnamese lord Ng\xf4 Quy\u1ec1n defeated the forces of the Chinese Southern Han state at B\u1ea1ch \u0110\u1eb1ng River and achieved full independence for Vietnam after a millennium of Chinese domination.', u'Renamed as \u0110\u1ea1i Vi\u1ec7t (Great Viet), the nation enjoyed a golden era under the L\xfd and Tr\u1ea7n dynasties.', u'During the rule of the Tr\u1ea7n Dynasty, \u0110\u1ea1i Vi\u1ec7t repelled three Mongol invasions.', u'Meanwhile, Buddhism flourished and became the state religion.', u'Following the 1406\u20137 Ming\u2013H\u1ed3 War which overthrew the H\u1ed3 dynasty, Vietnamese independence was briefly interrupted by the Chinese Ming dynasty, but was restored by L\xea L\u1ee3i, the founder of the L\xea dynasty.', u'The Vietnamese dynasties reached their zenith in the L\xea dynasty of the 15th century, especially during the reign of Emperor L\xea Th\xe1nh T\xf4ng (1460\u20131497).', u'Between the 11th and 18th centuries, Vietnam expanded southward in a process known as nam ti\u1ebfn ("southward expansion"), eventually conquering the kingdom of Champa and part of the Khmer Empire.', u'From the 16th century onwards, civil strife and frequent political infighting engulfed much of Vietnam.', u"First, the Chinese-supported M\u1ea1c dynasty challenged the L\xea dynasty's power.", u'After the M\u1ea1c dynasty was defeated, the L\xea dynasty was nominally reinstalled, but actual power was divided between the northern Tr\u1ecbnh lords and the southern Nguy\u1ec5n lords, who engaged in a civil war for more than four decades before a truce was called in the 1670s.', u'During this time, the Nguy\u1ec5n expanded southern Vietnam into the Mekong Delta, annexing the Central Highlands and the Khmer lands in the Mekong Delta.', u'The division of the country ended a century later when the T\xe2y S\u01a1n brothers established a new dynasty.', u'However, their rule did not last long, and they were defeated by the remnants of the Nguy\u1ec5n lords, led by Nguy\u1ec5n \xc1nh and aided by the French.', u'Nguy\u1ec5n \xc1nh unified Vietnam, and established the Nguy\u1ec5n dynasty, ruling under the name Gia Long.', u"=== 1862\u20131945: French Indochina ===\n\nVietnam's independence was gradually eroded by France \u2013 aided by large Catholic militias \u2013 in a series of military conquests between 1859 and 1885.", u'In 1862, the southern third of the country became the French colony of Cochinchina.', u'By 1884, the entire country had come under French rule, with the Central and Northern parts of Vietnam separated in the two protectorates of Annam and Tonkin.', u'The three Vietnameses entities were formally integrated into the union of French Indochina in 1887.', u'The French administration imposed significant political and cultural changes on Vietnamese society.', u'A Western-style system of modern education was developed, and Roman Catholicism was propagated widely.', u'Most French settlers in Indochina were concentrated in Cochinchina, particularly in the region of Saigon.', u'The royalist C\u1ea7n V\u01b0\u01a1ng movement rebelled against French rule and was defeated in the 1890s after a decade of resistance.', u"Guerrillas of the C\u1ea7n V\u01b0\u01a1ng movement murdered around a third of Vietnam's Christian population during this period.", u'Developing a plantation economy to promote the export of tobacco, indigo, tea and coffee, the French largely ignored increasing calls for Vietnamese self-government and civil rights.', u'A nationalist political movement soon emerged, with leaders such as Phan B\u1ed9i Ch\xe2u, Phan Chu Trinh, Phan \u0110\xecnh Ph\xf9ng, Emperor H\xe0m Nghi and Ho Chi Minh fighting or calling for independence.', u'However, the 1930 Y\xean B\xe1i mutiny of the Vi\u1ec7t Nam Qu\u1ed1c D\xe2n \u0110\u1ea3ng was suppressed easily.', u'The French maintained full control of their colonies until World War II, when the war in the Pacific led to the Japanese invasion of French Indochina in 1940.', u'Afterwards, the Japanese Empire was allowed to station its troops in Vietnam while permitting the pro-Vichy French colonial administration to continue.', u"Japan exploited Vietnam's natural resources to support its military campaigns, culminating in a full-scale takeover of the country in March 1945 and the Vietnamese Famine of 1945, which caused up to two million deaths.", u'=== 1946\u201354: First Indochina War ===\n\nIn 1941, the Viet Minh \u2013 a communist and nationalist liberation movement \u2013 emerged under the Marxist\u2013Leninist revolutionary Ho Chi Minh, who sought independence for Vietnam from France and the end of the Japanese occupation.', u'Following the military defeat of Japan and the fall of its puppet Empire of Vietnam in August 1945, the Viet Minh occupied Hanoi and proclaimed a provisional government, which asserted national independence on 2 September.', u'In the same year, the Provisional Government of the French Republic sent the French Far East Expeditionary Corps to restore colonial rule, and the Viet Minh began a guerrilla campaign against the French in late 1946.', u'The resulting First Indochina War lasted until July 1954.', u'The defeat of French and Vietnamese loyalists in the 1954 Battle of Dien Bien Phu allowed Ho Chi Minh to negotiate a ceasefire from a favorable position at the subsequent Geneva Conference.', u'The colonial administration was ended and French Indochina was dissolved under the Geneva Accords of 1954, which separated the loyalist forces from the communists at the 17th parallel north with the Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone.', u"Two states formed after the partition \u2013 Ho Chi Minh's Democratic Republic of Vietnam in the north and Emperor B\u1ea3o \u0110\u1ea1i's State of Vietnam in the south.", u'A 300-day period of free movement was permitted, during which almost a million northerners, mainly Catholics, moved south, fearing persecution by the communists.', u'The partition of Vietnam was not intended to be permanent by the Geneva Accords, which stipulated that Vietnam would be reunited after elections in 1956.', u"However, in 1955, the State of Vietnam's Prime Minister, Ng\xf4 \u0110\xecnh Di\u1ec7m, toppled B\u1ea3o \u0110\u1ea1i in a fraudulent referendum organised by his brother Ng\xf4 \u0110\xecnh Nhu, and proclaimed himself president of the Republic of Vietnam.", u"=== 1954\u20131975: Vietnam War ===\n\nThe pro-Hanoi Viet Cong began a guerrilla campaign in the late 1950s to overthrow Di\u1ec7m's government.", u'Between 1953 and 1956, the North Vietnamese government instituted various agrarian reforms, including "rent reduction" and "land reform," which resulted in significant political oppression.', u'During the land reform, testimony from North Vietnamese witnesses suggested a ratio of one execution for every 160 village residents, which extrapolated nationwide would indicate nearly 100,000 executions.', u'Because the campaign was concentrated mainly in the Red River Delta area, a lower estimate of 50,000 executions became widely accepted by scholars at the time.', u'However, declassified documents from the Vietnamese and Hungarian archives indicate that the number of executions was much lower than reported at the time, although likely greater than 13,500.', u'In 1960 and 1962, the Soviet Union and North Vietnam signed treaties providing for further Soviet military support.', u'In the South, Di\u1ec7m countered North Vietnamese subversion (including the assassination of over 450 South Vietnamese officials in 1956) by detaining tens of thousands of suspected communists in "political reeducation centers."', u'This was a ruthless program that incarcerated many non-communists, although it was also successful at curtailing communist activity in the country, if only for a time.', u'The North Vietnamese government claimed that 2,148 individuals were killed in the process by November 1957.', u'In 1960 and 1962, the Soviet Union and North Vietnam signed treaties providing for further Soviet military support.', u"In 1963, Buddhist discontent with Di\u1ec7m's regime erupted into mass demonstrations, leading to a violent government crackdown.", u"This led to the collapse of Di\u1ec7m's relationship with the United States, and ultimately to the 1963 coup in which Di\u1ec7m and Nhu were assassinated.", u'The Di\u1ec7m era was followed by more than a dozen successive military governments, before the pairing of Air Marshal Nguy\u1ec5n Cao K\u1ef3 and General Nguy\u1ec5n V\u0103n Thi\u1ec7u took control in mid-1965.', u'Thieu gradually outmaneuvered Ky and cemented his grip on power in fraudulent elections in 1967 and 1971.', u'Under this political instability, the communists began to gain ground.', u"To support South Vietnam's struggle against the communist insurgency, the United States began increasing its contribution of military advisers, using the 1964 Tonkin Gulf incident as a pretext for such intervention.", u'US forces became involved in ground combat operations in 1965, and at their peak they numbered more than 500,000.', u'The US also engaged in a sustained aerial bombing campaign.', u'Meanwhile, China and the Soviet Union provided North Vietnam with significant material aid and 15,000 combat advisers.', u'Communist forces supplying the Viet Cong carried supplies along the Ho Chi Minh trail, which passed through Laos.', u'The communists attacked South Vietnamese targets during the 1968 Tet Offensive.', u'Although the campaign failed militarily, it shocked the American establishment, and turned US public opinion against the war.', u'During the offensive, communist troops massacred over 3,000 civilians at Hue.', u'Facing an increasing casualty count, rising domestic opposition to the war, and growing international condemnation, the US began withdrawing from ground combat roles in the early 1970s.', u'This process also entailed an unsuccessful effort to strengthen and stabilize South Vietnam.', u'Following the Paris Peace Accords of 27 January 1973, all American combat troops were withdrawn by 29 March 1973.', u'In December 1974, North Vietnam captured the province of Ph\u01b0\u1edbc Long and started a full-scale offensive, culminating in the Fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975.', u'South Vietnam was briefly ruled by a provisional government while under military occupation by North Vietnam.', u'On 2 July 1976, North and South Vietnam were merged to form the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.', u'The war left Vietnam devastated, with the total death toll standing at between 800,000 and 3.1 million.', u"=== 1976\u2013present: reunification and reforms ===\n\nIn the aftermath of the war, under L\xea Du\u1ea9n's administration, there were no mass executions of South Vietnamese who had collaborated with the U.S. or the Saigon government, confounding Western fears.", u'However, up to 300,000 South Vietnamese were sent to reeducation camps, where many endured torture, starvation, and disease while being forced to perform hard labor.', u'The government embarked on a mass campaign of collectivization of farms and factories.', u'This caused economic chaos and resulted in triple-digit inflation, while national reconstruction efforts progressed slowly.', u'In 1978, the Vietnamese military invaded Cambodia to remove from power the Khmer Rouge, who had been attacking Vietnamese border villages.', u'Vietnam was victorious, installing a government in Cambodia which ruled until 1989.', u'This action worsened relations with the Chinese, who launched a brief incursion into northern Vietnam in 1979.', u'This conflict caused Vietnam to rely even more heavily on Soviet economic and military aid.', u'At the Sixth National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam in December 1986, reformist politicians replaced the "old guard" government with new leadership.', u"The reformers were led by 71-year-old Nguy\u1ec5n V\u0103n Linh, who became the party's new general secretary.", u'Linh and the reformers implemented a series of free-market reforms \u2013 known as \u0110\u1ed5i M\u1edbi ("Renovation") \u2013 which carefully managed the transition from a planned economy to a "socialist-oriented market economy".', u'Though the authority of the state remained unchallenged under \u0110\u1ed5i M\u1edbi, the government encouraged private ownership of farms and factories, economic deregulation and foreign investment, while maintaining control over strategic industries.', u'The Vietnamese economy subsequently achieved strong growth in agricultural and industrial production, construction, exports and foreign investment.', u'However, these reforms have also caused a rise in income inequality and gender disparities.', u"== Government and politics ==\n\nThe Socialist Republic of Vietnam, along with China, Cuba, and Laos, is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.", u'Its current state constitution, 2013 Constitution, asserts the central role of the Communist Party of Vietnam in all organs of government, politics and society.', u"The General Secretary of the Communist Party performs numerous key administrative and executive functions, controlling the party's national organization and state appointments, as well as setting policy.", u'Only political organizations affiliated with or endorsed by the Communist Party are permitted to contest elections in Vietnam.', u'These include the Vietnamese Fatherland Front and worker and trade unionist parties.', u'Although the state remains officially committed to socialism as its defining creed, its economic policies have grown increasingly capitalist, with The Economist characterizing its leadership as "ardently capitalist communists".', u'=== Legislature ===\nThe National Assembly of Vietnam is the unicameral legislature of the state, composed of 498 members.', u'Headed by a Chairman, it is superior to both the executive and judicial branches, with all government ministers being appointed from members of the National Assembly.', u'=== Executive ===\n\nThe President of Vietnam is the titular head of state and the nominal commander-in-chief of the military, serving as the Chairman of the Council of Supreme Defense and Security.', u'The Prime Minister of Vietnam is the head of government, presiding over a council of ministers composed of three deputy prime ministers and the heads of 26 ministries and commissions.', u"=== Judiciary ===\nThe Supreme People's Court of Vietnam, headed by a Chief Justice, is the country's highest court of appeal, though it is also answerable to the National Assembly.", u"Beneath the Supreme People's Court stand the provincial municipal courts and numerous local courts.", u'Military courts possess special jurisdiction in matters of national security.', u'Vietnam maintains the death penalty for numerous offences; as of February 2014, there are around 700 inmates on death row in Vietnam.', u"=== Military ===\n\nThe Vietnam People's Armed Forces consists of the Vietnam People's Army, the Vietnam People's Public Security and the Vietnam Civil Defense Force.", u"The Vietnam People's Army (VPA) is the official name for the active military services of Vietnam, and is subdivided into the Vietnam People's Ground Forces, the Vietnam People's Navy, the Vietnam People's Air Force, the Vietnam Border Defense Force and the Vietnam Coast Guard.", u'The VPA has an active manpower of around 450,000, but its total strength, including paramilitary forces, may be as high as 5,000,000.', u"In 2011, Vietnam's military expenditure totalled approximately US$2.48 billion, equivalent to around 2.5% of its 2010 GDP.", u"=== International relations ===\n\nThroughout its history, Vietnam's key foreign relationship has been with its largest neighbour and one-time imperial master, China.", u"Vietnam's sovereign principles and insistence on cultural independence have been laid down in numerous documents over the centuries, such as the 11th-century patriotic poem Nam qu\u1ed1c s\u01a1n h\xe0 and the 1428 proclamation of independence B\xecnh Ng\xf4 \u0111\u1ea1i c\xe1o.", u'Though China and Vietnam are now formally at peace, significant territorial tensions remain between the two countries.', u'Currently, the formal mission statement of Vietnamese foreign policy is to: "Implement consistently the foreign policy line of independence, self-reliance, peace, cooperation and development; the foreign policy of openness and diversification and multi-lateralization of international relations.', u'Proactively and actively engage in international economic integration while expanding international cooperation in other fields."', u'Vietnam furthermore declares itself to be "a friend and reliable partner of all countries in the international community, actively taking part in international and regional cooperation processes."', u'By December 2007, Vietnam had established diplomatic relations with 172 countries, including the United States, which normalized relations in 1995.', u'Vietnam holds membership of 63 international organizations, including the United Nations, ASEAN, NAM, Francophonie and WTO.', u'It also maintains relations with over 650 non-government organizations.', u'In May 2016, President Obama further normalized relations with Vietnam after he announced the lifting of an arms embargo on sales of lethal arms to Vietnam.', u'=== Administrative subdivisions ===\n\nVietnam is divided into 58 provinces (Vietnamese: t\u1ec9nh, from the Chinese \u7701, sh\u011bng).', u'There are also five municipalities (th\xe0nh ph\u1ed1 tr\u1ef1c thu\u1ed9c trung \u01b0\u01a1ng), which are administratively on the same level as provinces.', u'The provinces are subdivided into provincial municipalities (th\xe0nh ph\u1ed1 tr\u1ef1c thu\u1ed9c t\u1ec9nh), townships (th\u1ecb x\xe3) and counties (huy\u1ec7n), which are in turn subdivided into towns (th\u1ecb tr\u1ea5n) or communes (x\xe3).', u'The centrally controlled municipalities are subdivided into districts (qu\u1eadn) and counties, which are further subdivided into wards (ph\u01b0\u1eddng).', u'== Geography ==\n\nVietnam is located on the eastern Indochina Peninsula between the latitudes 8\xb0 and 24\xb0N, and the longitudes 102\xb0 and 110\xb0E.', u'It covers a total area of approximately 331,210 km2 (127,881 sq mi), making it almost the size of Germany.', u"The combined length of the country's land boundaries is 4,639 km (2,883 mi), and its coastline is 3,444 km (2,140 mi) long.", u'At its narrowest point in the central Qu\u1ea3ng B\xecnh Province, the country is as little as 50 kilometres (31 mi) across, though it widens to around 600 kilometres (370 mi) in the north.', u"Vietnam's land is mostly hilly and densely forested, with level land covering no more than 20%.", u"Mountains account for 40% of the country's land area, and tropical forests cover around 42%.", u'The northern part of the country consists mostly of highlands and the Red River Delta.', u'Phan Xi P\u0103ng, located in L\xe0o Cai Province, is the highest mountain in Vietnam, standing 3,143 m (10,312 ft) high.', u'Southern Vietnam is divided into coastal lowlands, the mountains of the Annamite Range, and extensive forests.', u"Comprising five relatively flat plateaus of basalt soil, the highlands account for 16% of the country's arable land and 22% of its total forested land.", u'The soil in much of southern Vietnam is relatively poor in nutrients.', u'The Red River Delta, a flat, roughly triangular region covering 15,000 km2 (5,792 sq mi), is smaller but more intensely developed and more densely populated than the Mekong River Delta.', u'Once an inlet of the Gulf of Tonkin, it has been filled in over the millennia by riverine alluvial deposits.', u'The delta, covering about 40,000 km2 (15,444 sq mi), is a low-level plain no more than 3 meters (9.8 ft) above sea level at any point.', u'It is criss-crossed by a maze of rivers and canals, which carry so much sediment that the delta advances 60 to 80 meters (196.9 to 262.5 ft) into the sea every year.', u'=== Panoramic view ===\n\n\n=== Climate ===\n\nBecause of differences in latitude and the marked variety in topographical relief, the climate tends to vary considerably from place to place.', u'During the winter or dry season, extending roughly from November to April, the monsoon winds usually blow from the northeast along the Chinese coast and across the Gulf of Tonkin, picking up considerable moisture.', u'Consequently, the winter season in most parts of the country is dry only by comparison with the rainy or summer season.', u'The average annual temperature is generally higher in the plains than in the mountains, and higher in the south than in the north.', u'Temperatures vary less in the southern plains around Ho Chi Minh City and the Mekong Delta, ranging between 21 and 28 \xb0C (69.8 and 82.4 \xb0F) over the course of the year.', u'Seasonal variations in the mountains and plateaus and in the north are much more dramatic, with temperatures varying from 5 \xb0C (41.0 \xb0F) in December and January to 37 \xb0C (98.6 \xb0F) in July and August.', u'=== Ecology and biodiversity ===\n\nVietnam has two World Natural Heritage Sites \u2013 H\u1ea1 Long Bay and Phong Nha-K\u1ebb B\xe0ng National Park \u2013 and six biosphere reserves, including C\u1ea7n Gi\u1edd Mangrove Forest, C\xe1t Ti\xean, C\xe1t B\xe0, Ki\xean Giang, the Red River Delta, and Western Ngh\u1ec7 An.', u'Vietnam lies in the Indomalaya ecozone.', u'According to the 2005 National Environmental Present Condition Report.', u'Vietnam is one of twenty-five countries considered to possess a uniquely high level of biodiversity.', u"It is ranked 16th worldwide in biological diversity, being home to approximately 16% of the world's species.", u"15,986 species of flora have been identified in the country, of which 10% are endemic, while Vietnam's fauna include 307 nematode species, 200 oligochaeta, 145 acarina, 113 springtails, 7,750 insects, 260 reptiles, 120 amphibians, 840 birds and 310 mammals, of which 100 birds and 78 mammals are endemic.", u'Vietnam is furthermore home to 1,438 species of freshwater microalgae, constituting 9.6% of all microalgae species, as well as 794 aquatic invertebrates and 2,458 species of sea fish.', u'In recent years, 13 genera, 222 species, and 30 taxa of flora have been newly described in Vietnam.', u"Six new mammal species, including the saola, giant muntjac and Tonkin snub-nosed monkey have also been discovered, along with one new bird species, the endangered Edwards's pheasant.", u'In the late 1980s, a small population of Javan rhinoceros was found in C\xe1t Ti\xean National Park.', u'However, the last individual of the species in Vietnam was reportedly shot in 2010.', u"In agricultural genetic diversity, Vietnam is one of the world's twelve original cultivar centers.", u'The Vietnam National Cultivar Gene Bank preserves 12,300 cultivars of 115 species.', u'The Vietnamese government spent US$49.07 million on the preservation of biodiversity in 2004 alone, and has established 126 conservation areas, including 28 national parks.', u"== Economy ==\n\nIn 2012, Vietnam's nominal GDP reached US$138 billion, with a nominal GDP per capita of $1,527.", u"According to a December 2005 forecast by Goldman Sachs, the Vietnamese economy will become the world's 21st-largest by 2025, with an estimated nominal GDP of $436 billion and a nominal GDP per capita of $4,357.", u"According to a 2008 forecast by PricewaterhouseCoopers, Vietnam may be the fastest-growing of the world's emerging economies by 2025, with a potential growth rate of almost 10% per annum in real dollar terms.", u"In 2012, HSBC predicted that Vietnam's total GDP would surpass those of Norway, Singapore and Portugal by 2050.", u'Vietnam has been for much of its history a predominantly agricultural civilization based on wet rice cultivation.', u'There is also an industry for bauxite mining in Vietnam, an important material for the production of aluminum.', u'The Vietnamese economy is shaped primarily by the Vietnamese Communist Party in Five Year Plans made through the plenary sessions of the Central Committee and national congresses.', u'The collectivization of farms, factories and economic capital is a part of this central planning, with millions of people working in government programs.', u"Vietnam's economy has been plagued with inefficiency and corruption in state programs, poor quality and underproduction, and restrictions on economic activity.", u'It also suffered from the post-war trade embargo instituted by the United States and most of Europe.', u"These problems were compounded by the erosion of the Soviet bloc, which included Vietnam's main trading partners, in the late 1980s.", u'In 1986, the Sixth National Congress of the Communist Party introduced socialist-oriented market economic reforms as part of the \u0110\u1ed5i M\u1edbi reform program.', u'Private ownership was encouraged in industries, commerce and agriculture.', u"Thanks largely to these reforms, Vietnam achieved around 8% annual GDP growth between 1990 and 1997, and the economy continued to grow at an annual rate of around 7% from 2000 to 2005, making Vietnam one of the world's fastest growing economies.", u"Growth remained strong even in the face of the late-2000s global recession, holding at 6.8% in 2010, but Vietnam's year-on-year inflation rate hit 11.8% in December 2010, according to a GSO estimate.", u'The Vietnamese dong was devalued three times in 2010 alone.', u'Manufacturing, information technology and high-tech industries now form a large and fast-growing part of the national economy.', u'Though Vietnam is a relative newcomer to the oil industry, it is currently the third-largest oil producer in Southeast Asia, with a total 2011 output of 318,000 barrels per day (50,600 m3/d).', u'In 2010, Vietnam was ranked as the 8th largest crude petroleum producers in the Asia and Pacific region.', u'Like its Chinese neighbours, Vietnam continues to make use of centrally planned economic five-year plans.', u'Deep poverty, defined as the percentage of the population living on less than $1 per day, has declined significantly in Vietnam, and the relative poverty rate is now less than that of China, India, and the Philippines.', u'This decline in the poverty rate can be attributed to equitable economic policies aimed at improving living standards and preventing the rise of inequality; these policies have included egalitarian land distribution during the initial stages of the \u0110\u1ed5i M\u1edbi program, investment in poorer remote areas, and subsidising of education and healthcare.', u'According to the IMF, the unemployment rate in Vietnam stood at 4.46% in 2012.', u'=== Trade ===\n\nSince the early 2000s, Vietnam has applied sequenced trade liberalisation, a two-track approach opening some sectors of the economy to international markets while protecting others.', u'In July 2006, Vietnam updated its intellectual property legislation to comply with TRIPS, and it became a member of the WTO on 11 January 2007.', u"Vietnam is now one of Asia's most open economies: two-way trade was valued at around 160% of GDP in 2006, more than twice the contemporary ratio for China and over four times the ratio for India.", u"Vietnam's chief trading partners include China, Japan, Australia, the ASEAN countries, the United States and Western Europe.", u"Vietnam's Customs office reported in July 2013 that the total value of international merchandise trade for the first half of 2013 was US$124 billion, which was 15.7% higher than the same period in 2012.", u'Mobile phones and their parts were both imported and exported in large numbers, while in the natural resources market, crude oil was a top-ranking export and high levels of iron and steel were imported during this period.', u"The U.S. was the country that purchased the highest amount of Vietnam's exports, while Chinese goods were the most popular Vietnamese import.", u'As a result of several land reform measures, Vietnam has become a major exporter of agricultural products.', u"It is now the world's largest producer of cashew nuts, with a one-third global share; the largest producer of black pepper, accounting for one-third of the world's market; and the second-largest rice exporter in the world, after Thailand.", u"Vietnam is the world's second largest exporter of coffee.", u'Vietnam has the highest proportion of land use for permanent crops \u2013 6.93% \u2013 of any nation in the Greater Mekong Subregion.', u'Other primary exports include tea, rubber, and fishery products.', u"However, agriculture's share of Vietnam's GDP has fallen in recent decades, declining from 42% in 1989 to 20% in 2006, as production in other sectors of the economy has risen.", u"In 2014 Vietnam negotiated a free trade agreement with the European Union, giving the country access to the EU's Generalized System of Preferences.", u'This provides preferential access to European markets for developing countries through reduced tariffs.', u'=== Science and technology ===\n\nVietnamese scholars developed many academic fields during the dynastic era, most notably social sciences and the humanities.', u'Vietnam has a millennium-deep legacy of analytical histories, such as the \u0110\u1ea1i Vi\u1ec7t s\u1eed k\xfd to\xe0n th\u01b0 of Ng\xf4 S\u0129 Li\xean.', u'Vietnamese monks led by the abdicated Emperor Tr\u1ea7n Nh\xe2n T\xf4ng developed the Tr\xfac L\xe2m Zen branch of philosophy in the 13th century.', u'Arithmetics and geometry have been widely taught in Vietnam since the 15th century, using the textbook \u0110\u1ea1i th\xe0nh to\xe1n ph\xe1p by L\u01b0\u01a1ng Th\u1ebf Vinh as a basis.', u'L\u01b0\u01a1ng Th\u1ebf Vinh introduced Vietnam to the notion of zero, while M\u1ea1c Hi\u1ec3n T\xedch used the term s\u1ed1 \u1ea9n (en: "unknown/secret/hidden number") to refer to negative numbers.', u"Vietnamese scholars furthermore produced numerous encyclopedias, such as L\xea Qu\xfd \u0110\xf4n's V\xe2n \u0111\xe0i lo\u1ea1i ng\u1eef.", u'In recent times, Vietnamese scientists have made many significant contributions in various fields of study, most notably in mathematics.', u'Ho\xe0ng T\u1ee5y pioneered the applied mathematics field of global optimization in the 20th century, while Ng\xf4 B\u1ea3o spending on science and technology equalled around 0.45% of its GDP.", u"=== Transport ===\n\nMuch of Vietnam's modern transport network was originally developed under French rule to facilitate the level, district roads managed at the district level, urban roads managed by cities and towns, and commune roads managed at the commune level.", u"Bicycles, motor scooters and motorcycles remain the most popular forms of road transport in Vietnam's urban areas, although the number of privately owned automobiles is also on the rise, especially in the larger cities.", u'Public buses operated by private companies are the main mode of long-distance travel for much of the population.', u'Road safety is a serious issue in Vietnam \u2013 on average, 30 people are killed in traffic accidents every cross-country rail service is the Reunification Express, which runs from Ho Chi Minh City to Hanoi, covering a distance of nearly 2,000 kilometres.", u'From Hanoi, railway lines branch out to the northeast, north and west; the eastbound line runs from Hanoi to H\u1ea1 Long Bay, the northbound line from Hanoi to Th\xe1i Nguy\xean, and the northeast line from Hanoi to L\xe0o Cai.', u'In 2009, Vietnam and Japan signed a deal to build a high-speed railway using Japanese technology; numerous Vietnamese engineers were later sent to Japan to receive training in the operation and maintenance of high-speed trains.', u'The railway will be a 1,630-km-long express route, serving a total of 26 stations, including Hanoi and the Thu Thiem terminus in Ho Chi Minh City.', u"Using Japan's Shinkansen technology, the line will support trains travelling at a maximum speed of 360 kilometres (220 mi) per hour.", u'The high-speed lines linking Hanoi to Vinh, Nha Trang and Ho Chi Minh City will be laid ====\nAs a coastal country, Vietnam has many major sea ports, including Cam Ranh, Da Nang, Hai Phong, Ho Chi Minh City, Hong Gai, Qui Nh\u01a1n, V\u0169ng T\xe0u and Nha Trang.', u"Further inland, the country's extensive network of rivers play a key role in rural transportation, with over 17,700 kilometres (11,000 mi) of navigable waterways carrying ferries, barges and water taxis.", u"In addition, the Mekong Delta and Red River Delta are vital to Vietnam's social and economic welfare \u2013 most of the country's population lives along or near these river deltas, and the major cities of Ho Chi which are the source of longstanding disagreements with China and other nearby nations.', u'=== Water supply and sanitation ===\n\nWater supply and sanitation in Vietnam is characterized by challenges and achievements.', u'Among the achievements is a substantial increase in access to water supply and sanitation between 1990 and 2010, nearly universal metering, and increased investment in wastewater treatment since 2007.', u'Among the challenges are continued widespread water pollution, poor service quality, low access to improved sanitation in rural areas, poor sustainability of rural water systems, insufficient cost recovery for urban sanitation, and the declining availability of foreign grant and soft loan funding as the Vietnamese economy grows and donors shift to loan financing.', remain low and some utilities have engaged in activities outside their mandate.', u'== Demographics ==\n\nAs of 2014, the population of Vietnam as standing at approximately 90.7 million people.', Vi\u1ec7t), a tonal Mon\u2013Khmer language which is spoken by the majority of the population.', u'In its early history, Vietnamese writing used Chinese characters.', u'In the 13th century, the have strengthened.", u"=== Religion ===\n\nAccording to an analysis by the Pew Research Center, in 2010 about 45.3% of the Vietnamese adhere to indigenous religions, 16.4% to Buddhism, 8.2% to 16th and 17th centuries, and was further propagated by French missionaries in the 19th and 20th centuries, and to a lesser extent, by American Protestant missionaries during the Vietnam War, largely colonists in conquering and ruling the country and in helping French attempts to install Catholic emperors, such as in the L\xea V\u0103n Kh\xf4i revolt of 1833.', u"Furthermore, the Catholic Church's strongly anti-communist stance has made it an enemy of the Vietnamese state.", u'The Vatican Church is officially banned, and only government-controlled Catholic organisations are permitted.', u'However, the Vatican has attempted to negotiate the opening of diplomatic relations with Vietnam in recent years.', u'Several other minority faiths exist in Vietnam.', u'A significant number of Baha'is are also in evidence.", u'The Vietnamese government rejects allegations that it does not allow religious freedom.', u"The state's official position on religion is that all citizens are free to their belief, and that all religions are equal before the law.", u'Nevertheless, only government-approved religious organisations are allowed; for example, the South Vietnam-founded Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam is banned in favour of a communist-approved body.', u'=== Education ===\n\nVietnam has an extensive state-controlled network of schools, colleges and universities, and a growing number of privately run and partially privatised institutions.', u'General education in Vietnam is divided into five categories: kindergarten, elementary schools, middle schools, high schools, and universities.', u'A large number of public schools have been constructed across the country to raise the national literacy rate, which stood at 90.3% in 2008.', u"A large number of Vietnam's most acclaimed universities are based in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.", u"Facing serious crises, Vietnam's education system is under a holistic program of reform launched by the government.", u'Education is not free; therefore, some poor families may have trouble paying tuition for their children without some form of public or private assistance.', u'Regardless, school enrollment is among the highest in the world, and the number of colleges and universities increased dramatically in the 2000s, from 178 in 2000 to 299 in 2005.', u"=== Health ===\n\nIn 2009, Vietnam's national life expectancy stood at 76 years for women and 72 for men, and the infant mortality rate was 12 per 1,000 live births.", u'By 2009, 85% of the population had access to improved water sources.', u'However, malnutrition is still common in the rural provinces.', u"In 2001, government spending on health care corresponded to just 0.9% of Vietnam's gross domestic product (GDP), with state subsidies covering only about 20% of health care expenses.", u'In 1954, North Vietnam established a public health system that reached down to the hamlet level.', u'After the national reunification in 1975, a nationwide health service was established.', u'In the late 1980s, the quality of healthcare declined to some degree as a result of budgetary constraints, a shift of responsibility to the provinces, and the introduction of charges.', u'Inadequate funding has also contributed to a shortage of nurses, midwives, and hospital beds; in 2000, Vietnam had only 250,000 hospital beds, or 14.8 beds per 10,000 people, according to the World Bank.', u'Since the early 2000s, Vietnam has made significant progress in combating malaria, with the malaria mortality rate falling to about 5% of its 1990s equivalent by 2005, after the country introduced improved antimalarial drugs and treatment.', u'However, tuberculosis cases are on the rise, with 57 deaths per day reported in May 2004.', u'With an intensified vaccination program, better hygiene, and foreign assistance, Vietnam hopes to reduce sharply the number of TB cases and annual new TB infections.', u'As of September 2005, Vietnam had diagnosed 101,291 HIV cases, of which 16,528 progressed to AIDS, and 9,554 died.', u'However, the actual number of HIV-positive individuals is estimated to be much higher.', u'On average, 40\u201350 new infections are reported every day in Vietnam.', u'As of 2007, 0.5% of the population is estimated to be infected with HIV, and this figure has remained stable since 2005.', u'In June 2004, the United States announced that Vietnam would be one of 15 nations to receive funding as part of a US$15 billion global AIDS relief plan.', u"== Culture ==\n\nVietnam's culture has developed over the centuries from indigenous ancient \u0110\xf4ng S\u01a1n culture with wet rice agriculture as its economic base.", u'Some elements of the national culture have Chinese origins, drawing on elements of Confucianism and Taoism in its traditional political system and philosophy.', u'Vietnamese society is structured around l\xe0ng (ancestral villages); all Vietnamese mark a common ancestral anniversary on the tenth day of the third lunar month.', u'The influences of immigrant peoples \u2013 such as the Cantonese, Hakka, Hokkien and Hainan cultures \u2013 can also be seen, while the national religion of Buddhism is strongly entwined with popular culture.', u'In recent centuries, the influences of Western cultures, most notably France and the United States, have become evident in Vietnam.', u'The traditional focuses of Vietnamese culture are humanity (nh\xe2n ngh\u0129a) and harmony (h\xf2a); family and community values are highly regarded.', u"Vietnam reveres a number of key cultural symbols, such as the Vietnamese dragon, which is derived from crocodile and snake imagery; Vietnam's National Father, L\u1ea1c Long Qu\xe2n, is depicted as a holy dragon.", u"The l\u1ea1c \u2013 a holy bird representing Vietnam's National Mother, \xc2u C\u01a1 \u2013 is another prominent symbol, while turtle and horse images are also revered.", u'In the modern era, the cultural life of Vietnam has been deeply influenced by government-controlled media and cultural programs.', u'For many decades, foreign cultural influences \u2013 especially those of Western origin \u2013 were shunned.', u'However, since the 1990s, Vietnam has seen a greater exposure to Southeast Asian, European and American culture and media.', u"=== Media ===\n\nVietnam's media sector is regulated by the government in accordance with the 2004 Law on Publication.", u"It is generally perceived that Vietnam's media sector is controlled by the government to follow the official Communist Party line, though some newspapers are relatively outspoken.", u'The Voice of Vietnam is the official state-run national radio broadcasting service, broadcasting internationally via shortwave using rented transmitters in other countries, and providing broadcasts from its website.', u'Vietnam Television is the national television broadcasting company.', u'Since 1997, Vietnam has extensively regulated public Internet access, using both legal and technical means.', u'The resulting lockdown is widely referred to as the "Bamboo Firewall".', u'The collaborative project OpenNet Initiative classifies Vietnam\'s level of online political censorship to be "pervasive", while Reporters Without Borders considers Vietnam to be one of 15 global "internet enemies".', u'Though the government of Vietnam claims to safeguard the country against obscene or sexually explicit content through its blocking efforts, many politically and religiously sensitive websites are also banned.', u"=== Music ===\n\nTraditional Vietnamese music varies between the country's northern and southern regions.", u"Northern classical music is Vietnam's oldest musical form, and is traditionally more formal.", u'The origins of Vietnamese classical music can be traced to the Mongol invasions of the 13th century, when the Vietnamese captured a Chinese opera troupe.', u'Throughout its history, Vietnamese has been most heavily impacted by the Chinese musical tradition, as an integral part, along with Korea, Mongolia and Japan.', u'Nh\xe3 nh\u1ea1c is the most popular form of imperial court music.', u'Ch\xe8o is a form of generally satirical musical theatre.', u'X\u1ea9m or H\xe1t x\u1ea9m (X\u1ea9m singing) is a type of Vietnamese folk music.', u'Quan h\u1ecd (alternate singing) is popular in H\xe0 B\u1eafc (divided into B\u1eafc Ninh and B\u1eafc Giang Provinces) and across Vietnam.', u'H\xe1t ch\u1ea7u v\u0103n or h\xe1t v\u0103n is a spiritual form of music used to invoke spirits during ceremonies.', u'Nh\u1ea1c d\xe2n t\u1ed9c c\u1ea3i bi\xean is a modern form of Vietnamese folk music which arose in the 1950s.', u'Ca tr\xf9 (also h\xe1t \u1ea3 \u0111\xe0o) is a popular folk music.', u'"H\xf2" can not be thought of as the southern style of Quan h\u1ecd.', u'There are a range of traditional instruments, including the \u0110\xe0n b\u1ea7u (a monochord zither), the \u0110\xe0n g\xe1o (a two-stringed fiddle with coconut body), and the \u0110\xe0n nguy\u1ec7t (a two-stringed fretted moon lute).', u'=== Literature ===\n\nVietnamese literature has a centuries-deep history.', u'The country has a rich tradition of folk literature, based on the typical 6\u2013to-8-verse poetic form named ca dao, which usually focuses on village ancestors and heroes.', u'Written literature has been found dating back to the 10th-century Ng\xf4 dynasty, with notable ancient authors including Nguy\u1ec5n Tr\xe3i, Tr\u1ea7n H\u01b0ng \u0110\u1ea1o, Nguy\u1ec5n Du and Nguy\u1ec5n \u0110\xecnh Chi\u1ec3u.', u'Some literary genres play an important role in theatrical performance, such as h\xe1t n\xf3i in ca tr\xf9.', u'Some poetic unions have also been formed in Vietnam, such as the Tao \u0110\xe0n.', u'Vietnamese literature has in recent times been influenced by Western styles, with the first literary transformation movement \u2013 Th\u01a1 M\u1edbi \u2013 emerging in 1932.', u'=== Festivals ===\n\nVietnam has a plethora of festivals based on the lunar calendar, the most important being the T\u1ebft New Year celebration.', u'Traditional Vietnamese weddings remain widely popular, and are often celebrated by expatriate Vietnamese in Western countries.', u'=== Tourism ===\n\nVietnam has become a major tourist destination since the 1990s, assisted by significant state and private investment, particularly in coastal regions.', u'About 3.77 million international tourists visited Vietnam in 2009 alone.', u'Popular tourist destinations include the former imperial capital of Hu\xe9, the World Heritage Sites of Phong Nha-K\u1ebb B\xe0ng National Park, H\u1ed9i An and M\u1ef9 S\u01a1n, coastal regions such as Nha Trang, the caves of H\u1ea1 Long Bay and the Marble Mountains.', u'Numerous tourist projects are under construction, such as the B\xecnh D\u01b0\u01a1ng tourist complex, which possesses the largest artificial sea in Southeast Asia.', u"On 14 February 2011, Joe Jackson, the father of American pop star Michael Jackson, attended a ground breaking ceremony for what will be Southeast Asia's largest entertainment complex, a five-star hotel and amusement park called Happyland.", u'The US$2 billion project, which has been designed to accommodate 14 million tourists annually, is located in southern Long An Province, near Ho Chi Minh City.', u'It is expected that the complex will be completed in 2014.', u'=== Clothing ===\nThe \xe1o d\xe0i, a formal dress, is worn for special occasions such as weddings and religious festivals.', u'White \xe1o d\xe0i is the required uniform for girls in many high schools across Vietnam.', u'\xc1o d\xe0i was once worn by both genders, but today it is mostly the preserve of women, although men do wear it to some occasions, such as traditional weddings.', u'Other examples of traditional Vietnamese clothing include the \xe1o t\u1ee9 th\xe2n, a four-piece woman\'s dress; the \xe1o ng\u0169, a form of the th\xe2n in 5-piece form, mostly worn in the north of the country; the y\u1ebfm, a woman\'s undergarment; the \xe1o b\xe0 ba, rural working "pyjamas" for men and women; the \xe1o g\u1ea5m, a formal brocade tunic for government receptions; and the \xe1o the, a variant of the \xe1o g\u1ea5m worn by grooms at weddings.', u'Traditional headwear includes the standard conical n\xf3n l\xe1 and the "lampshade-like" n\xf3n quai thao.', u"=== Sport ===\n\nThe Vovinam and B\xecnh \u0110\u1ecbnh martial arts are widespread in Vietnam, while soccer is the country's most popular team sport.", u'Its national team won the ASEAN Football Championship in 2008.', u'Other Western sports, such as badminton, tennis, volleyball, ping-pong and chess, are also widely popular.', u'Vietnam has participated in the Summer Olympic Games since 1952, when it competed as the State of Vietnam.', u'After the partition of the country in 1954, only South Vietnam competed in the Games, sending athletes to the 1956 and 1972 Olympics.', u'Since the reunification of Vietnam in 1976, it has competed as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, attending every Summer Olympics from 1988 onwards.', u'The present Vietnam Olympic Committee was formed in 1976 and recognized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 1979.', u'As of 2014, Vietnam has never participated in the Winter Olympics.', u'In 2016, Vietnam participated in the Rio Olympics, where they won their first gold medal.', u'=== Cuisine ===\n\nVietnamese cuisine traditionally features a combination of five fundamental taste "elements" (Vietnamese: ng\u0169 v\u1ecb): spicy (metal), sour (wood), bitter (fire), salty (water) and sweet (earth).', u'Common ingredients include fish sauce, shrimp paste, soy sauce, rice, fresh herbs, fruits and vegetables.', u"Vietnamese recipes use lemongrass, ginger, mint, Vietnamese mint, long coriander, Saigon cinnamon, bird's eye chili, lime and basil leaves.", u'Traditional Vietnamese cooking is known for its fresh ingredients, minimal use of oil, and reliance on herbs and vegetables, and is considered one of the healthiest cuisines worldwide.', u'In northern Vietnam, local foods are often less spicy than southern dishes, as the colder northern climate limits the production and availability of spices.', u'Black pepper is used in place of chilis to produce spicy flavors.', u'The use of such meats as pork, beef, and chicken was relatively limited in the past, and as a result freshwater fish, crustaceans \u2013 particularly crabs \u2013 and mollusks became widely used.', u'Fish sauce, soy sauce, prawn sauce, and limes are among the main flavoring ingredients.', u'Many signature Vietnamese dishes, such as b\xfan ri\xeau and b\xe1nh cu\u1ed1n, originated in the north and were carried to central and southern Vietnam by {'sentences': [u"Luna 9, internal designation Ye-6 No.13, was an unmanned space mission of the Soviet Union's Luna programme.", u'On 3 February 1966 the Luna 9 spacecraft became the first spacecraft to achieve a soft landing on the Moon, or any planetary body other than Earth, and to transmit photographic data to Earth from the surface of another planetary body.', u'== Spacecraft ==\nThe lander had a mass of 99 kilograms (218 lb).', u'It used a landing bag to survive the impact speed of 22 kilometres per hour (6.1 m/s; 14 mph).', u'It was a hermetically sealed container with radio equipment, a program timing device, heat control systems, scientific apparatus, power sources, and a television system.', u'== Launch and translunar coast ==\nLuna 9 was launched by a Molniya-M rocket, serial number 103-32, flying from Site 31/6 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic.', u'Liftoff took place at 11:41:37 UTC on 31 January 1966.', u'The first three stages of the four-stage carrier rocket injected the payload and fourth stage into low Earth orbit, at an altitude of 168 by 219 kilometres (104 by 136 mi) and 51.8 degrees inclination.', u"The fourth stage, a Blok-L, then fired to raise the orbit's perigee to a new apogee approximately 500,000 kilometres (310,000 mi), before deploying Luna 9 into a highly elliptical geocentric orbit.", u'The spacecraft then spun itself up to 0.67 rpm using nitrogen jets.', u'On 1 February at 19:29 UT, a mid-course correction took place involving a 48-second burn and resulting in a delta-V of 71.2 metres per second (234 ft/s).', u'== Descent and landing ==\n\nAt an altitude of 8,300 kilometres (5,200 mi) from the Moon, the spacecraft was oriented for the firing of its retrorockets and its spin was stopped in preparation for landing.', u'At 25 kilometres (16 mi) above the lunar surface, the radar altimeter triggered the jettison of the side modules, the inflation of the air bags and the firing of the retro rockets.', u'At 250 metres (820 ft) from the surface, the main retrorocket was turned off and the four outrigger engines were used to slow the craft.', u'Approximately 5 metres (16 ft) above the lunar surface, a contact sensor touched the ground triggering the engines to be shut down and the landing capsule to be ejected.', u'The craft landed at 22 kilometres per hour (6.1 m/s; 14 mph)\nThe spacecraft bounced several times before coming to rest in Oceanus Procellarum west of Reiner and Marius craters at approximately 7.08 N, 64.37 W on 3 February 1966 at 18:45:30 UT.', u'Luna 9 was the twelfth attempt at a soft-landing by the Soviet Union; it was also the first successful deep space probe built by the Lavochkin design bureau, which ultimately would design and build almost all Soviet (later Russian) lunar and interplanetary spacecraft.', u"All operations prior to landing occurred without fault, and the 58-centimetre (23 in) spheroid ALS capsule landed on the Moon at 18:45:30 UT on 3 February 1966 west of the craters Reiner and Marius in the Ocean of Storms (at 7\xb08' north latitude and 64\xb022' west longitude).", u'Approximately five minutes after touchdown, Luna 9 began transmitting data to Earth, but it was seven hours (after the Sun had climbed to 7\xb0 elevation) before the probe began sending the first of nine images (including five panoramas) of the surface of the Moon.', u'== Surface operations ==\nApproximately 250 seconds after landing in the Oceanus Procellarum, four petals which covered the top half of the spacecraft opened outward for increased stability.', u'The television camera system began a photographic survey of the lunar environment.', u'Seven radio sessions of 8 hours and 5 minutes, were transmitted, as well as a series of three TV pictures.', u'After assembly the photographs gave a panoramic view of the immediate lunar surface, comprising views of nearby rocks and of the horizon, 1.4 kilometres (0.87 mi) away.', u'The pictures from Luna 9 were not released immediately by the Soviet authorities, but scientists at Jodrell Bank Observatory in England, which was monitoring the craft, noticed that the signal format used was identical to the internationally agreed Radiofax system used by newspapers for transmitting pictures.', u'The Daily Express rushed a suitable receiver to the Observatory and the pictures from Luna 9 were decoded and published worldwide.', u"The BBC speculated that the spacecraft's designers deliberately fitted the probe with equipment conforming to the standard, to enable reception of the pictures by Jodrell Bank.", u'The radiation detector, the only scientific instrument on board, measured a dosage of 30 millirads (0.3 milligrays) per day.', u'The mission also determined that a spacecraft would not sink into the lunar dust; that the ground could support a lander.', u'Last contact with the spacecraft was at 22:55 UT on 6 February 1966.', u'== Sources ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nZarya - Luna 9 chronology\nAnimation of mission\nJodrell Bank first image\nLuna 9 panoramas'], 'year': '1966-01-31', 'title': 'Luna 9 launched for moon'}
{'sentences': [u'Sherman is the northernmost and least populous town of Fairfield County, Connecticut, United States.', u'The population was 3,581 at the 2010 census.', u'The town was formed in 1802 Connecticut received approval from the General Assembly of the Colony of Connecticut to establish a new township.', u'According to one account, they negotiated with Chief Squantz of the Schaghticoke tribe.', u'Alternatively, it is told that they did not negotiate with Chief Squantz because he moved to the north end of Squantz Pond land area and refused to "sell" the township of New Fairfield.', {'sentences': [u'Maarten Schmidt (born December 28, 1929) is a Dutch astronomer who measured the distances of quasars.', u'Born in Groningen, The Netherlands, Schmidt studied with Jan Hendrik Oort.', u'He earned his Ph.D. degree from Leiden Observatory in 1956.', u'In 1959, he emigrated to the United States and went to work at the California Institute of Technology.', u'In the beginning, he worked on theories about the mass distribution and dynamics of galaxies.', u'Of particular note from this period was his formulation of what has become known as the Schmidt law, which relates the density of interstellar gas to the rate of star formation occurring in that gas.', u'He later began a study of the light spectra of radio sources.', u'In 1963, using the famous 200-inch reflector telescope at the Palomar Observatory, Schmidt identified the visible object corresponding to one of these radio sources, known as 3C 273 and also studied its spectrum.', u'While its star-like appearance suggested it was relatively nearby, the spectrum of 3C 273 proved to have what was at the time a high redshift of 0.158, showing that it lay far beyond the Milky Way, and thus possessed an extraordinarily high luminosity.', u'Schmidt termed 3C 273 a "quasi-stellar" object or quasar; thousands have since been identified.', u'== Honors ==\nAwards\nHelen B. Warner Prize (1964)\nFront cover of Time March 11, 1966 \nHenry Norris Russell Lectureship (1978)\nGold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society (1980)\nCorrespondent of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (1980)\nJames Craig Watson Medal (1991)\nBruce Medal (1992)\nKavli Prize for Astrophysics (2008)\nMember of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters.', u'Named after him\nAsteroid 10430 Martschmidt\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links =='], 'year': '1963-02-05', 'title': 'Maarten Schmidt discovers enormous red shifts in quasars'}
{'sentences': [u'An electric light is a device that produces visible light by the flow of electric current.', u'It is the most common form of artificial lighting and is essential to modern society, providing interior lighting for buildings and exterior light for evening and nighttime activities.', u'In technical usage, a replaceable component that produces light from electricity is called a lamp.', u'Compact lamps are commonly called light bulbs; for example, the incandescent light bulb.', u'Lamps usually have a base made of ceramic, metal, glass or plastic, which secures the lamp in the socket of a light fixture.', u'The electrical connection to the socket may be made with a screw-thread base, two metal pins, two metal caps or a bayonet cap.', u'The three main categories of electric lights are incandescent lamps, which produce light by a filament heated white-hot by electric current, gas-discharge lamps, which produce light by means of an electric arc through a gas, and LED lamps, which produce light by a flow of electrons across a band gap in a semiconductor.', u'Before electric lighting became common in the early 20th century, people used candles, gas lights, oil lamps, and fires.', u'Humphry Davy developed the first incandescent light in 1802, followed by the first practical electric arc light in 1806.', u"By the 1870s, Davy's arc lamp had been successfully commercialized, and was used to light many public spaces.", u'The development of a steadily glowing filament suitable for interior lighting took longer, but by the early twentieth century inventors had successfully developed options, replacing the arc light with incandescents.', u'The energy efficiency of electric lighting has increased radically since the first demonstration of arc lamps and the incandescent light bulb of the 19th century.', u'Modern electric light sources come in a profusion of types and sizes adapted to myriad applications.', u'Most modern electric lighting is powered by centrally generated electric power, but lighting may also be powered by mobile or standby electric generators or battery systems.', u'Battery-powered light is often reserved for when and where stationary lights fail, often in the form of flashlights, electric lanterns, and in vehicles.', u'== Types ==\n\nTypes of electric lighting include:\nIncandescent light bulb, a heated filament inside a glass envelope\nHalogen lamps are incandescent lamps that use a fused quartz envelope filled with halogen gas\n\nLED lamp, a solid-state lamp that uses light-emitting diodes (LEDs) as the source of light\nArc lamp\nXenon arc lamp\nMercury-xenon arc lamp\nUltra-high-performance lamp, an ultra-high-pressure mercury-vapor arc lamp for use in projectors\nMetal-halide lamp\n\nGas-discharge lamp, a light source that generates light by sending an electrical discharge through an ionized gas\nFluorescent lamp\nCompact fluorescent lamp, a fluorescent lamp designed to replace an incandescent lamp\n\nNeon lamp\nMercury-vapor lamp\nSodium-vapor lamp\nSulfur lamp\nElectrodeless lamp, a gas discharge lamp in which the power is transferred from outside the bulb to inside via electromagnetic fields\n\nDifferent types of lights have vastly differing efficiencies and color of light.', u'*Color temperature is defined as the temperature of a black body emitting a similar spectrum; these spectra are quite different from those of black bodies.', u'The most efficient source of electric light is the low-pressure sodium lamp.', u'It produces, for all practical purposes, a monochromatic orange/yellow light, which gives a similarly monochromatic perceprtion of any illuminated scene.', u'For this reason, it is generally reserved for outdoor public lighting usages.', u'Low-pressure sodium lights are favoured for public lighting by astronomers, since the light pollution that they generate can be easily filtered, contrary to broadband or continuous spectra.', u'=== Incandescent light bulb ===\n\nThe modern incandescent light bulb, with a coiled filament of tungsten, was commercialized in the 1920s developed from the carbon filament lamp introduced in about 1880.', u'As well as bulbs for normal illumination, there is a very wide range, including low voltage, low-power types often used as components in equipment, but now largely displaced by LEDs\nThere is currently interest in banning some types of filament lamp in some countries, such as Australia planning to ban standard incandescent light bulbs by 2010, because they are inefficient at converting electricity to light.', u'Sri Lanka has already banned importing filament bulbs because of high use of electricity and less light.', u'Less than 3% of the input energy is converted into usable light.', u'Nearly all of the input energy ends up as heat that, in warm climates, must then be removed from the building by ventilation or air conditioning, often resulting in more energy consumption.', u'In colder climates where heating and lighting is required during the cold and dark winter months, the heat byproduct has at least some value.', u'==== Halogen lamp ====\n\nHalogen lamps are usually much smaller than standard incandescents, because for successful operation a bulb temperature over 200 \xb0C is generally necessary.', u'For this reason, most have a bulb of fused silica (quartz), but sometimes aluminosilicate glass.', u'This is often sealed inside an additional layer of glass.', u'The outer glass is a safety precaution, reducing UV emission and because halogen bulbs can occasionally explode during operation.', u'One reason is if the quartz bulb has oily residue from fingerprints.', u'The risk of burns or fire is also greater with bare bulbs, leading to their prohibition in some places unless enclosed by the luminaire.', u'Those designed for 12 or 24 volt operation have compact filaments, useful for good optical control, also they have higher efficiencies (lumens per watt) and better lives than non-halogen types.', u'The light output remains almost constant throughout life.', u'=== Fluorescent lamp ===\n\nFluorescent lamps consist of a glass tube that contains mercury vapour or argon under low pressure.', u'Electricity flowing through the tube causes the gases to give off ultraviolet energy.', u'The inside of the tubes are coated with phosphors that give off visible light when struck by ultraviolet energy.', u'have much higher efficiency than Incandescent lamps.', u'For the same amount of light generated, they typically use around one-quarter to one-third the power of an incandescent.', u'The typical luminous efficacy of fluorescent lighting systems is 50\u2013100 lumens per watt, several times the efficacy of incandescent bulbs with comparable light output.', u'Fluorescent lamp fixtures are more costly than incandescent lamps because they require a ballast to regulate the current through the lamp, but the lower energy cost typically offsets the higher initial cost.', u'Compact fluorescent lamps are now available in the same popular sizes as incandescents and are used as an energy-saving alternative in homes.', u'Because they contain mercury, many fluorescent lamps are classified as hazardous waste.', u'The United States Environmental Protection Agency recommends that fluorescent lamps be segregated from general waste for recycling or safe disposal, and some jurisdictions require recycling of them.', u'=== LED lamp ===\n\nSolid state LEDs have been popular as indicator lights in consumer electronics and professional audio gear since the 1970s.', u'In the 2000s efficacy and output have risen to the point where LEDs are now being used in lighting applications such as car headlights and brakelights, in flashlights and bike lights, as well as in decorative applications such as holiday lighting.', u'Indicator LEDs are known for their extremely long life, up to 100,000 hours, but lighting LEDs are operated much less conservatively, and consequently have shorter lives.', u'LED technology is useful for lighting designers because of its low power consumption, low heat generation, instantaneous on/off control, and in the case of single color LEDs, continuity of color throughout the life of the diode and relatively low cost of manufacture.', u'LED lifetime depends strongly on the temperature of the diode.', u"Operating an LED lamp in conditions that increase the internal temperature can greatly shorten the lamp's life.", u'=== Carbon arc lamp ===\n\nCarbon arc lamps consist of two carbon rod electrodes in open air, supplied by a current-limiting ballast.', u'The electric arc is struck by touching the rods then separating them.', u'The ensuing arc heats the carbon tips to white heat.', u'These lamps have higher efficiency than filament lamps, but the carbon rods are short lived and require constant adjustment in use.', u'The lamps produce significant ultra-violet output, they require ventilation when used indoors, and due to their intensity they need protecting from direct sight.', u'Invented by Humphry Davy around 1805, the carbon arc was the first practical electric light.', u'They were used commercially beginning in the 1870s for large building and street lighting until they were superseded in the early 20th century by the incandescent light.', u'Carbon arc lamps operate at high powers and produce high intensity white light.', u'They also are a point source of light.', u'They remained in use in limited applications that required these properties, such as movie projectors, stage lighting, and searchlights, until after World War 2.', u'=== Discharge lamp ===\nA discharge lamp has a glass or silica envelope containing two metal electrodes separated by a gas.', u'Gases used include, neon, argon, xenon, sodium, metal halide, and mercury.', u"The core operating principle is much the same as the carbon arc lamp, but the term 'arc lamp' is normally used to refer to carbon arc lamps, with more modern types of gas discharge lamp normally called discharge lamps.", u'With some discharge lamps, very high voltage is used to strike the arc.', u'This requires an electrical circuit called an igniter, which is part of the ballast circuitry.', u'After the arc is struck, the internal resistance of the lamp drops to a low level, and the ballast limits the current to the operating current.', u'Without a ballast, excess current would flow, causing rapid destruction of the lamp.', u'Some lamp types contain a little neon, which permits striking at normal running voltage, with no external ignition circuitry.', u'Low pressure sodium lamps operate this way.', u'The simplest ballasts are just an inductor, and are chosen where cost is the deciding factor, such as street lighting.', u'More advanced electronic ballasts may be designed to maintain constant light output over the life of the lamp, may drive the lamp with a square wave to maintain completely flicker-free output, and shut down in the event of certain faults.', u'== Lamp life expectancy ==\nLife expectancy for many types of lamp is defined as the number of hours of operation at which 50% of them fail, that is the median life of the lamps.', u'Production tolerances as low as 1% can create a variance of 25% in lamp life, so in general some lamps will fail well before the rated life expectancy, and some will last much longer.', u'For LEDs, lamp life is defined as the operation time at which 50% of lamps have experienced a 70% decrease in light output.', u'Some types of lamp are also sensitive to switching cycles.', u'Rooms with frequent switching such as bathrooms can expect much shorter lamp life than what is printed on the box.', u'Compact fluorescent lamps are particularly sensitive to switching cycles.', u'== Public lighting ==\nThe total amount of artificial light (especially from street light) is sufficient for cities to be easily visible at night from the air, and from space.', u'This light is the source of light pollution that burdens astronomers and others.', u"Human-made lights highlight particularly developed or populated areas of the Earth's surface, including the seaboards of Europe, the eastern United States, India, Japan and South Korea.", u'== Uses other than illumination ==\n\nElectric lamps can be used as heat sources, for example in incubators, as heat lamps in fast food restaurants and toys such as the Easy-Bake Oven.', u'Tungsten filament lamps have long been used as fast-acting thermistors in electronic circuits.', u'Popular uses have included:\nStabilisation of sine wave oscillators\nProtection of tweeters in speaker enclosures (excess current that is too high for the tweeter illuminates the light rather than blowing the tweeter).', u'Automatic volume control in telephones\n\n\n== Lamp circuit symbols ==\nIn circuit diagrams lamps usually are shown as symbols.', u'There are two main types of symbols, these are:\n\n\n== See also ==\nLightbulb socket\nLight source\nLight tube\nList of light sources\n\n\n== References =='], 'year': '1879-02-10', 'title': '1st electric arc light used [in California Theater]'}
