placed in a bomb crater and doused with petrol.', u'The corpses were set on fire as the Red Army shelling continued.', u"Grand Admiral Karl D\xf6nitz and Joseph Goebbels assumed Hitler's roles as head of state and chancellor respectively.", u'Berlin surrendered on 2 May.', u"Records in the Soviet archives obtained after the fall of the Soviet Union state that the remains of Hitler, Braun, Joseph and Magda Goebbels, the six Goebbels children, General Hans Krebs, and Hitler's dogs were repeatedly buried and exhumed.", u'On 4 April 1970, a Soviet KGB team used detailed burial charts to exhume five wooden boxes at the SMERSH facility in Magdeburg.', u'The remains from the boxes were burned, crushed, and scattered into the Biederitz river, a tributary of the Elbe.', u"According to Kershaw, the corpses of Braun and Hitler were fully burned when the Red Army found them, and only a lower jaw with dental work could be identified as Hitler's remains.", u'=== The Holocaust ===\n\nIf the international Jewish financiers in and outside Europe should succeed in plunging the nations once more into a world war, then the result will not be the Bolshevisation of the earth, and thus the victory of Jewry, but the annihilation of the Jewish race in Europe!', u"The Holocaust and Germany's war in the East were based on Hitler's long-standing view that the Jews were the enemy of the German people and that Lebensraum was needed for Germany's expansion.", u'He focused on Eastern Europe for this expansion, aiming to defeat Poland and the Soviet Union and then removing or killing the Jews and Slavs.', u'The Generalplan Ost (General Plan East) called for deporting the population of occupied Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to West Siberia, for use as slave labour or to be murdered; the conquered territories were to be colonised by German or "Germanised" settlers.', u'The goal was to implement this plan after the conquest of the Soviet Union, but when this failed, Hitler moved the plans forward.', u'By January 1942, he had decided that the Jews, Slavs, and other deportees considered undesirable should be killed.', u'The genocide was ordered by Hitler and organised and executed by Heinrich Himmler and Reinhard Heydrich.', u'The records of the Wannsee Conference, held on 20 January 1942 and led by Heydrich, with fifteen senior Nazi officials participating, provide the clearest evidence of systematic planning for the Holocaust.', u'On 22 February, Hitler was recorded saying, "we shall regain our health only by eliminating the Jews".', u'Although no direct order from Hitler authorising the mass killings has surfaced, his public speeches, orders to his generals, and the diaries of Nazi officials demonstrate that he conceived and authorised the extermination of European Jewry.', u'He approved the Einsatzgruppen\u2014killing squads that followed the German army through Poland, the Baltic, and the Soviet Union\u2014and was well informed about their activities.', u'By summer 1942, Auschwitz concentration camp was expanded to accommodate large numbers of deportees for killing or enslavement.', u'Scores of other concentration camps and satellite camps were set up throughout Europe, with several camps devoted exclusively to extermination.', u'Between 1939 and 1945, the Schutzstaffel (SS), assisted by collaborationist governments and recruits from occupied countries, was responsible for the deaths of at least eleven million people, including 5.5 to 6 million Jews (representing two-thirds of the Jewish population of Europe), and between 200,000 and 1,500,000 Romani people.', u'Deaths took place in concentration and extermination camps, ghettos, and through mass executions.', u'Many victims of the Holocaust were gassed to death, whereas others died of starvation or disease or while working as slave labourers.', u'In addition to eliminating Jews, the Nazis planned to reduce the population of the conquered territories by 30 million people through starvation in an action called the Hunger Plan.', u'Food supplies would be diverted to the German army and German civilians.', u'Cities would be razed and the land allowed to return to forest or resettled by German colonists.', u'Together, the Hunger Plan and Generalplan Ost would have led to the starvation of 80 million people in the Soviet Union.', u'These partially fulfilled plans resulted in the democidal deaths of an estimated 19.3 million civilians and prisoners of war.', u"Hitler's policies resulted in the killing of nearly two million Poles, over three million Soviet prisoners of war, communists and other political opponents, homosexuals, the physically and mentally disabled, Jehovah's Witnesses, Adventists, and trade unionists.", u'Hitler did not speak publicly about the killings, and seems never to have visited the concentration camps.', u'The Nazis embraced the concept of racial hygiene.', u'On 15 September 1935, Hitler presented two laws\u2014known as the Nuremberg Laws\u2014to the Reichstag.', u'The laws banned sexual relations and marriages between Aryans and Jews and were later extended to include "Gypsies, Negroes or their bastard offspring".', u'The laws stripped all non-Aryans of their German citizenship and forbade the employment of non-Jewish women under the age of 45 in Jewish households.', u"Hitler's early eugenic policies targeted children with physical and developmental disabilities in a programme dubbed Action Brandt, and he later authorised a euthanasia programme for adults with serious mental and physical disabilities, now referred to as Action T4.", u'== Leadership style ==\nHitler ruled the NSDAP autocratically by asserting the F\xfchrerprinzip (leader principle).', u'The principle relied on absolute obedience of all subordinates to their superiors; thus he viewed the government structure as a pyramid, with himself\u2014the infallible leader\u2014at the apex.', u'Rank in the party was not determined by elections\u2014positions were filled through appointment by those of higher rank, who demanded unquestioning obedience to the will of the leader.', u'Hitler\'s leadership style was to give contradictory orders to his subordinates and to place them into positions where their duties and responsibilities overlapped with those of others, to have "the stronger one [do] the job".', u'In this way, Hitler fostered distrust, competition, and infighting among his subordinates to consolidate and maximise his own power.', u'His cabinet never met after 1938, and he discouraged his ministers from meeting independently.', u'Hitler typically did not give written orders; instead he communicated verbally, or had them conveyed through his close associate, Martin Bormann.', u'He entrusted Bormann with his paperwork, appointments, and personal finances; Bormann used his position to control the flow of information and access to Hitler.', u"Hitler dominated his country's war effort during World War II to a greater extent than any other national leader.", u"He assumed the role of supreme commander of the armed forces during 1938, and subsequently made all major decisions regarding Germany's military strategy.", u'His decision to mount a risky series of offensives against Norway, France, and the Low Countries in 1940 against the advice of the military proved successful, though the diplomatic and military strategies he employed in attempts to force the United Kingdom out of the war ended in failure.', u'Hitler deepened his involvement in the war effort by appointing himself commander-in-chief of the Army in December 1941; from this point forward he personally directed the war against the Soviet Union, while his military commanders facing the Western Allies retained a degree of autonomy.', u"Hitler's leadership became increasingly disconnected from reality as the war turned against Germany, with the military's defensive strategies often hindered by his slow decision making and frequent directives to hold untenable positions.", u'Nevertheless, he continued to believe that only his leadership could deliver victory.', u'In the final months of the war Hitler refused to consider peace negotiations, regarding the complete destruction of Germany as preferable to surrender.', u"The military did not challenge Hitler's dominance of the war effort, and senior officers generally supported and enacted his decisions.", u'== Legacy ==\n\nHitler\'s suicide was likened by contemporaries to a "spell" being broken.', u'Public support for Hitler had collapsed by the time of his death and few Germans mourned his passing; Kershaw argues that most civilians and military personnel were too busy adjusting to the collapse of the country or fleeing from the fighting to take any interest.', u'According to historian John Toland, National Socialism "burst like a bubble" without its leader.', u'Hitler\'s actions and Nazi ideology are almost universally regarded as gravely immoral; according to Kershaw, "Never in history has such ruination\u2014physical and moral\u2014been associated with the name of one man".', u"Hitler's political programme brought about a world war, leaving behind a devastated and impoverished Eastern and Central Europe.", u'Germany itself suffered wholesale destruction, characterised as Stunde Null (Zero Hour).', u"Hitler's policies inflicted human suffering on an unprecedented scale; according to R. J. Rummel, the Nazi regime was responsible for the democidal killing of an estimated 19.3 million civilians and prisoners of war.", u'In addition, 29 million soldiers and civilians died as a result of military action in the European Theatre of World War II.', u'The number of civilians killed during the Second World War was unprecedented in the history of warfare.', u'Historians, philosophers, and politicians often use the word "evil" to describe the Nazi regime.', u'Many European countries have criminalised both the promotion of Nazism and Holocaust denial.', u'Historian Friedrich Meinecke described Hitler as "one of the great examples of the singular and incalculable power of personality in historical life".', u'English historian Hugh Trevor-Roper saw him as "among the \'terrible simplifiers\' of history, the most systematic, the most historical, the most philosophical, and yet the coarsest, cruelest, least magnanimous conqueror the world has ever known".', u"For the historian John M. Roberts, Hitler's defeat marked the end of a phase of European history dominated by Germany.", u'In its place emerged the Cold War, a global confrontation between the Western Bloc, dominated by the United States and other NATO nations, and the Eastern Bloc, dominated by the Soviet Union.', u'Historian Sebastian Haffner avers that without Hitler and the displacement of the Jews, the modern nation state of Israel would not exist.', u'He contends that without Hitler, the de-colonisation of former European spheres of influence would have been postponed.', u'Further, Haffner claims that other than Alexander the Great, Hitler had a more significant impact than any other comparable historical figure, in that he too caused a wide range of worldwide changes in a relatively short time span.', u'== Views on religion ==\n\nHitler was born to a practising Catholic mother and an anticlerical father; after leaving home Hitler never again attended Mass or received the sacraments.', u'Speer states that Hitler made harsh pronouncements against the church to his political associates and though he never officially left it, he had no attachment to it.', u'He adds that Hitler felt that in the absence of the church the faithful would turn to mysticism, which he considered a step backwards.', u'According to Speer, Hitler believed that either Japanese religious beliefs or Islam would have been a more suitable religion for the Germans than Christianity, with its "meekness and flabbiness".', u'Historian John S. Conway states that Hitler was fundamentally opposed to the Christian churches.', u'According to Bullock, Hitler did not believe in God, was anticlerical, and held Christian ethics in contempt because they contravened his preferred view of "survival of the fittest".', u"He favoured aspects of Protestantism that suited his own views, and adopted some elements of the Catholic Church's hierarchical organisation, liturgy, and phraseology in his politics.", u'Hitler viewed the church as an important politically conservative influence on society, and he adopted a strategic relationship with it that "suited his immediate political purposes".', u'In public, Hitler often praised Christian heritage and German Christian culture, though professing a belief in an "Aryan Jesus", one who fought against the Jews.', u'Any pro-Christian public rhetoric was at variance with his private statements, which described Christianity as "absurdity" and nonsense founded on lies.', u'According to a U.S. Office of Strategic Services report, "The Nazi Master Plan", Hitler planned to destroy the influence of Christian churches within the Reich.', u'His eventual goal was the total elimination of Christianity.', u"This goal informed Hitler's movement early on, but he saw it as inexpedient to express this extreme position publicly.", u'According to Bullock, Hitler wanted to wait until after the war before executing this plan.', u"Speer wrote that Hitler had a negative view of Himmler's and Alfred Rosenberg's mystical notions and Himmler's attempt to mythologise the SS.", u'Hitler was more pragmatic, and his ambitions centred on more practical concerns.', u"== Health ==\n\nResearchers have variously suggested that Hitler suffered from irritable bowel syndrome, skin lesions, irregular heartbeat, coronary sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, syphilis, giant cell arteritis with temporal arteritis, and tinnitus.", u'In a report prepared for the Office of Strategic Services in 1943, Walter C. Langer of Harvard University described Hitler as a "neurotic psychopath".', u'In his 1977 book The Psychopathic God: Adolf Hitler, historian Robert G. L. Waite proposes that he suffered from borderline personality disorder.', u"Historians Henrik Eberle and Hans-Joachim Neumann consider that while he suffered from a number of illnesses including Parkinson's disease, Hitler did not experience pathological delusions and was always fully aware of, and therefore responsible for, the decisions he was making.", u"Theories about Hitler's medical condition are difficult to prove, and placing too much weight on them may have the effect of attributing many of the events and consequences of Nazi Germany to the possibly impaired physical health of one individual.", u'Kershaw feels that it is better to take a broader view of German history by examining what social forces led to the Nazi dictatorship and its policies rather than to pursue narrow explanations for the Holocaust and World War II based on only one person.', u'Hitler followed a vegetarian diet.', u'At social events he sometimes gave graphic accounts of the slaughter of animals in an effort to make his dinner guests shun meat.', u'Bormann had a greenhouse constructed near the Berghof (near Berchtesgaden) to ensure a steady supply of fresh fruit and vegetables for Hitler throughout the war.', u'Hitler publicly avoided alcohol.', u'He occasionally drank beer and wine in private, but gave up drinking because of weight gain in 1943.', u'He was a non-smoker for most of his adult life, but smoked heavily in his youth (25 to 40 cigarettes a day).', u'He eventually quit, calling the habit "a waste of money".', u'He encouraged his close associates to quit by offering a gold watch to anyone able to break the habit.', u'Hitler began using amphetamine occasionally after 1937 and became addicted to it in late 1942.', u"Speer linked this use of amphetamine to Hitler's increasingly erratic behavior and inflexible decision making (for example, rarely allowing military retreats).", u'Prescribed 90 medications during the war years, Hitler took many pills each day for chronic stomach problems and other ailments.', u'He regularly consumed amphetamine, barbiturates, opiates, and cocaine.', u'He suffered ruptured eardrums as a result of the 20 July plot bomb blast in 1944, and 200 wood splinters had to be removed from his legs.', u'Newsreel footage of Hitler shows tremors of his left hand and a shuffling walk, which began before the war and worsened towards the end of his life.', u"Ernst-G\xfcnther Schenck and several other doctors who met Hitler in the last weeks of his life also formed a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease.", u'== Family ==\n\nHitler created a public image as a celibate man without a domestic life, dedicated entirely to his political mission and the nation.', u'He met his lover, Eva Braun, in 1929, and married her in April 1945.', u"In September 1931, his half-niece, Geli Raubal, committed suicide with Hitler's gun in his Munich apartment.", u'It was rumoured among contemporaries that Geli was in a romantic relationship with him, and her death was a source of deep, lasting pain.', u'Paula Hitler, the younger sister of Hitler and the last living member of his immediate family, died in 1960.', u'== In propaganda films Der Sieg des Glaubens and Triumph des Willens\u2014made by Leni Riefenstahl, regarded as a pioneer of modern filmmaking.', u'=== List of propaganda and film appearances ===\nDer Sieg des Glaubens {'sentences': [u"The Pike's Peak Gold Rush (later known as the Colorado Gold Rush) was the boom in gold prospecting and mining in the Pike's Peak Country of western Kansas Territory and southwestern Nebraska Territory of the United States that began in July 1858 and lasted until roughly the creation of the Colorado Territory on February 28, 1861.", u'An estimated 100,000 gold seekers took part in one of the greatest gold rushes in North American history.', u'The participants in the gold rush were known as "Fifty-Niners" after 1859, the peak year of the rush and often used the motto Pike\'s Peak or Bust!', u"But in fact the location of the Pike's Peak Gold Rush was 85 miles (137 km) north of Pike's Peak.", u"It was only named Pike's Peak Gold Rush because of how well known and important Pike's Peak was.", u"== Overview ==\n\nThe Pike's Peak Gold Rush, which followed the California Gold Rush by approximately one decade, produced a dramatic but temporary influx of immigrants into the Pike's Peak Country of the Southern Rocky Mountains.", u'The rush was exemplified by the slogan "Pike\'s Peak or Bust!', u'", a reference to the prominent mountain at the eastern edge of the Rocky Mountains that guided many early prospectors to the region westward over the Great Plains.', u'The prospectors provided the first major European-American population in the region.', u'The rush created a few mining camps such as Denver City and Boulder City that would develop into cities.', u'Many smaller camps such as Auraria and Saint Charles City were absorbed by larger camps and towns.', u'Scores of other mining camps have faded into ghost towns, but quite a few camps such as Central City, Black Hawk, Georgetown, and Idaho Springs survive.', u'== Discovery ==\n\nFor many years people had suspected the mountains had numerous rich gold deposits.', u'In 1835, a French trapper by the name of Eustace Carriere had ended up losing his party and wandered through the mountains for many weeks.', u'During these weeks he found many gold specimens which he later took back to New Mexico for examination.', u'Upon examination, they turned out to be "pure gold".', u'But when he tried to lead an expedition back to the location of where he found the gold, they came up short because he could not quite remember the location.', u'In 1849 and 1850, several parties of gold seekers bound for the California Gold Rush panned small amounts of gold from various streams in the South Platte River valley at the foot of the Rocky Mountains.', u'The Rocky Mountain gold failed to impress or delay men with visions of unlimited wealth in California, and the discoveries were not reported for several years.', u'As the hysteria of the California Gold Rush faded, many discouraged gold seekers returned home.', u'Rumors of gold in the Rocky Mountains persisted and several small parties explored the region.', u'In the summer of 1857, a party of Spanish-speaking gold seekers from New Mexico worked a placer deposit along the South Platte River about 5 miles (8 kilometers) above Cherry Creek in what is today Denver.', u'William Greeneberry "Green" Russell was a Georgian who worked in the California gold fields in the 1850s.', u'Russell was married to a Cherokee woman, and through his connections to the tribe, he heard about an 1849 discovery of gold along the South Platte River.', u'Green Russell organized a party to prospect along the South Platte River, setting off with his two brothers and six companions in February 1858.', u'They rendezvoused with Cherokee tribe members along the Arkansas River in present-day Oklahoma and continued westward along the Santa Fe Trail.', u'Others joined the party along the way until their number reached 107.', u"Upon reaching Bent's Fort, they turned to the northwest, reaching the confluence of Cherry Creek and the South Platte on May 23.", u'The site of their initial explorations is in present-day Confluence Park in Denver.', u'They began prospecting in the river beds, exploring Cherry Creek and nearby Ralston Creek but without success.', u'In the first week of July 1858, Green Russell and Sam Bates found a small placer deposit near the mouth of Little Dry Creek that yielded about 20 troy ounces (622 grams) of gold, the first significant gold discovery in the Rocky Mountain region.', u'The site of the discovery is in the present-day Denver suburb of Englewood, just north of the junction of U.S. Highway 285 and U.S. Highway 85.', u'== The initial boom ==\n\nThe first decade of the boom was largely concentrated along the South Platte River at the base of the mountains, the canyon of Clear Creek in the mountains west of Golden City, at Breckenridge and in South Park at Como, Fairplay, and Alma.', u'By 1860, Denver City, Golden City, and Boulder City were substantial towns serving the mines.', u'Rapid population growth led to the creation of the Colorado Territory in 1861.', u"The Pike's Peak Gold Rush sent many into a frenzy, prompting them to pack up their belongings and head to Colorado.", u'They gathered their supplies, wagons, mules, mining equipment, anything they could think of to sustain them when they arrived at their destination.', u"As early as the spring of 1859, people raced to the Pike's Peak country.", u'Some even dared to go out in the winter of 1858 to try to get a head start, only to realize that they would have to wait until the snow melted to even begin their mining for gold.', u'=== Free gold ===\n\nHardrock mining boomed for a few years, but then declined in the mid-1860s as the miners exhausted the shallow parts of the veins that contained free gold, and found that their amalgamation mills could not recover gold from the deeper sulfide ores.', u'This problem was eventually solved and gold and silver mining in Colorado became a major industry.', u'Colorado produced 150,000 ounces of gold in 1861 and 225,000 troy ounces in 1862.', u'This led Congress to establish the Denver Mint.', u'Cumulative Colorado production by 1865 was 1.25 million ounces, of which sixty percent was placer gold.', u'== See also ==\nSilver mining in Colorado\nColorado Silver {'sentences': [u'A senate is a deliberative assembly, often the upper house or chamber of a bicameral legislature or parliament.', u'The name comes from the ancient Roman Senate (Latin: Senatus), so-called as an assembly of the senior (Latin: senex meaning "the elder" or "the old one") and therefore allegedly wiser and more experienced members of the society or ruling class.', u'Thus, the literal meaning of the word "senate" is: Assembly of Elders.', u'Many countries have an assembly named a senate, composed of senators who may be elected, appointed, have inherited the title, or gained membership by other methods, depending on the country.', u'Modern senates typically serve to provide a chamber of "sober second thought" to consider legislation passed by a lower house, whose members are usually elected.', u'== Overview ==\nThe modern word Senate is derived from the [Latin] word sen\u0101tus (senate), which comes from senex, \u201cold man\u201d.', u'The members or legislators of a senate are called senators.', u'The Latin word senator was adopted into English with no change in spelling.', u'Its meaning is derived from a very ancient form of social organization, in which advisory or decision-making powers are reserved for the eldest men.', u'For the same reason, the word senate is correctly used when referring to any powerful authority characteristically composed by the eldest members of a community, as a deliberative body of a faculty in an institution of higher learning is often called a senate.', u'This form adaptation was used to show the power of those in body and for the decision-making process to be thorough, which could take a long period of time.', u'The original senate was the Roman Senate, which lasted until 580 (various efforts to revive it were made in Medieval Rome).', u'In the Eastern Roman Empire, the Byzantine Senate continued until the Fourth Crusade, circa 1202\u20131204.', u'Modern democratic states with bicameral parliamentary systems are sometimes equipped with a senate, often distinguished from an ordinary parallel lower house, known variously as the \u201cHouse of Representatives\u201d, \u201cHouse of Commons\u201d, \u201cChamber of Deputies\u201d, \u201cNational Assembly\u201d, \u201cLegislative Assembly\u201d, or "House of Assembly", by electoral rules.', u'This may include minimum age required for voters and candidates, proportional or majoritarian or plurality system, and an electoral basis or collegium.', u'Typically, the senate is referred to as the upper house and has a smaller membership than the lower house.', u'In some federal states senates also exist at the subnational level.', u'In the United States all states with the exception of Nebraska (whose legislature is a unicameral body called the \u201cLegislature\u201d but whose members refer to themselves as \u201csenators\u201d) have a state senate.', u'There is also the US Senate at the federal level.', u"Similarly in Argentina, in addition to the Senate at federal level, eight of the country's provinces, Buenos Aires, Catamarca, Corrientes, Entre R\xedos, Mendoza, Salta, San Luis (since 1987) and Santa Fe, have bicameral legislatures with a Senate.", u'C\xf3rdoba and Tucum\xe1n changed to unicameral systems in 2001 and 2003 respectively.', u'In Australia and Canada, only the upper house of the federal parliament is known as the Senate.', u'All states other than Queensland have an upper house known as a Legislative council.', u"Several Canadian provinces also once had a Legislative Council, but these have all been abolished, the last being Quebec's Legislative council in 1968.", u'In Germany, the last Senate of a State parliament, the Senate of Bavaria, was abolished in 1999.', u'Senate membership can be determined either through elections or appointments.', u'For example, elections are held every three years for half the membership of the Australian Senate, the term of a senator being six years.', u'In contrast, members of the Canadian Senate are appointed by the Governor General upon the recommendation of the Prime Minister of Canada, holding the office until they resign, are removed, or retire at the mandatory age of 75.', u'== Alternative meanings ==\nThe terms Senate and Senator, however, do not necessarily refer to a second chamber of a legislature:\nThe Senate of Finland was, until 1919, the executive branch and the supreme court.', u'The Senate of Latvia (lv) fulfilled a similar judicial function during the interbellum (1918-1940).', u'In German politics:\nIn the Bundesl\xe4nder (Federated States) of Germany which form a City State (in German: Stadtstaat), i.e.', u'Berlin (Senate of Berlin), Bremen (Senate of Bremen) and Hamburg (Senate of Hamburg), the Senates (Senat in German) are the executive branch, with Senator (Senator) being the holders of ministerial portfolios.', u'In a number of cities which were former members of the Hanse (a medieval confederacy of port cities mainly at the shores of the Baltic Sea and the North Sea), such as Greifswald, L\xfcbeck, Rostock, Stralsund, or Wismar, the city government is also called a Senate.', u'However, in Bavaria, the Senate was a second legislative chamber until its abolition in 1999.', u'In German jurisdiction:\nThe term Senat (senate) in higher courts of appeal refers to the "bench" in its broader metonymy meaning, describing members of the judiciary collectively (usually five judges), often occupied with a particular subject-matter jurisdiction.', u'However, the judges are not called "senators".', u'The German term Strafsenat (literally "Penal Senate") in a German court translates to Bench of penal-law jurisdiction and Zivilsenat (literally "Civil Senate") to Bench of private-law jurisdiction.', u'The Federal Constitutional Court of Germany consists of two senates of eight judges each.', u'In its case the division is mostly of an organizational nature, as a matter of dividing the work load; both senates handle the same kind of constitutional cases.', u'At some points in the past, one senate was considered more conservative and the other more liberal, but that is not the case as of 2011.', u'In Scotland, judges of the High Court of Justiciary are called Senators of the College of Justice.', u'In some, mostly federal countries with a unicameral legislature, some of the legislators are elected differently from the others and are called Senators.', u'In federal countries, such Senators represent the territories, while the other members represent the people at large (this device is used to allow a federal representation without having to establish a bicameral legislature); this is the case with St. Kitts and Nevis, Comoros and Micronesia.', u"In other, non-federal countries, the use of the term Senator marks some other difference between such members and the rest of the legislators (such as the method of selection); this is the case with the States of Jersey, Dominica's House of Assembly and the Saint Vincent House of Assembly.", u"In Wales, the National Assembly for Wales debating chamber is called the Senedd, pronounced 'Seneth'.", u'An academic senate is the governing body of some universities.', u'In Greece during the early stages of the Greek War of Independence, various local legislative and executive bodies were established by the Greek rebels.', u'Two of them were styled "senate": the Peloponnesian Senate and the Senate of Western Continental Greece.', u'== National senates in the world ==\n\n\n== Defunct senates ==\n\nNotes\n\n\n== See also ==\nSenator for life\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nLivius.org: Roman Senate\n[1]'], 'year': '1868-03-13', 'title': 'Senate begins Pres Andrew Johnson impeachment trial'}
{'sentences': [u'Freedom Riders were civil rights activists who rode interstate buses into the segregated southern United States in 1961 and following years to challenge the non-enforcement of the United States Supreme Court decisions Irene Morgan v. Commonwealth of Virginia (1946) and Boynton v. Virginia (1960), which ruled that segregated public buses were unconstitutional.', u'The Southern states had ignored the rulings and the federal government did nothing to enforce them.', u'The first Freedom Ride left Washington, D.C., on May 4, 1961, and was scheduled to arrive in New Orleans on May 17.', u'Boynton outlawed racial segregation in the restaurants and waiting rooms in terminals serving buses that crossed state lines.', u'Five years prior to the Boynton ruling, the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) had issued a ruling in Sarah Keys v. Carolina Coach Company (1955) that had explicitly denounced the Plessy v. Ferguson (1896) doctrine of separate but equal in interstate bus travel.', u'The ICC failed to enforce its ruling, and Jim Crow travel laws remained in force throughout the South.', u'The Freedom Riders challenged this status quo by riding interstate buses in the South in mixed racial groups to challenge local laws or customs that enforced segregation in seating.', u'The Freedom Rides, and the violent reactions they provoked, bolstered the credibility of the American Civil Rights Movement.', u'They called national attention to the disregard for the federal law and the local violence used to enforce segregation in the southern United States.', u'Police arrested riders for trespassing, unlawful assembly, and violating state and local Jim Crow laws, along with other alleged offenses, but they often first let white mobs attack them without intervention.', u'The Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) sponsored most of the subsequent Freedom Rides, but some were also organized by the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC).', u'The Freedom Rides followed dramatic sit-ins against segregated lunch counters, conducted by students and youth throughout the South, and boycotts of retail establishments that maintained segregated facilities, beginning in 1960.', u"The Supreme Court's decision in Boynton supported the right of interstate travelers to disregard local segregation ordinances.", u'Southern local and state police considered the actions of the Freedom Riders as criminal and arrested them in some locations.', u'In some localities, such as Birmingham, Alabama, the police cooperated with Ku Klux Klan chapters and other whites opposing the actions and allowed mobs to attack the riders.', u'== History ==\n\n\n=== Starting point ===\nThe Freedom Riders were inspired by the 1947 Journey of Reconciliation, led by Bayard Rustin and George Houser and co-sponsored by the Fellowship of Reconciliation and the then-fledgling Congress of Racial Equality (CORE).', u'Like the Freedom Rides of 1961, the Journey of Reconciliation was intended to test an earlier Supreme Court ruling that banned racial discrimination in interstate travel.', u'Rustin, Igal Roodenko, Joe Felmet and Andrew Johnnson, were arrested and sentenced to serve on a chain gang in North Carolina for violating local Jim Crow laws regarding segregated seating on public transportation.', u'The first Freedom Ride began on May 4, 1961.', u'Led by CORE Director James Farmer, 13 riders (seven black, six white, including Genevieve Hughes, William E. Harbour, and Ed Blankenheim) left Washington, DC, on Greyhound and Trailways buses.', u'Their plan was to ride through Virginia, the Carolinas, Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi, ending in New Orleans, Louisiana, where a civil rights rally was planned.', u'Most of the Riders were from CORE, and two were from SNCC.', u'Many were in their 40s and 50s.', u'Some were as young as 18.', u"The Freedom Riders' tactics for their journey were to have at least one interracial pair sitting in adjoining seats, and at least one black rider sitting up front, where seats under segregation had been reserved for white customers by local custom throughout the South.", u'The rest of the team would sit scattered throughout the rest of the bus.', u"One rider would abide by the South's segregation rules in order to avoid arrest and to contact CORE and arrange bail for those who were arrested.", u'Only minor trouble was encountered in Virginia and North Carolina, but John Lewis was attacked in Rock Hill, South Carolina.', u'Some of the Riders were arrested in Charlotte, North Carolina; Winnsboro, South Carolina; and Jackson, Mississippi.', u'=== Mob violence in Anniston and Birmingham ===\nThe Birmingham, Alabama, Police Commissioner, Bull Connor, together with Police Sergeant Tom Cook (an avid Ku Klux Klan supporter), organized violence against the Freedom Riders with local Ku Klux Klan chapters.', u'The pair made plans to bring the Ride to an end in Alabama.', u'They assured Gary Thomas Rowe, an FBI informer and member of Eastview Klavern #13 (the most violent Klan group in Alabama), that the mob would have fifteen minutes to attack the Freedom Riders without any arrests being made.', u'The plan was to allow an initial assault in Anniston with a final assault taking place in Birmingham.', u"On May 14, Mother's Day, in Anniston, a mob of Ku Klux Klansmen, some still in church attire, attacked the first of the two buses (the Greyhound).", u'The driver tried to leave the station, but was blocked until KKK members slashed its tires.', u'The mob forced the crippled bus to stop several miles outside of town and then firebombed it.', u'As the bus burned, the mob held the doors shut, intending to burn the riders to death.', u'Sources disagree, but either an exploding fuel tank or an undercover state investigator brandishing a revolver caused the mob to retreat, and the riders escaped the bus.', u'The mob beat the riders after they escaped the bus.', u'Only warning shots fired into the air by highway patrolmen prevented the riders from being lynched.', u'That night, the hospitalized Freedom Riders, most of whom had been refused care, were removed from the hospital at 2 AM, because the staff feared the mob outside the hospital.', u'The local civil rights leader Rev.', u'Fred Shuttlesworth organized several cars of blacks to rescue the injured Freedom Riders in defiance of the white supremacists.', u'The blacks were under the leadership of Colonel Stone Johnson and were openly armed as they arrived at the hospital, protecting the Freedom Riders from the mob.', u'When the Trailways bus reached Anniston and pulled in at the terminal an hour after the Greyhound bus was burned, it was boarded by eight Klansmen.', u'They beat the Freedom Riders and left them semi-conscious in the back of the bus.', u'When the bus arrived in Birmingham, it was attacked by a mob of KKK members aided and abetted by police under the orders of Commissioner Bull Connor.', u'As the riders exited the bus, they were beaten by the mob with baseball bats, iron pipes and bicycle chains.', u'Among the attacking Klansmen was Gary Thomas Rowe, an FBI informant.', u'White Freedom Riders were singled out for especially frenzied beatings; James Peck required more than 50 stitches to the wounds in his head.', u'Peck was taken to Carraway Methodist Medical Center, which refused to treat him; he was later treated at Jefferson Hillman Hospital.', u'When reports of the bus burning and beatings reached US Attorney General Robert Kennedy, he urged restraint on the part of Freedom Riders.', u'He sent an assistant, John Seigenthaler, to Alabama to try to calm the situation.', u'Despite the violence suffered and the threat of more to come, the Freedom Riders wanted to continue their journey.', u'Kennedy had arranged an escort for the Riders in order to get them to Montgomery, Alabama, safely.', u'However, radio reports told of the mob awaiting the riders at the bus terminal, as well as on the route to Montgomery.', u'The Greyhound clerks told the Riders that their drivers were refusing to drive any Freedom Riders anywhere.', u'Recognizing that their efforts had already called national attention to the civil rights cause and wanting to make the rally in New Orleans, the Riders decided to abandon the rest of the bus ride and fly directly to New Orleans from Birmingham.', u'When they first boarded the plane, all passengers had to exit because of a bomb threat.', u'Diane Nash, a Nashville college student and SNCC leader, believed that if Southern violence were allowed to halt the Freedom Rides, the movement would be set back years.', u'She pushed to find replacements to resume the rides.', u'On May 17, a new set of riders, 10 students from Nashville, took a bus to Birmingham, where they were arrested by Bull Connor and jailed.', u'These students kept their spirits up in jail by singing freedom songs.', u'Out of frustration, Connor drove them back up to the Tennessee line and dropped them off, saying, "I just couldn\'t stand their singing."', u'They immediately returned to Birmingham.', u"=== Mob violence in Montgomery ===\nIn answer to SNCC's call, Freedom Riders from across the Eastern US joined John Lewis and Hank Thomas, the two young SNCC members of the original Ride, who had remained in Birmingham.", u'On May 19, they attempted to resume the ride, but, terrified by the howling mob surrounding the bus depot, the drivers refused.', u'Harassed and besieged by the mob, the riders waited all night for a bus.', u'Under intense public pressure from the Kennedy administration, Greyhound was forced to provide a driver.', u"After direct intervention by Byron White of the Attorney General's office, Alabama Governor John Patterson reluctantly promised to protect the bus from KKK mobs and snipers on the road between Birmingham and Montgomery.", u'On the morning of May 20, the Freedom Ride resumed, with the bus carrying the riders traveling toward Montgomery at 90 miles an hour, protected by a contingent of the Alabama State Highway Patrol.', u'The Highway Patrol abandoned the bus and riders at the Montgomery city limits.', u'At the bus station on South Court Street, a white mob awaited.', u'They beat the Freedom Riders with baseball bats and iron pipes.', u'The local police allowed the beatings to go on uninterrupted.', u'Again, white Freedom Riders were singled out for particularly brutal beatings.', u'Reporters and news photographers were attacked first and their cameras destroyed, but one reporter took a photo later of Jim Zwerg in the hospital, showing how he was beaten and bruised.', u'Seigenthaler, a Justice Department official, was beaten and left unconscious lying in the street.', u'Ambulances refused to take the wounded to the hospital.', u'Local blacks rescued them, and a number of the Freedom Riders were hospitalized.', u"On the following night, Sunday, May 21, more than 1500 people packed Reverend Ralph Abernathy's First Baptist Church to honor the Freedom Riders.", u'Among the speakers were Rev.', u'Martin Luther King, Jr., who was newly based in Montgomery, Rev.', u'Fred Shuttlesworth, and James Farmer.', u'Outside, a mob of more than 3,000 whites attacked blacks, with a handful of the United States Marshals Service protecting the church from assault and fire bombs.', u'With city and state police making no effort to restore order, the civil rights leaders appealed to the President for protection.', u'President Kennedy threatened the governor to intervene with federal troops if he would not protect the people.', u'Governor Patterson forestalled that by finally ordering the Alabama National Guard to disperse the mob, and the Guard reached the church in the early morning.', u'In a commemorative Op-Ed piece in 2011, Bernard Lafayette remembered the mob breaking windows of the church with rocks and setting off tear gas canisters.', u'He recounted heroic action by King.', u'After learning that black taxi drivers were arming and forming a group to rescue the people inside, he worried that more violence would result.', u'He selected ten volunteers, who promised non-violence, to escort him through the white mob, which parted to let King and his escorts pass as they marched two by two.', u'King went out to the black drivers and asked them to disperse, to prevent more violence.', u'King and his escorts formally made their way back inside the church, unmolested.', u'Lafayette also was interviewed by BBC in 2011 and told about these events in an episode broadcast on radio 31 August 2011 in commemoration of the Freedom Rides.', u'The Alabama National Guard finally arrived in the early morning to disperse the mob and safely escorted all the people from the church.', u'=== Into Mississippi ===\n\nThe next day, Monday, May 22, more Freedom Riders from Congress of Racial Equality and Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee arrived in Montgomery to continue the rides through the South and replace the wounded riders still in the hospital.', u'Behind the scenes, the Kennedy administration arranged a deal with the governors of Alabama and Mississippi.', u'The governors agreed that state police and the National Guard would protect the Riders from mob violence.', u'In return, the federal government would not intervene to stop local police from arresting Freedom Riders for violating segregation ordinances when the buses arrived at the depots.', u'On Wednesday morning, May 24, Freedom Riders boarded buses for the journey to Jackson, Mississippi.', u'Surrounded by Highway Patrol and the National Guard, the buses arrived in Jackson without incident.', u'The riders were immediately arrested when they tried to use the white-only facilities at the depot.', u'In Montgomery, the next round of Freedom Riders, including the Yale University chaplain William Sloane Coffin, Gaylord Brewster Noyce, and southern ministers Shuttlesworth, Abernathy, Wyatt Tee Walker, and others were similarly arrested for violating local segregation ordinances.', u'This established a pattern followed by subsequent Freedom Rides, most of which traveled to Jackson, where they were arrested and jailed.', u"The Riders' strategy became one of trying to fill the jails.", u'Once the Jackson and Hinds County jails were filled to overflowing, the state transferred the Freedom Riders to the infamous Mississippi State Penitentiary (known as Parchman Farm).', u'Abusive treatment there included placement of Riders in the Maximum Security Unit (Death Row), issuance of only underwear, no exercise, and no mail.', u'When the Freedom Riders refused to stop singing freedom songs, prison officials took away their mattresses, sheets, and toothbrushes.', u'More Freedom Riders arrived from across the country, and at one time, more than 300 were held in Parchman Farm.', u'=== Kennedy urges "cooling off period" ===\nThe Kennedys called for a "cooling off period" and condemned the Rides as unpatriotic because they embarrassed the nation on the world stage at the height of the Cold War.', u'The Soviet Union criticized the United States for its racism and the attacks on the riders.', u'Attorney General Robert Kennedy, the chief law-enforcement officer of the land, was quoted as saying that he "does not feel that the Department of Justice can side with one group or the other in disputes over Constitutional rights."', u'His comment angered civil rights supporters, who considered the Justice Department duty-bound to enforce Supreme Court rulings and defend citizens exercising their Constitutional rights from mob violence.', u'Nonetheless, international outrage about the widely covered events and racial violence created pressure on United States political leaders.', u'On May 29, 1961, Attorney General Kennedy sent a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) asking it to comply with the bus-desegregation ruling it had issued in November 1955, in Sarah Keys v. Carolina Coach Company.', u'That ruling had explicitly repudiated separate but equal in the realm of interstate bus travel.', u'Chaired by the South Carolina Democrat J. Monroe Johnson, the ICC had failed to implement its own ruling.', u'James Farmer, head of CORE, responded to Kennedy saying, "We have been cooling off for 350 years, and if we cooled off any more, we\'d be in a deep freeze."', u'=== Summer escalation ===\n\nCORE, SNCC, and the SCLC rejected any "cooling off period".', u'They formed a Freedom Riders Coordinating Committee to keep the Rides rolling through June, July, August, and September.', u'During those months, more than 60 different Freedom Rides criss-crossed the South, most of them converging on Jackson, where every rider was arrested, more than 300 in total.', u'An unknown number of riders were arrested in other Southern towns.', u'It is estimated that almost 450 riders participated in one or more Freedom Rides.', u'About 75% were male, and the same percentage were under the age of 30, with about equal participation from blacks and whites.', u'During the summer of 1961, Freedom Riders also campaigned against other forms of racial discrimination.', u'They sat together in segregated restaurants, lunch counters and hotels.', u'This was especially effective when they targeted large companies, such as hotel chains.', u'Fearing boycotts in the North, the hotels began to desegregate their businesses.', u'In mid-June, a group of Freedom Riders had scheduled to end their ride in Tallahassee, Florida, with plans to fly home from the Tallahassee airport.', u"They were provided a police escort to the airport from the city's bus facilities.", u'At the airport, they decided to eat at a restaurant that was marked "For Whites Only".', u'The owners decided to close rather than serve the mixed group of Freedom Riders.', u'Although the restaurant was privately owned, it was leased from the county government.', u'Canceling their plane reservations, the Riders decided to wait until the restaurant re-opened so they could be served.', u'They waited until 11:00 pm that night and returned the following day.', u'During this time, hostile crowds gathered, threatening violence.', u'On June 16, 1961, the Freedom Riders were arrested in Tallahassee for unlawful assembly.', u'That arrest and subsequent trial became known as Dresner v. City of Tallahassee.', u'Convictions of the Riders were appealed to the US Supreme Court in 1963, which refused to hear the case based on technical reasons.', u'=== Monroe and Robert F. Williams ===\nIn early August, SNCC staff members James Forman and Paul Brooks, with the support of Ella Baker, began planning a Freedom Ride in solidarity with Robert F. Williams.', u'Williams was an extremely militant and controversial NAACP chapter president for Monroe, North Carolina.', u'After making the public statement that he would "meet violence with violence," (since the federal government would not protect his community from racial attacks) he had been suspended by the NAACP national board over the objections of Williams\' local membership.', u'Williams continued his work against segregation however, and was facing repeated attempts on his life because of it.', u"Some SNCC staff members sympathized with the local community's proclivity for armed self-defense, although many on the ride to Monroe saw this as an opportunity to prove the superiority of Gandhian nonviolence over the use of force.", u'The Freedom Riders in Monroe were brutally attacked by white supremacists with the approval of local police.', u"On August 27, James Forman - SNCC's Executive Secretary - was struck unconscious with the butt of a rifle and taken to jail with numerous other demonstrators.", u'Police and civilian white supremacists roamed the town shooting at blacks, who returned the gunfire.', u'Robert F. Williams fortified the black neighborhood against attack and in the process briefly detained a white couple who had gotten lost there.', u'The police accused Williams of kidnapping and called in the state milita and FBI to arrest him, in spite of the couple being quickly released.', u'Certain he would be lynched, Williams fled and eventually found refuge in Cuba.', u'Movement lawyers, eager to disengage from the situation, successfully urged the Freedom Riders not to practice the normal "jail-no bail" strategy in Monroe.', u'Local officials, also apparently eager to de-escalate, found demonstrators guilty but immediately suspended their sentences.', u'One Freedom Rider however, John Lowry, went on trial for the kidnapping case, along with several associates of Robert F. Williams, including Mae Mallory.', u'Monroe legal defense committees were popular around the country, but ultimately Lowry and Mallory served prison sentences.', u'In 1965, their convictions were vacated due to the exclusion of blacks from the jury selection.', u'=== Resolution and legacy ===\nBy September it had been over three months since the filing of the petition by Robert Kennedy.', u'CORE and SNCC leaders made tentative plans for a mass demonstration known as the "Washington Project".', u'This would mobilize hundreds, perhaps thousands, of nonviolent demonstrators to the capital city to apply pressure on the ICC and the Kennedy administration.', u'The idea was pre-empted when the ICC finally issued the necessary orders just before the end of the month.', u'The new policies went into effect on November 1, 1961, six years after the ruling in Sarah Keys v. Carolina Coach Company.', u'After the new ICC rule took effect, passengers were permitted to sit wherever they pleased on interstate buses and trains; "white" and "colored" signs were removed from the terminals; racially segregated drinking fountains, toilets, and waiting rooms serving interstate customers were consolidated; and the lunch counters began serving all customers, regardless of race.', u'The widespread violence provoked by the Freedom Rides sent shock waves through American society.', u'People worried that the Rides were evoking widespread social disorder and racial divergence, an opinion supported and strengthened in many communities by the press.', u'The press in white communities condemned the direct action approach that CORE was taking, while some of the national press negatively portrayed the Riders as provoking unrest.', u'At the same time, the Freedom Rides established great credibility with blacks and whites throughout the United States and inspired many people to engage in direct action for civil rights.', u'Perhaps most significantly, the actions of the Freedom Riders from the North, who faced danger on behalf of southern blacks, impressed and inspired the many blacks living in rural areas throughout the South.', u'They formed the backbone of the wider civil rights movement, who engaged in voter registration and other activities.', u'Southern blacks generally organized around their churches, the center of their communities and a base of moral strength.', u'The Freedom Riders helped inspire participation in other subsequent civil rights campaigns, including voter registration throughout the South, freedom schools, and the Black Power movement.', u'At the time, most blacks in southern states had been unable to register to vote, due to constitutions, laws and practices that had effectively disfranchised most of them since the turn of the 20th century.', u'For instance, white administrators supervised reading comprehension and literacy tests that highly educated blacks could not pass.', u'== List of Freedom Rides ==\n\n\n=== Precursors to Freedom Rides ===\n\n\n=== Original and subsequent Freedom Rides ===\n\n\n=== Mississippi Freedom Rides ===\n\n\n== Commemorations ==\n\nIn celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Freedom Rides, Oprah Winfrey invited all living Freedom Riders to join her TV program to celebrate their legacy.', u'The episode aired on May 4, 2011.', u'On May 6\u201316, 2011, 40 college students from across the United States embarked on a bus ride from Washington, D.C. to New Orleans, retracing the original route of the Freedom Riders.', u'The 2011 Student Freedom Ride, which was sponsored by PBS and American Experience, commemorated the 50th anniversary of the original Freedom Rides.', u'Students met with civil rights leaders along the way and traveled with original Freedom Riders such as Ernest "Rip" Patton, Joan Mulholland, Bob Singleton, Helen Singleton, Jim Zwerg, and Charles Person.', u'On May 16, 2011, PBS aired a documentary called Freedom Riders.', u'On May 19\u201321, 2011, the Freedom Rides were commemorated in Montgomery, Alabama, at the new Freedom Ride museum in the old Greyhound Bus terminal, where some of the violence had taken place in 1961.', u'On May 22\u201326, 2011, the arrival of the Freedom Rides in Jackson, Mississippi was commemorated with a 50th Anniversary Reunion and Conference in the city.', u'During commemorative events in February 2013 in Montgomery, Congressman John Lewis accepted the apologies of Chief Kevin Murphy of the Montgomery Police Department; Murphy gave Lewis his own badge, off his uniform, moving Lewis to tears.', u'In late 2011, Palestinian activists, inspired by the freedom riders, used the same methods in Israel by boarding a bus from which they were excluded.', u'Dan Shore\'s 2013 opera "Freedom Ride," set in New Orleans, celebrates the Freedom Riders.', u'== Notable Freedom Riders ==\n\n\n== See also ==\n"He Was My Brother", a Simon & Garfunkel song about the Freedom Riders\nReverse freedom rides\nFreedom Ride (Australia)\n\n\n== Notes ==\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Bibliography ==\n\n\n===
