{'sentences': [u'RMS Queen Mary is a retired ocean liner that sailed primarily on the North Atlantic Ocean from 1936 to 1967 for the Cunard Line (known as Cunard-White Star Line when the vessel entered service).', u"Built by John Brown & Company in Clydebank, Scotland, Queen Mary along with her sister ship, RMS Queen Elizabeth, were built as part of Cunard's planned two-ship weekly express service between Southampton, Cherbourg, and New York City.", u'The two ships were a British response to the superliners built by German and French companies in the late 1920s and early 1930s.', u'Queen Mary was the flagship of the Cunard Line from May 1936 until October 1946 when she was replaced in that role by Queen Elizabeth.', u'Queen Mary sailed on her maiden voyage on 27 May 1936 and captured the Blue Riband in August of that year; she lost the title to SS Normandie in 1937 and recaptured it in 1938, holding it until 1952 when she was beaten by the new SS United States.', u'With the outbreak of World War II, she was converted into a troopship and ferried Allied soldiers for the duration of the war.', u'Following the war Queen Mary was refitted for passenger service and along with Queen Elizabeth commenced the two-ship transatlantic passenger service for which the two ships were initially built.', u'The two ships dominated the transatlantic passenger transportation market until the dawn of the jet age in the late 1950s.', u'By the mid-1960s, Queen Mary was ageing and, though still among the most popular transatlantic liners, was operating at a loss.', u'After several years of decreased profits for Cunard Line, Queen Mary was officially retired from service in 1967.', u'She left Southampton for the last time on 31 October 1967 and sailed to the port of Long Beach, California, United States, where she remains permanently moored.', u'Much of the machinery, including one of the two engine rooms, three of the four propellers, and all of the boilers, were removed.', u'The ship serves as a tourist attraction featuring restaurants, a museum, and a hotel.', u'The ship is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.', u'The National Trust for Historic Preservation has accepted the Queen Mary as part of the Historic Hotels of America.', u'== Construction and naming ==\nWith Germany launching Bremen and Europa into service, Britain did not want to be left behind in the shipbuilding race.', u'White Star Line began construction on their 80,000-ton Oceanic in 1928, while Cunard planned a 75,000-ton unnamed ship of their own.', u'Construction on the ship, then known only as "Hull Number 534", began in December 1930 on the River Clyde by the John Brown & Company shipyard at Clydebank in Scotland.', u'Work was halted in December 1931 due to the Great Depression and Cunard applied to the British Government for a loan to complete 534.', u'The loan was granted, with enough money to complete Queen Mary and to build a sister ship, Hull No.', u'552, which became Queen Elizabeth.', u"One condition of the loan was that Cunard would merge with the White Star Line, which was Cunard's chief British rival at the time and which had already been forced by the depression to cancel construction of its Oceanic.", u'Both lines agreed and the merger was completed on 10 May 1934.', u'Work on Queen Mary resumed immediately and she was launched on 26 September 1934.', u'Completion ultimately took \u200a3 1\u20442 years and cost 3.5 million pounds sterling.', u"Much of the ship's interior was designed and constructed by the Bromsgrove Guild.", u'The ship was named after Queen Mary, consort of King George V. Until her launch, the name she was to be given was kept a closely guarded secret.', u'Legend has it that Cunard intended to name the ship Victoria, in keeping with company tradition of giving its ships names ending in "ia", but when company representatives asked the king\'s permission to name the ocean liner after Britain\'s "greatest queen", he said his wife, Queen Mary, would be delighted.', u'And so, the legend goes, the delegation had of course no other choice but to report that No.', u'534 would be called Queen Mary.', u'This story was denied by company officials, and traditionally the names of sovereigns have only been used for capital ships of the Royal Navy.', u"Some support for the story was provided by Washington Post editor Felix Morley, who sailed as a guest of the Cunard Line on Queen Mary's 1936 maiden voyage.", u'In his 1979 autobiography, For the Record, Morley wrote that he was placed at table with Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard Line.', u'Bates told him the story of the naming of the ship "on condition you won\'t print it during my lifetime."', u'The name Queen Mary could also have been decided upon as a compromise between Cunard and the White Star Line, as both lines had traditions of using names either ending in "ic" with White Star and "ia" with Cunard.', u'The name had already been given to the Clyde turbine steamer TS Queen Mary, so Cunard made an arrangement with its owners and this older ship was renamed Queen Mary II.', u'== History (1934\u20131939) ==\nIn 1934 the new liner was launched by Queen Mary as RMS Queen Mary.', u"On her way down the slipway, Queen Mary was slowed by eighteen drag chains, which checked the liner's progress into the Clyde, a portion of which had been widened to accommodate the launch.", u'When she sailed on her maiden voyage from Southampton, England on 27 May 1936, she was commanded by Sir Edgar T. Britten, who had been the master designate for Cunard White Star whilst the ship was under construction at the John Brown shipyard.', u'Queen Mary had a 80,774 gross tonnage (GT).', u"Her rival Normandie, which originally grossed 79,280 tonnes, had been modified the preceding winter to increase her size to 83,243 GT (an enclosed tourist lounge was built on the aft boat deck on the area where the game court was), and therefore kept the title of the world's largest ocean liner.", u'Queen Mary sailed at high speeds for most of her maiden voyage to New York, until heavy fog forced a reduction of speed on the final day of the crossing, arriving in New York Harbor on June 1.', u"Queen Mary's design was criticised for being too traditional, especially when Normandie's hull was revolutionary with a clipper-shaped, streamlined bow.", u'Except for her cruiser stern, she seemed to be an enlarged version of her Cunard predecessors from the pre\u2013World War I era.', u'Her interior design, while mostly Art Deco, seemed restrained and conservative when compared to the ultramodern French liner.', u'Queen Mary proved to be the more popular vessel than her larger rival, in terms of passengers carried.', u'In August 1936, Queen Mary captured the Blue Riband from Normandie, with average speeds of 30.14 knots (55.82 km/h; 34.68 mph) westbound and 30.63 knots (56.73 km/h; 35.25 mph) eastbound.', u'Normandie was refitted with a new set of propellers in 1937 and reclaimed the honour, but in 1938 Queen Mary took back the Blue Riband in both directions with average speeds of 30.99 knots (57.39 km/h; 35.66 mph) westbound and 31.69 knots (58.69 km/h; 36.47 mph) eastbound, records which stood until lost to United States in 1952.', u"=== Interior ===\nAmong facilities available on board Queen Mary, the liner featured two indoor swimming pools, beauty salons, libraries, and children's nurseries for all three classes, a music studio and lecture hall, telephone connectivity to anywhere in the world, outdoor paddle tennis courts, and dog kennels.", u'The largest room onboard was the cabin class (first class) main dining room (grand salon), spanning three stories in height and anchored by wide columns.', u'The cabin-class swimming pool facility spanned over two decks in height.', u'This was the first ocean liner to be equipped with her own Jewish prayer room \u2013 part of a policy to show that British shipping lines avoided the racism evident at that time in Nazi Germany.', u'The cabin-class main dining room featured a large map of the transatlantic crossing, with twin tracks symbolising the winter/spring route (further south to avoid icebergs) and the summer/autumn route.', u"During each crossing, a motorised model of Queen Mary would indicate the vessel's progress en route.", u'As an alternative to the main dining room, Queen Mary featured a separate cabin-class Verandah Grill on the Sun Deck at the upper aft of the ship.', u'The Verandah Grill was an exclusive \xe0 la carte restaurant with a capacity of approximately eighty passengers, and was converted to the Starlight Club at night.', u'Also on board was the Observation Bar, an Art Deco-styled lounge with wide ocean views.', u'Woods from different regions of the British Empire were used in her public rooms and staterooms.', u'Accommodation ranged from fully equipped, luxurious cabin (first) class staterooms to modest and cramped third-class cabins.', u'Artists commissioned by Cunard in 1933 for works of art in the interior include Edward Wadsworth and A. Duncan Carse.', u'== World War II ==\n\nIn late August 1939, Queen Mary was on a return run from New York to Southampton.', u'The international situation led to her being escorted by the battlecruiser HMS Hood.', u'She arrived safely, and set out again for New York on 1 September.', u'By the time she arrived, the Second World War had started and she was ordered to remain in port alongside Normandie until further notice.', u"In March 1940 Queen Mary and Normandie were joined in New York by Queen Mary's new sister ship Queen Elizabeth, fresh from her secret dash from Clydebank.", u'The three largest liners in the world sat idle for some time until the Allied commanders decided that all three ships could be used as troopships.', u'Normandie was destroyed by fire during her troopship conversion.', u'Queen Mary left New York for Sydney, Australia, where she, along with several other liners, was converted into a troopship to carry Australian and New Zealand soldiers to the United Kingdom.', u"In the WWII conversion, the ship's hull, superstructure and funnels were painted navy grey.", u'As a result of her new colour, and in combination with her great speed, she became known as the "Grey Ghost."', u'To protect against magnetic mines, a degaussing coil was fitted around the outside of the hull.', u'Inside, stateroom furniture and decoration were removed and replaced with triple-tiered wooden bunks, which were later replaced by standee bunks.', u'Six miles of carpet, 220 cases of china, crystal and silver service, tapestries and paintings were removed and stored in warehouses for the duration of the war.', u'The woodwork in the staterooms, the cabin-class dining room and other public areas was covered with leather.', u'Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth were the largest and fastest troopships involved in the war, often carrying as many as 15,000 men in a single voyage, and often traveling out of convoy and without escort.', u'Their high speed made it difficult for U boats to catch them.', u'On 2 October 1942, Queen Mary accidentally sank one of her escort ships, slicing through the light cruiser HMS Curacoa off the Irish coast with a loss of 239 lives.', u'Queen Mary was carrying thousands of Americans of the 29th Infantry Division to join the Allied forces in Europe.', u'Due to the risk of U-boat attacks, Queen Mary was under orders not to stop under any circumstances and steamed onward with a fractured stem.', u"Some sources claim that hours later, the convoy's lead escort returned to rescue 99 survivors of Curacoa's crew of 338, including her captain John W. Boutwood.", u"This claim is contradicted by the liner's then Staff Captain (and later Cunard Commodore) Harry Grattidge, who records that Queen Mary's Captain immediately ordered the accompanying destroyers to look for survivors within moments of the Curacoa's sinking.", u'In December 1942, Queen Mary carried 16,082 American soldiers from New York to Great Britain, a standing record for the most passengers ever transported on one vessel.', u'During this trip, while 700 miles (1,100 km) from Scotland during a gale, she was suddenly hit broadside by a rogue wave that may have reached a height of 28 metres (92 ft).', u"An account of this crossing can be found in Carter's book.", u'As quoted in the book, Carter\'s father, Dr. Norval Carter, part of the 110th Station Hospital on board at the time, wrote in a letter that at one point Queen Mary "damned near capsized... One moment the top deck was at its usual height and then, swoom!', u'Down, over, and forward she would pitch."', u'It was calculated later that the ship rolled 52 degrees, and would have capsized had she rolled another 3 degrees.', u'The incident inspired Paul Gallico to write his novel, The Poseidon Adventure (1969) and carry the incident to a fictional extreme.', u'This was adapted as a 1972 film by the same name, in which the SS Poseidon is turned upside-down, and the trapped passengers try to escape.', u'Naturally parts of the film were shot in the actual Queen Mary, conveniently docked in Long Beach.', u'During the war Queen Mary carried British Prime Minister Winston Churchill across the Atlantic for meetings with fellow Allied forces officials on several occasions.', u'He was listed on the passenger manifest as "Colonel Warden".', u'The ship was also used to return American troops from Europe after the war.', u'== After World War II ==\n\nFrom September 1946 to July 1947, Queen Mary was refitted for passenger service, adding air conditioning and upgrading her berth configuration to 711 first class (formerly called cabin class), 707 cabin class (formerly tourist class) and 577 tourist class (formerly third class) passengers.', u"Following refit, Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth dominated the transatlantic passenger trade as Cunard White Star's two-ship weekly express service through the latter half of the 1940s and well into the 1950s.", u'They proved highly profitable for Cunard (as the company was renamed in 1947).', u'On 1 January 1949, Queen Mary ran aground off Cherbourg, France.', u'She was refloated the next day and returned to service.', u'In 1958 the first transatlantic flight by a jet began a completely new era of competition for the Cunard Queens.', u'On some voyages, winters especially, Queen Mary sailed into harbour with more crew than passengers, though both she and Queen Elizabeth still averaged over 1000 passengers per crossing into the middle 1960s.', u'By 1965, the entire Cunard fleet was operating at a loss.', u"Hoping to continue financing the Queen Elizabeth 2 which was under construction at Brown's shipyard - Cunard mortgaged the majority of the fleet.", u"Due to a combination of age, lack of public interest, inefficiency in a new market, and the damaging after effects of the national seamen's strike, Cunard announced that both Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth would be retired from service and sold off.", u'Many offers were submitted, and the bid of $3.45m/\xa31.2m from Long Beach, California beat the Japanese scrap merchants.', u'Queen Mary was retired from service in 1967.', u'On 27 September she completed her 1,000th and last crossing of the North Atlantic, having carried 2,112,000 passengers over 3,792,227 miles (6,102,998 km).', u'Under the command of Captain John Treasure Jones, who had been her captain since 1965, she sailed from Southampton for the last time on 31 October with 1,093 passengers and 806 crew.', u'After an epic voyage around Cape Horn, she arrived in Long Beach on 9 December.', u'Queen Elizabeth was withdrawn in 1968 and Queen Elizabeth 2 took over the transatlantic route in 1969.', u'== Long Beach ==\n\nQueen Mary is permanently moored as a tourist attraction, hotel, museum, and event facility in Long Beach.', u"From 1983 to 1993, Howard Hughes' plane Spruce Goose, was located in a large dome nearby.", u'The dome was later repurposed as a soundstage for film and television.', u'The structure is now used by Carnival Cruise Lines as a ship terminal, as a venue for the Long Beach Derby Gals roller derby team and as an event venue.', u'Since drilling had started for oil in Long Beach Harbor, some of the revenue had been set aside in the "Tidelands Oil Fund."', u'Some of this money was allocated in 1958 for the future purchase of a maritime museum for Long Beach.', u'=== Conversion ===\n\nWhen Queen Mary was bought by Long Beach, the new owners decided not to preserve her as an ocean liner.', u'It had been decided to clear almost every area of the ship below "C" deck (called "R" deck after 1950, to lessen passenger confusion, as the restaurants were located on "R" deck) to make way for Jacques Cousteau\'s new Living Sea Museum.', u'This increased museum space to 400,000 square feet (37,000 m2).', u'It required removal of all the boiler rooms, the forward engine room, both turbo generator rooms, the ship stabilisers, and the water softening plant.', u"The ship's empty fuel tanks were filled with local mud to keep the ship's centre of gravity and draft at the correct levels, as these critical factors had been affected by the removal of the various components and structure.", u'Only the aft engine room and "shaft alley", at the stern of the ship, would be spared.', u'Remaining space would be used for storage or office space.', u'One problem that arose during the conversion was a dispute between land-based and maritime unions over conversion jobs.', u'The United States Coast Guard had final say.', u'Queen Mary was deemed a building, since most of her propellers had been removed and her machinery gutted.', u'The ship was also repainted with its red water level paint at a slightly higher level than previously.', u'During the conversion the funnels were removed, as this area was needed to lift out the scrap materials from the engine and boiler rooms.', u'Workers found that the funnels were significantly degraded and they were replaced with replicas.', u'With all of the lower decks nearly gutted from R deck and down, Diners Club, the initial lessee of the ship, converted the remainder of the vessel into a hotel.', u'Diners Club Queen Mary dissolved and vacated the ship in 1970 after their parent company, Diners Club International, was sold, and a change in corporate direction was mandated during the conversion process.', u'Specialty Restaurants, a Los Angeles-based company that focused on theme-based restaurants, took over as master lessee the following year.', u'This second plan was based on converting most of her first- and second-class cabins on A and B decks into hotel rooms, and converting the main lounges and dining rooms into banquet spaces.', u"On Promenade Deck, the starboard promenade was enclosed to feature an upscale restaurant and caf\xe9 named Lord Nelson's and Lady Hamilton's; it was themed in the fashion of early-19th-century sailing ships.", u'The famed and elegant Observation Bar was redecorated as a western-themed bar.', u'The smaller first-class public rooms, such as the Drawing Room, Library, Lecture Room and the Music studio, would be stripped of most of their fittings and converted to commercial use.', u'This markedly expanded retail space on the ship.', u"Two more shopping malls were built on the Sun Deck in separate spaces previously used for first-class cabins and engineers' quarters.", u'A post-war feature of the ship, the first-class cinema, was removed for kitchen space for the new Promenade Deck dining venues.', u'The first-class lounge and smoking room were reconfigured and converted into banquet space.', u'The second-class smoking room was subdivided into a wedding chapel and office space.', u'On the Sun Deck, the elegant Verandah Grill would be gutted and converted into a fast-food eatery, while a new upscale dining venue was created directly above it on Sports Deck, in space once used for crew quarters.', u'The second-class lounges were expanded to the sides of the ship and used for banqueting.', u'On R deck, the first-class dining room was reconfigured and subdivided into two banquet venues, the Royal Salon and the Windsor Room.', u'The second-class dining room was subdivided into kitchen storage and a crew mess hall, while the third-class dining room was initially used as storage and crew space.', u'Also on R deck, the first-class Turkish bath complex, the 1930s equivalent to a spa, was removed.', u'The second-class pool was removed and its space initially used for office space, while the first-class swimming pool was used for hotel guests.', u'Combined with modern safety codes and the structural soundness of the area directly below, the swimming pool is no longer in use.', u'No crew cabins remain intact aboard the ship today.', u'=== As a tourist attraction ===\n\nOn 8 May 1971 Queen Mary opened her doors to tourists.', u"Initially, only portions of the ship were open to the public as Specialty Restaurants had yet to open its dining venues and PSA had not completed work converting the ship's original First Class staterooms into the hotel.", u'As a result, the ship was open only on weekends.', u"On 11 December 1971 Jacques Cousteau's Museum of the Sea opened, with a quarter of the planned exhibits completed.", u"Within the decade, Cousteau's museum closed due to low ticket sales and the deaths of many of the fish that were housed in the museum.", u"On 2 November 1972 PSA's hotel opened its initial 150 guest rooms.", u'Two years later, with all 400 rooms finished, PSA brought in Hyatt Hotels to manage the hotel.', u'It operated the facility from 1974 to 1980 as the Queen Mary Hyatt Hotel.', u'By 1980, it had become apparent that the existing system was not working.', u'The ship was losing millions each year for the city because the hotel, restaurants and museum were run by three separate concessionaires, while the city owned the vessel and operated guided tours.', u'It was decided that a single operator with more experience in attractions was needed.', u'Jack Wrather, a local millionaire, had fallen in love with the ship because he and his wife, Bonita Granville, had fond memories of sailing on it numerous times.', u'Wrather signed a 66-year lease with the city of Long Beach to operate the entire property.', u'He oversaw the display of the Spruce Goose, on long-term loan.', u'The immense plane, which had been sitting in a hangar in Long Beach for decades unseen by the public, was installed in a huge geodesic dome adjacent to the liner in 1983, attracting increased attendance.', u'His Wrather Port Properties operated the entire attraction after his death in 1984 until 1988, when his holdings were bought by the Walt Disney Company.', u'Wrather had built the Disneyland Hotel in 1955, when Walt Disney had insufficient funds to construct the resort himself.', u'Disney had been trying to buy the hotel for 30 years.', u'When they finally succeeded, they also acquired the Queen Mary.', u'This was never marketed as a Disney property.', u'Through the late 1980s and early 1990s the Queen Mary struggled financially.', u'Disney pinned their hopes for turning the attraction around on Port Disney, a huge planned resort on the adjacent docks.', u"It was to include a theme park known as DisneySea, themed around the world's oceans.", u'The plans eventually fell through; in 1992 Disney gave up the lease on the ship to focus on building what would become Disney California Adventure Park.', u'The DisneySea concept was recycled a decade later in Japan as Tokyo DisneySea, with a recreated ocean liner resembling Queen Mary named the SS Columbia as the centerpiece of the American Waterfront area.', u'With Disney gone, the Hotel Queen Mary closed on 30 September 1992.', u'The owners of the Spruce Goose, the Aero Club of Southern California, sold the plane to the Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum in Oregon.', u'The plane departed on barges on 2 October 1992, leaving the huge dome empty.', u'The Queen Mary tourist attraction remained open for another two months, but on 31 December 1992, the Queen Mary completely closed her doors to tourists and visitors.', u'On 5 February 1993, RMS Foundation, Inc signed a five-year lease with the city of Long Beach to act as the operators of the property.', u'The foundation was run by President and C.E.O.', u'Joseph F. Prevratil, who had managed the attraction for Wrather.', u'On 26 February 1993 the tourist attraction reopened completely, while the hotel reopened partially on 5 March with 125 rooms and the banquet facilities, with the remainder of the rooms coming on line on 30 April.', u"In 1995, RMS Foundation's lease was extended to twenty years, while the scope of the lease was reduced to operation of the ship.", u"A new company, Queen's Seaport Development, Inc. (QSDI), was established in 1995 to control the real estate adjacent to the vessel.", u'In 1998, the City of Long Beach extended the QSDI lease to 66 years.', u'In 2005, QSDI sought Chapter 11 protection due to a rent credit dispute with the City.', u'In 2006, the bankruptcy court requested bids from parties interested in taking over the lease from QSDI.', u'The minimum required opening bid was $41M.', u'The operation of the ship, by RMS Foundation, remained independent of the bankruptcy.', u'In Summer 2007, Queen Mary\'s lease was sold to a group named "Save the Queen," managed by Hostmark Hospitality Group.', u'They planned to develop the land adjacent to Queen Mary, and upgrade, renovate, and restore the ship.', u"During their management, staterooms were updated with iPod docking stations and flatscreen TVs, and the ship's three funnels and waterline area were repainted their original Cunard Red color.", u"The portside Promenade Deck's planking was restored and refinished.", u"Many lifeboats were repaired and patched, and the ship's kitchens were renovated with new equipment.", u"In 2004, Queen Mary and Stargazer Productions added Tibbies Great American Cabaret to the space previously occupied by the ship's bank and wireless telegraph room.", u'Stargazer Productions and Queen Mary transformed the space into a working dinner theatre complete with stage, lights, sound, and scullery.', u'In late September 2009, management of Queen Mary was taken over by Delaware North Companies, who plan to continue restoration and renovation of the ship and its property.', u'They were determined to revitalise and enhance the ship as an attraction.', u'But in April 2011, The City Of Long Beach was informed that Delaware North was no longer managing Queen Mary.', u'Garrison Investment Group said this decision was purely business.', u'Delaware North still manages Scorpion, a Soviet submarine that has been a separate attraction next to Queen Mary since 1998.', u'Evolution Hospitality, LLC.', u'assumed operational control of the Queen Mary on 23 September 2011, with Garrison Investments leasing Queen Mary.', u'In 2016 Urban Commons, a real estate company, assumed the lease of the Queen Mary.', u'They revealed plans to extensively renovate the liner over the next year, and to redevelop the adjacent 45 acres of parking with a boutique hotel, restaurants, a marina, an amphitheater, jogging trails, bike paths, and possibly a huge Ferris wheel, all at a cost of up to $250 million.', u'=== Meeting of the Queens ===\n\nOn 23 February 2006, RMS Queen Mary 2 saluted her predecessor as she made a port of call in Los Angeles Harbor, while on a cruise to Mexico.', u'On March 2011, Queen Mary was saluted by the MS Queen Victoria while fireworks were going on, and on 12 March 2013, the MS Queen Elizabeth made a salute while there were fireworks.', u'The salute was carried out with Queen Mary replying with her one working air horn in response to Queen Mary 2 sounding her combination of two brand new horns and an original 1934 Queen Mary horn (on loan from the City of Long Beach).', u'Queen Mary originally had three whistles tuned to 55 Hz, a frequency chosen because it was low enough that the extremely loud sound of it would not be painful to human ears.', u"Modern IMO regulations specify ships' horn frequencies to be in the range 70\u2013200 Hz for vessels that are over 200 metres (660 ft) in length.", u'Traditionally, the lower the frequency, the larger the ship.', u'Queen Mary 2, being 345 metres (1,132 ft) long, was given the lowest possible frequency (70 Hz) for her regulation whistles, in addition to the refurbished 55 Hz whistle on permanent loan.', u'Fifty-five Hz is the "A" note an octave above the lowest note of a standard piano keyboard.', u'The air-driven Tyfon whistle can be heard at least 10 miles (16 km) away.', u"=== W6RO ===\nQueen Mary's original, professionally manned wireless radio room was removed when the ship was moored in Long Beach.", u'In its place, an amateur radio room was created one deck above the original radio reception room, with some of the discarded original radio equipment used for display purposes.', u'The amateur radio station, with the call sign W6RO ("Whiskey Six Romeo Oscar"), relies on volunteers from a local amateur radio club.', u'They staff the radio room during most public hours.', u'The radios can also be used by other licensed amateur radio operators.', u'In honour of his over forty years of dedication to W6RO and Queen Mary, in November 2007 the Queen Mary Wireless Room was renamed as the Nate Brightman Radio Room.', u"This was announced on 28 October 2007, at Brightman's 90th birthday party by Joseph Prevratil, former President and CEO of the Queen Mary.", u"=== Rumors of hauntings ===\nFollowing Queen Mary's permanent docking in California, the ship was rumored to be haunted.", u'Since the 1980s, this supposed haunting has been featured in the marketing and promotion of the ship, with various attractions and tours presenting the theme for visitors.', u'The ship was ranked as "one of the top 10 most haunted places in America" by Time Magazine in 2008.', u"In particular, Cabin B340 (formerly Cabin B326, prior to the ship's refitting after World War II) is alleged to be haunted by the spirit of a person who was murdered there.", u'Individuals have reported hearing sounds of children playing in the nursery.', u'Other reported ghosts include a young sailor who was accidentally killed in the ship\'s engine room, crewmembers of the Curacoa who were killed when Queen Mary collided with her, and an unidentified "lady in white".', u'At least one book has been written on the subject.', u"At least 49 crew and passengers are known to have died during the Queen Mary's service as a luxury liner.", u"Although many hauntings are reported as the ghosts of drowning victims, the ship's logs do not record any instances of passengers drowning.", u'Approximately 75% of the deaths were crew members, and about 25% were passengers.', u'It is unknown how many servicemen or POWs died aboard the Queen Mary during her stint as a troop transport ship in World War II.', u'Paranormal researcher John Champion writes in Skeptical Inquirer Magazine that he understands why people persist in believing that the Queen Mary is haunted when the only evidence given is anecdotes, creepy feelings and shadows.', u'Tourists who sign up for the haunted tour are given access to normally off limit areas of the ship, while tours of the history of the ship are more limited.', u'Champion believes that the owners are doing a disservice to the real history, the people who should be honored "by remembering who they really were and what they actually did".', u"He understands why people report strange occurrences, the ship still creaks and groans, and people's imaginations can get away from them such that they start seeing and hearing all kinds of things, attributing them to the paranormal which they have been primed for.", u'"Ghost stories are fine", concludes Champion "when presented as such.', u'The confusion of science and history with fiction ... gets us further away from the ability to relish in and truly explore our own recent history."', u'The ship has been the site of many paranormal television shows including Ghost Hunters, Ghost Adventures, Fact or Faked and Most Haunted.', u'== See also ==\n\nRMS Mauretania (1938)\nMS Queen Elizabeth\nMS Queen Victoria\nRMS St Helena, one of the last Royal Mail Ships\n\n\n== "cures" of the time damaged rather than aided the young Einstein, but schizophrenia can be intractable.', u'His brother Hans Albert Einstein believed that his memory and cognitive abilities were damaged by electroconvulsive therapy treatments.', u'After suffering a breakdown, Eduard had told his father that he hated him.', u'Albert Einstein immigrated to the United States from Germany in 1933 Einstein (born January 1902 \u2013 last mentioned in 1903; possible date of death, 18 September 1903) was the first child of Mileva Mari\u0107 and Albert Einstein.", u'According to the correspondence between her parents, "Lieserl" was born in January 1902, a year before her parents married, in Novi Sad, Vojvodina, present day Serbia, and was cared for by her mother for a short time while Einstein worked in Switzerland before Mari\u0107 joined him there without the child.', u'"Lieserl\'s" existence was unknown to biographers until 1986, when a batch of letters between Albert and Mileva were discovered by Hans Albert Einstein\'s daughter Evelyn.', u'Mari\u0107 had hoped for a girl, while Einstein would have preferred a boy.', u'In their letters, they called the unborn child "Lieserl", when referring to a girl, or "Hanserl", if a boy.', u'Both "Lieserl" and "Hanserl" were augmentatives of the common German names Liese and Hans.', u'The first reference to Mari\u0107\'s pregnancy was found in a letter Einstein wrote to her from Winterthur, probably on 28 May 1901 (letter 36), asking twice about "the boy" and "our little son", whereas Mari\u0107\'s first reference was found in her letter of 13 November 1901 (letter 43) from Stein am Rhein, in which she referred to the unborn child as "Lieserl".', u'Einstein goes along with Mari\u0107\'s wish for a daughter, and referred to the unborn child as "Lieserl" as well, but with a sense of humour as in letter 45 of 12 December 1901 "... and be happy about our Lieserl, whom I secretly (so Dollie doesn\'t notice) prefer to imagine a Hanserl."', u'The child must have been born shortly before 4 February 1902, when Einstein wrote: "... now you see that it really is a Lieserl, just as you\'d wished.', u'Is she healthy and does she cry properly?', u'[...] I love her so much and don\'t even know her yet!"', u'The last time "Lieserl" was mentioned in their extant correspondence was in Einstein\'s letter of 19 September 1903 (letter 54), in which he showed concern for her suffering from scarlet fever.', u'His asking "as what is the child registered?', u'[Adding] we must take precautions that problems don\'t arise for her later" may indicate the intention to give the child up for adoption.', u'As neither the full name, nor the fate of the child are known, so far several theories about her life and death have been put forward:\nMichele Zackheim, in her book on "Lieserl", Einstein\'s Daughter, states that "Lieserl" was mentally challenged at birth, and that she lived with her mother\'s family and probably died of scarlet fever in September 1903.', u'Another possibility, favoured by Robert Schulmann of the Einstein Papers Project, is that "Lieserl" was adopted by Mari\u0107\'s close friend, Helene Savi\u0107, and was raised by her and lived under the name "Zorka Savi\u0107" until the 1990s.', u'Savi\u0107 did in fact raise a child by the name of Zorka, who was blind from childhood and died in the 1990s.', u'Her grandson Milan Popovi\u0107 rejects the possibility that it was "Lieserl", and also favors the theory that the child died in September 1903.', u'A letter widely circulated on the Internet on the "universal force" of love, attributed as "a letter from Albert Einstein to his daughter", is a hoax.', u"== Abraham Einstein (Albert's grandfather) ==\nAbraham Einstein (8 Apr 1808 \u2013 21 Nov 1868), the son of Ruppert Einstein and Rebekha Overnauer, is the father of Hermann Einstein and grandfather of Hermann's son, Albert.", u'Abraham married Helene Moos, both German Jews, in April 1839 female\nSurnames are Einstein and places are in Germany unless otherwise noted.', u'=== Einsteins and Ainsteins ===\nFirst known is Moses Ainstein, Germany (fl.', u'c. 1700).', u'He had two sons: {'sentences': [u'North is a noun, adjective, or adverb indicating direction or geography.', u'North is one of the four cardinal directions or compass points.', u'It is the opposite of south and is perpendicular to east and west.', u'== Etymology ==\nThe word north is related to the Old High German nord, both descending from the Proto-Indo-European unit ner-, meaning "down" (or "under").', u'(Presumably a natural primitive description of its concept is "to the left of the rising sun".)', u'The Latin word borealis comes from the Greek boreas "north wind, north", which, according to Ovid, was personified as the son of the river-god Strymon, the father of Calais and Zetes.', u'Septentrionalis is from septentriones, "the seven plow oxen", a name of Ursa Maior.', u'The Greek arktikos is named for the same constellation, and is the derivation of the English word "Arctic".', u'Other languages have sometimes more interesting derivations.', u"For example, in Lezgian, kefer can mean both 'disbelief' and 'north', since to the north of the Muslim Lezgian homeland there are areas formerly inhabited by non-Muslim Caucasian and Turkic peoples.", u'In many languages of Mesoamerica, "north" also means "up".', u'In Hungarian the word for north is \xe9szak, which is derived from \xe9jszaka ("night"), since above the Tropic of Cancer, the Sun never shines from the north, except inside the Arctic Circle during the summer midnight sun.', u"The direction north is often associated with colder climates due to the fact that most of the world's land at high latitudes are located in the northern hemisphere.", u'== Mapping ==\nBy convention, the top side of a map is often north.', u'To go north using a compass for navigation, set a bearing or azimuth of 0\xb0 or 360\xb0.', u'North is specifically the direction that, in Western culture, is treated as the fundamental direction:\nNorth is used (explicitly or implicitly) to define all other directions.', u'The (visual) top edges of maps usually correspond to the northern edge of the area represented, unless explicitly stated otherwise or landmarks are considered more useful for that territory than specific directions.', u'On any rotating non-astronomical object, north denotes the side appearing to rotate counter-clockwise when viewed from afar along the axis of rotation.', u'== Magnetic north and declination ==\nMagnetic north is of interest because it is the direction indicated as north on a properly functioning (but uncorrected) magnetic compass.', u'The difference between it and true north is called the magnetic declination (or simply the declination where the context is clear).', u'For many purposes and physical circumstances, the error in direction that results from ignoring the distinction is tolerable; in others a mental or instrument compensation, based on assumed knowledge of the applicable declination, can solve all the problems.', u'But simple generalizations on the subject should be treated as unsound, and as likely to reflect popular misconceptions about terrestrial magnetism.', u'Maps intended for usage in orienteering by compass will clearly indicate the local declination for easy correction to true north.', u'Maps may also indicate grid north, which is a navigational term referring to the direction northwards along the grid lines of a map projection.', u'== Roles of north as prime direction ==\nThe visible rotation of the night sky around the visible celestial pole provides a vivid metaphor of that direction corresponding to up.', u'Thus the choice of the north as corresponding to up in the northern hemisphere, or of south in that role in the southern, is, prior to world-wide communication, anything but an arbitrary one.', u'On the contrary, it is of interest that Chinese and Islamic culture even considered south as the proper top end for maps.', u"In Western culture:\nMaps tend to be drawn for viewing with either true north or magnetic north at the top\nGlobes of the earth have the North Pole at the top, or if the Earth's axis is represented as inclined from vertical (normally by the angle it has relative to the axis of the Earth's orbit), in the top half.", u"Maps are usually labelled to indicate which direction on the map corresponds to a direction on the earth,\nusually with a single arrow oriented to the map's representation of true north,\noccasionally with a single arrow oriented to the map's representation of magnetic north, or two arrows oriented to true and magnetic north respectively,\noccasionally with a compass rose, but if so, usually on a map with north at the top and usually with north decorated more prominently than any other compass point.", u'Up is a metaphor for north.', u'The notion that north should always be up and east at the right was established by the Greek astronomer Ptolemy.', u'The historian Daniel Boorstin suggests that perhaps this was because the better-known places in his world were in the northern hemisphere, and on a flat map these were most convenient for study if they were in the upper right-hand corner.', u'== Roles of east and west as inherently subsidiary directions ==\nWhile the choice of north over south as prime direction reflects quite arbitrary historical factors, east and west are not nearly as natural alternatives as first glance might suggest.', u'Their folk definitions are, respectively, "where the sun rises" and "where it sets".', u'Except on the Equator, however, these definitions, taken together, would imply that\neast and west would not be 180 degrees apart, but instead would differ from that by up to twice the degrees of latitude of the location in question, and\nthey would each move slightly from day to day and, in the temperate zones, markedly over the course of the year.', u'Reasonably accurate folk astronomy, such as is usually attributed to Stone Age peoples or later Celts, would arrive at east and west by noting the directions of rising and setting (preferably more than once each) and choosing as prime direction one of the two mutually opposite directions that lie halfway between those two.', u'The true folk-astronomical definitions of east and west are "the directions, a right angle from the prime direction, that are closest to the rising and setting, respectively, of the sun (or moon).', u'== Cultural references ==\nBeing the "default" direction on the compass, north is referred to frequently in Western popular culture.', u'Some examples include:\nThe phrase "north of X" is often used by Americans to mean "more than X" or "greater than X", i.e.', u'"The world population is north of 7 billion people" or "north of 40 [years old]".', u'== See also ==\nNordicity\nList of northernmost items\nNordicism\nNorthing\nSeptentrional\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\n The dictionary definition of north at Wiktionary'], 'year': '1862-05-31', 'title': 'Battle of Fair Oaks - Va; North defeats South'}
{'sentences': [u'Magazines are publications, usually periodical publications, that are printed or electronically published (sometimes referred to as online magazines) They are generally published on a regular schedule and contain a variety of content.', u'They are generally financed by advertising, by a purchase price, by prepaid subscriptions, or a combination of the three.', u'At its root, the word "magazine" refers to a collection or storage location.', u'In the case of written publication, it is a collection of written articles.', u'This explains why magazine publications share the word root with gunpowder magazines, artillery magazines, firearms magazines, and, in various languages although not English, retail stores such as department stores.', u'== Definition ==\nBy definition, a "magazine" paginates with each issue starting at page three, with the standard sizing being 8 3/8" x 10 7/8".', u'However, in the technical sense a "journal" has continuous pagination throughout a volume.', u'Thus Business Week, which starts each issue anew with page one, is a magazine, but the Journal of Business Communication, which starts each volume with the winter issue and continues the same sequence of pagination throughout the coterminous year, is a journal.', u'Some professional or trade publications are also peer-reviewed, an example being the Journal of Accountancy.', u'Academic or professional publications that are not peer-reviewed are generally professional magazines.', u'The fact that a publication calls itself a "journal" does not make it a journal in the technical sense.', u'The Wall Street Journal is actually a newspaper.', u'== Distribution ==\n\nMagazines can be distributed through the mail, through sales by newsstands, bookstores, or other vendors, or through free distribution at selected pick-up locations.', u'The subscription business models for distribution fall into three main categories.', u'=== Paid circulation ===\nIn this model, the magazine is sold to readers for a price, either on a per-issue basis or by subscription, where an annual fee or monthly price is paid and issues are sent by post to readers.', u'Paid circulation allows for defined readership statistics.', u'=== Non-paid circulation ===\nThis means that there is no cover price and issues are given away, for example in street dispensers, airline in-flight magazines, or included with other products or publications.', u'An example from the UK and Australia is TNT Magazine.', u'Because this model involves giving issues away to unspecific populations, the statistics only entail the number of issues distributed, and not who reads them.', u'=== Controlled circulation ===\nThis is the model used by many trade magazines (industry-based periodicals) distributed only to qualifying readers, often for free and determined by some form of survey.', u'This latter model was widely used before the rise of the World Wide Web and is still employed by some titles.', u'For example, in the United Kingdom, a number of computer-industry magazines use this model, including Computer Weekly and Computing, and in finance, Waters Magazine.', u'For the global media industry, an example would be VideoAge International.', u'== History ==\n\nThe earliest example of magazines was Erbauliche Monaths Unterredungen, a literary and philosophy magazine, which was launched in 1663 in Germany.', u"The Gentleman's Magazine, first published in 1731, in London was the first general-interest magazine.", u'Edward Cave, who edited The Gentleman\'s Magazine under the pen name "Sylvanus Urban", was the first to use the term "magazine," on the analogy of a military storehouse.', u'Founded by Herbert Ingram in 1842, The Illustrated London News was the first illustrated magazine.', u'=== Britain ===\nThe oldest consumer magazine still in print is The Scots Magazine, which was first published in 1739, though multiple changes in ownership and gaps in publication totalling over 90 years weaken that claim.', u"Lloyd's List was founded in Edward Lloyd's England coffee shop in 1734; it is still published as a daily business newspaper.", u'Despite being among the first mass media outlets to venture from the bible, periodicals still remained rooted in the naturalized class and gender system held by European and American society.', u'Manufacturing of the early magazines were done via an archaic form of the printing press, using large hand engraved wood blocks for printing.', u'When production of magazines increased, entire production lines were created to manufacture these wooden blocks.', u'=== France ===\n\nUnder the ancien regime, the most prominent magazines were Mercure de France, Journal des s\xe7avans, founded in 1665 for scientists, and Gazette de France, founded in 1631.', u"Jean Loret was one of France's first journalists.", u'He disseminated the weekly news of music, dance and Parisian society from 1650 until 1665 in verse, in what he called a gazette burlesque, assembled in three volumes of La Muse historique (1650, 1660, 1665).', u'The French press lagged a generation behind the British, for they catered to the needs the aristocracy, while the newer British counterparts were oriented toward the middle and working classes.', u'Periodicals were censored by the central government in Paris.', u'They were not totally quiescent politically\u2014often they criticized Church abuses and bureaucratic ineptitude.', u'They supported the monarchy and they played at most a small role in stimulating the revolution.', u'During the Revolution new periodicals played central roles as propaganda organs for various factions.', u'Jean-Paul Marat (1743\u20131793) was the most prominent editor.', u"His L'Ami du peuple advocated vigorously for the rights of the lower classes against the enemies of the people Marat hated; it closed when he was assassinated.", u'After 1800 Napoleon reimposed strict censorship.', u'Magazines flourished after Napoleon left in 1815.', u'Most were based in Paris and most emphasized literature, poetry and stories.', u'They served religious, cultural and political communities.', u'In times of political crisis they expressed and helped shape the views of their readership and thereby were major elements in the changing political culture.', u'For example there were eight Catholic periodicals in 1830 in Paris.', u'None were officially owned or sponsored by the Church and they reflected a range of opinion among educated Catholics about current issues, such as the 1830 July Revolution that overthrew the Bourbon monarchy.', u'Several were strong supporters of the Bourbon kings, but all eight ultimately urged support for the new government, putting their appeals in terms of preserving civil order.', u'They often discussed the relationship between church and state.', u'Generally they urged priests to focus on spiritual matters and not engage in politics.', u'Historian M. Patricia Dougherty says this process created a distance between the Church and the new monarch and enabled Catholics to develop a new understanding of church-state relationships and the source of political authority.', u'=== United States ===\n\n\n==== Late 19th century ====\n\nIn the mid 1800s monthly magazines gained popularity.', u'They were general interest to begin, containing some news, vignettes, poems, history, political events, and social discussion.', u'Unlike newspapers, they were more of a monthly record of current events along with entertaining stories, poems, and pictures.', u"The first periodicals to branch out from news were Harper's and The Atlantic, which focused on fostering the arts.", u"Both Harper's and the The Atlantic persist to this day, with Harper's being a cultural magazine and The Atlantic focusing mainly on world events.", u"Early publications of Harper's even held famous works such as early publications of Moby Dick or famous events such as the laying of the world's first trans-Atlantic cable however the majority of early content was trickle down from British events.", u'The development of the magazines stimulated an increase in literary criticism and political debate, moving towards more opinionated pieces from the objective newspapers.', u'The increased time between prints and the greater amount of space to write provided a forum for public arguments by scholars and critical observers.', u'The early periodical predecessors to magazines started to evolve to modern definition in the late 1800s.', u'Works slowly became more specialized and the general discussion or cultural periodicals were forced to adapt to a consumer market which yearned for more localization of issues and events.', u'==== Progressive Era: 1890s-1920s ====\n\nMass circulation magazines became much more common after 1900, some with circulations in the hundreds of thousands of subscribers.', u'Some passed the million-mark in the 1920s.', u'It was an age of Mass media.', u'Thanks to the rapid expansion of national advertising, the cover price fell sharply to about 10 cents.', u'One cause was the heavy coverage of corruption in politics, local government and big business, especially by Muckrakers.', u'They were journalists who wrote for popular magazines to expose social and political sins and shortcomings.', u'They relied on their own investigative journalism reporting; muckrakers often worked to expose social ills and corporate and political corruption.', u"Muckraking magazines\u2013notably McClure's\u2013took on corporate monopolies and crooked political machines while raising public awareness of chronic urban poverty, unsafe working conditions, and social issues like child labor.", u'The journalists who specialized in exposing waste, corruption, and scandal operated at the state and local level, like Ray Stannard Baker, George Creel, and Brand Whitlock.', u"Other like Lincoln Steffens exposed political corruption in many large cities; Ida Tarbell went after John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company.", u"Samuel Hopkins Adams in 1905 showed the fraud involved in many patent medicines, Upton Sinclair's 1906 novel The Jungle gave a horrid portrayal of how meat was packed, and, also in 1906, David Graham Phillips unleashed a blistering indictment of the U.S. Senate.", u'Roosevelt gave these journalists their nickname when he complained they were not being helpful by raking up all the muck.', u'==== 21st century ====\nIn 2011, 152 magazines ceased operations and in 2012, 82 magazines were closed down.', u'Between the years of 2008 to 2015, Oxbridge communications announced that 227 magazines launched and 82 magazines closed in 2012 in North America.', u'Furthermore, according to MediaFinder.com, 93 new magazines launched between the first six months of 2014 and just 30 closed.', u'The category that produced new publications was "Regional interest", six new magazines were launched, including 12th & Broad and Craft Beer & Brewing.', edition.", u'Ladies Home Journal, stopped their monthly schedule and home delivery for subscribers to become a quarterly newsstand-only special interest publication.', u'According to statistics from the end of 2013, subscription levels for 22 of the top 25 magazines declined from 2012 to 2013, with just Time, Glamour and ESPN The Magazine gaining numbers.', u"== Women's magazines ==\n\n\n=== Fashion ===\n\nImmortalized in movies and magazines, young women's fashions of the 1920s set both a trend and social statement, a breaking-off from the rigid Victorian way of life.", u'Their glamorous life style was celebrated in the feature pages and in the advertisements, where they learned the brands that best exemplified the look they sought.', u'These young, rebellious, middle-class women, labeled "flappers by older generations, did away with the corset and donned slinky knee-length dresses, which exposed their legs and arms.', u'The hairstyle of the decade was a chin-length bob, which had several popular variations.', u'Cosmetics, which until the 1920s were not typically accepted in American society because of their association with prostitution, became, for the first time, extremely popular.', u'In the 1920s new magazines appealed to young German women with a sensuous image and advertisements for the appropriate clothes and accessories they would want to purchase.', {'sentences': [u"Gemini 4 (officially Gemini IV) was the second manned space flight in NASA's Project Gemini, occurring in June 1965.", u'It was the tenth manned American spaceflight (including two X-15 flights at altitudes exceeding 100 kilometers (54 nmi)).', u'Astronauts James McDivitt and Edward H. White, II circled the Earth 66 times in four days, making it the first US flight to approach the five-day flight of the Soviet Vostok 5.', u'The highlight of the mission was the first space walk by an American, during which White floated free outside the spacecraft, tethered to it, for approximately 20 minutes.', u"Both of these accomplishments helped the United States overcome the Soviet Union's early lead in the Space Race.", u'The flight also included the first attempt to make a space rendezvous as McDivitt attempted to maneuver his craft close to the Titan II upper stage which launched it into orbit, but this was not successful.', u'The flight was the first American flight to perform many scientific experiments in space, including use of a sextant to investigate the use of celestial navigation for lunar flight in the Apollo program.', u'== Crew ==\n\n\n=== Backup Crew ===\n\n\n=== Support crew ===\nVirgil I.', u'"Gus" Grissom (Houston CAPCOM)\nRoger B. Chaffee (CAPCOM)\nEugene Cernan (CAPCOM)\n\n\n== Mission parameters ==\nMass: 7,880 pounds (3,570 kg)\nPerigee (insertion): 89.5 nautical miles (165.8 km)\nApogee (insertion): 158.6 nautical miles (293.7 km)\nPeriod: 88.94 min\nInclination: 32.53\xb0\nPerigee (last orbit): 81 nautical miles (150 km)\nApogee (last orbit): 125.7 nautical miles (232.8 km)\n\n\n=== Spacewalk ===\nEdward H. White - EVA - June 3, 1965\nHatch opened: 19:34 UTC\nStart EVA: 19:46 UTC\nEnd EVA: 20:06 UTC\nDuration: 20 minutes\nHatch closed: 20:10 UTC\n\n\n== Objectives ==\nGemini 4 would be the first multi-day space flight by the United States, designed to show that it was possible for humans to remain in space for extended lengths of time.', u'The four-day, 66-orbit flight would approach but not break the five-day record set by the Soviet Vostok 5 in June 1963.', u'Subsequent Gemini flights would be longer, to prove endurance exceeding the time required to fly to the Moon and back.', u'A second objective was the first American extra-vehicular activity (EVA), known popularly as a "space walk".', u'The first space walk had already been performed by Soviet Alexei Leonov on Voskhod 2 in March 1965.', u'NASA moved up the spacewalk from the original schedule, to demonstrate that the US was gaining on the early lead taken by the Soviets in what was known as the Space Race.', u'As late as 11 days before the scheduled June 3 launch, newspapers were reporting that NASA was saying it "had not yet determined whether White would be the first American astronaut to expose himself to the elements of space," and that "A decision might not be made until a day or two before launching."', u'A third objective was for Gemini 4 to attempt the first space rendezvous, flying in formation with the spent second stage of its Titan II launch vehicle.', u"== Flight ==\n\n\n=== Launch ===\n\nLaunched from LC-19 at Cape Kennedy Air Force Station, Florida, Gemini 4 was the first flight to be controlled by the new Mission Control Center at the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston, Texas, which had to conduct three-shift operations due to the flight's long duration.", u'The broadcast of the launch was itself historic.', u'For the first time an international audience, from 12 European nations, could watch the lift-off on live television via the Early Bird satellite.', u'Press interest, due to the satellite broadcast and the new center in Houston, proved to be so high that NASA had to lease buildings to accommodate the 1,100 print and broadcast journalists who requested accreditation.', u'Flight control shifted from Cape Kennedy to Houston as soon as the vehicle cleared the launch tower.', u'Except for a few moments of pogo oscillation (axial vibrations in the rocket), the launch came off perfectly, the spacecraft entering into an 87-by-153-nautical-mile (161 by 283 km) orbit.', u'=== Rendezvous attempt ===\nOn the first orbit, McDivitt attempted to rendezvous with the spent Titan second stage.', u'This was unsuccessful for a number of reasons:\nNASA engineers had not yet worked out the idiosyncrasies of orbital mechanics involved in rendezvous, which are counter-intuitive.', u'Simply thrusting the spacecraft toward the target changed its orbital altitude and velocity relative to the target.', u'When McDivitt tried this, he found himself moving away and downward, as the retrograde thrust lowered his orbit, increasing his speed.', u'The stage was dumping its residual propellant, causing it to move around in various directions relative to the Gemini.', u'There were only two running lights on the stage, which made it hard at times for McDivitt to determine its orientation.', u'McDivitt concluded that a rendezvous target should have at least three lights.', u'There was no radar on board Gemini 4 to give a precise range to the target, so the astronauts had to rely on their visual depth perception to estimate the range, and this differed for the two men.', u'Initially McDivitt estimated the distance at 400\u2013500 feet (120\u2013150 m), while White believed it was closer ("a little over 200 feet (61 m)").', u"At the worst point, McDivitt estimated it was about a half mile (800 meters) away, while White's estimate was three-quarters of a mile (1200 meters).", u"McDivitt estimated he was able to get as close as 200 feet (61 m), but now White's estimate was between 850 and 1,000 feet (260 and 300 m).", u'After expending almost half his thruster fuel, McDivitt finally gave up, in order to concentrate on the more important EVA objective.', u'(Rendezvous was finally achieved successfully by Wally Schirra commanding Gemini 6A in December.)', u"After the rendezvous, Gemini 4's orbit was now 89.2 by 155 nautical miles (165.2 by 287.1 km).", u'Twenty-two hours into the mission, Mission Control estimated the orbit would decay to 81 by 125.7 nautical miles (150.0 by 232.8 km) at the end of 63 revolutions.', u'=== Extra-vehicular activity (EVA) ===\n\nOriginally planned for the second revolution, the astronauts postponed the EVA until the third after McDivitt decided that White, following the stress of the launch and the failed rendezvous, looked tired and hot.', u'After a rest, the pair finished performing the checklist for the EVA.', u'Flying over Carnarvon, Australia, they began to depressurize the cabin.', u'Over Hawaii, White pulled the handle to open his hatch, but the latches failed to move.', u'Fortunately, McDivitt knew what the problem was, because the hatch had failed to close in a vacuum chamber test on the ground, after which McDivitt worked with a technician to see what the cause was.', u'A spring, which forced gears to engage in the mechanism, had failed to compress, and McDivitt got to see how the mechanism worked.', u'In flight, he was able to help White get it open, and thought he could get it to latch again.', u'There were communication problems during the spacewalk.', u"Gemini spacecraft were the first to use a voice-operated switch (known as VOX) on the astronaut's microphones, but McDivitt soon realized his VOX circuit wasn't working properly; he could only hear the Capsule Communicator (CAPCOM) in the push-to-talk setting, but not on VOX (though both astronauts could be heard by each other and the ground.)", u'Plus, while outside the spacecraft, White was unable to receive transmissions from the ground and had to have all messages relayed through McDivitt.', u'McDivitt must have switched to the VOX setting somewhere around the time White was exiting the spacecraft, because at that point, for most of the EVA, neither he nor White responded either to the Hawaii CAPCOM, or to the Houston CAPCOM, Gus Grissom.', u'Grissom tried to talk to Gemini 4 a total of 40 times in 13 minutes before he got a response.', u'Tied to a tether, White floated out of the spacecraft, using a Hand-Held Maneuvering Unit (informally called a "zip gun") which expelled pressurized oxygen to provide thrust for controlling his travel.', u'He went fifteen feet (five meters) out, and began to experiment with maneuvering.', u'He found it easy, especially the pitch and yaw, although he thought the roll would use too much gas.', u'He maneuvered around the spacecraft while McDivitt took photographs.', u'White enjoyed the experience, but exhausted the HHMU gas sooner than he would have liked.', u'White was running up against two factors which constrained the time for his EVA: loss of signal from the Bermuda tracking station, and crossing the solar terminator.', u"The flight controllers were becoming increasingly frustrated with their inability to remind White of the time constraint, because they didn't want the first EVA to be performed in darkness, or out of communication with Earth.", u"Finally McDivitt decided to take his microphone off of VOX:\nMcDivitt, to White: I'm going out to PUSH-TO-TALK and see what the Flight Director has got to say.", u'Flight Director Chris Kraft, to Grissom: The flight director says, get back in!', u'(Kraft was not on the air-to-ground loop with the astronauts.)', u'McDivitt: Gus, this is Jim.', u'Got any message for us?', u'Grissom: Gemini 4, get back in!', u'McDivitt: Okay.', u'... (to White): ...', u'They want you to come back in now.', u'White tried to use taking more pictures as an excuse to stay out longer, and McDivitt had to coax him in.', u'He finally came back in after a total of approximately 20 minutes.', u'He said, "It\'s the saddest moment of my life."', u'By the time he got in, the spacecraft had entered darkness.', u'The hatch proved to be as stubborn to relatch as it was to open.', u"This would have been disastrous, resulting in both men's deaths on reentry.", u'But McDivitt was able to fix the mechanism once again, so White could close it.', u"The mission plan called for opening the hatch again to throw out White's now-unnecessary EVA equipment, but McDivitt elected not to do this, instead keeping the unnecessary equipment on board for the rest of the flight.", u"They powered down the spacecraft's maneuvering system, intending to drift for the next two-and-a-half days to conserve the remaining fuel.", u'They also intended to sleep alternate four-hour periods, but this turned out to be extremely difficult with the constant radio communications and the small cabin, about the size of the front seats of a compact car.', u"White's 20-minute space walk was the mission's highlight, with McDivitt's photographs being published worldwide.", u"These also showed White wearing an Omega 'Speedmaster' chronograph watch on his spacesuit sleeve, one of two makes which had been approved by NASA for space use following extensive tests.", u"Omega were unaware of these tests or the fact that their product was going to be used in space, until they saw McDivitt's photos.", u'The model worn during the spacewalk is now known as the "Ed White" by watch collectors.', u'=== Experiments ===\nEleven experiments were carried on the spacecraft:\nExperiment D-8 used five dosimeters to measure the radiation in the spacecraft environment.', u'Of particular interest was the South Atlantic Anomaly.', u'Experiment D-9 was an experiment in simple spacecraft navigation where the crew used a sextant to measure their position using the stars.', u'The objective was to investigate the feasibility of using this technique for lunar flights on the Apollo program.', u'Experiments S-5 and S-6 were both photography experiments where they used a 70-millimeter Hasselblad camera to photograph the weather and terrain below them.', u'There were two medical experiments: M-3 and M-4.', u'The first was a bungee cord that the crew used for exercise.', u'They said, after the mission, that this got harder as the mission went on, though this may have been due to a lack of sleep.', u'The second was the phonocardiogram experiment, which had sensors attached to their bodies that measured heartbeat rates, especially during liftoff, EVA, and reentry.', u'There were four engineering experiments:\nMSC-1 measured the electrostatic charge in the spacecraft,\nMSC-2 was a proton-electron spectrometer,\nMSC-3 was a tri-axis magnetometer and\nMSC-10 involved the crew photographing the red-blue Earth limb.', u'=== Reentry ===\n\nThe computer failed on the 48th revolution.', u'This was unfortunate for IBM which had just put an advertisement in the Wall Street Journal saying that its computers were so reliable that even NASA used them.', u'The computer failure meant that the capsule would not be able to perform a closed-loop lifting reentry as planned.', u'Reentry came on the 62nd revolution.', u'An open-loop rolling reentry (as used in Mercury) had to be used because of the computer failure.', u'The astronauts began rolling the spacecraft at 65 nautical miles (120 km) altitude to increase its stability.', u'They started slowing the roll rate at 89,000 feet (27 km) and stopped it by 39,000 feet (12 km).', u'The drogue parachute deployed shortly after this, and the main deployed at 10,600 feet (3.2 km).', u'A malfunctioning thruster caused the roll to be much faster than planned, and the landing was rough.', u"Neither of the crew encountered any problems, however, contrary to NASA doctors' concerns about their landing upright \u2014 as opposed to on their backs, as in Mercury \u2014 after four days in space.", u'Even though they landed 43 nautical miles (80 km) short of the intended landing target, some ships had already started steaming to the touchdown point and a helicopter was able to see them land.', u'The prime recovery ship was USS Wasp.', u'The recovery was supported by 10,249 U.S. Department of Defense personnel, 134 aircraft, and 26 ships.', u"== Insignia ==\n\nGemini 4's crew originally intended to call their spacecraft American Eagle, but this was rejected after NASA management issued a memo saying that they did not want a repeat performance of the previous mission, on which Gus Grissom had named his spacecraft Molly Brown.", u'The callsign for the mission became simply Gemini 4.', u"There was no patch flown on the crew's suits, although the one shown here, created after the fact, is on display in McDivitt's museum.", u'Since McDivitt and White were prohibited from naming their spacecraft, they decided to put the American flag on their suits, the first astronauts to do so, although Soviet crews wore the Cyrillic "\u0421\u0421\u0421\u0420" on their spacesuit helmets.', u'Previous astronauts had only had the NASA insignia and a strip with their name on their suits.', u'The flight was commemorated on a pair of US postage stamps in 1967.', u'== Spacecraft location ==\nThe spacecraft is on permanent display at the National Air and Space Museum, Washington, D.C.\n\n\n== See also
