Little Brown and Company\nSeidman, David, The Complete Sailor, International Marine, 1995\nJobson, Gary, Sailing Fundamentals, Simon & Schuster, 1987'], 'year': '1952-06-14', 'title': 'Keel laid for 1st nuclear powered sub the Nautilus'}
{'sentences': [u'In baseball, a home run (abbreviated HR, also "homer", "dinger", "dong", "bomb", "blast", "goner" , "shot", or "four-bagger") is scored when the ball is hit in such a way that the batter is able to circle the bases and reach home safely in one play without any errors being committed by the defensive team in the process.', u'In modern baseball, the feat is typically achieved by hitting the ball over the outfield fence between the foul poles (or making contact with either foul pole) without first touching the ground, resulting in an automatic home run.', u'There is also the "inside-the-park" home run, increasingly rare in modern baseball, where the batter reaches home safely while the baseball is in play on the field.', u'When a home run is scored, the batter is also credited with a hit and a run scored, and an RBI for each runner that scores, including himself.', u'Likewise, the pitcher is recorded as having given up a hit, and a run for each runner that scores including the batter.', u'Homeruns are among the most popular aspects of baseball and, as a result, prolific home run hitters are usually the most popular among fans and consequently the highest paid by teams\u2014hence the old saying, variously attributed to slugger Ralph Kiner, or to a teammate talking about Kiner, "Home run hitters drive Cadillacs, and singles hitters drive Fords."', u'== Types of home runs ==\n\n\n=== Out of the park ===\n\nIn modern times a home run is most often scored when the ball is hit over the outfield wall between the foul poles (in fair territory) before it touches the ground (in flight), and without being caught or deflected back onto the field by a fielder.', u'A batted ball is also a home run if it touches either foul pole or its attached screen before touching the ground, as the foul poles are by definition in fair territory.', u'Furthermore, many major-league ballparks have ground rules stating that a batted ball striking specific architectural features while in flight is a home run due to their location beyond the outfield wall.', u'A batted ball that goes over the outfield wall after touching the ground is not a home run, but an automatic double for the batter (often colloqually called a "ground rule double").', u'A fielder is allowed to reach over the wall to attempt to catch the ball as long as his feet are on or over the field during the attempt.', u'If the fielder successfully catches the ball while it is in flight the batter is out, even if the ball has already passed the vertical plane of the wall.', u'However, since the fielder is not part of the field, a ball that bounces off a fielder and over the wall without touching the ground is still a home run.', u"A fielder may not deliberately throw his glove, cap, or any other equipment or apparel to stop or deflect a fair ball, and an umpire may award a home run to the batter if a fielder does so on a ball that, in the umpire's judgment, would have otherwise been a home run (this is rare in modern professional baseball).", u'A home run accomplished in any of the above manners is an automatic home run.', u'The ball is dead, even if it rebounds onto the field from striking a foul pole or an object beyond the outfield wall, and the batter and any preceding runners cannot be put out at any time while running the bases.', u"However, if one or more runners fail to touch a base or one runner passes another before reaching home plate, that runner or runners can be called out on appeal, though in the case of not touching a base a runner can go back and touch it if doing so won't cause them to be passed by another preceding runner and they have not yet touched the next base (or home plate in the case of missing third base).", u'This stipulation is in Approved Ruling (2) of Rule 7.10(b).', u'=== Inside-the-park home run ===\n\nAn inside-the-park home run occurs when a batter hits the ball into play and is able to circle the bases before the fielders can put him out.', u'Unlike with an outside-the-park home run, the batter-runner and all preceding runners are liable to be put out by the defensive team at any time while running the bases.', u'This can only happen if the ball does not leave the ballfield.', u'In the early days of baseball, outfields were relatively much more spacious, reducing the likelihood of an over-the-fence home run, while increasing the likelihood of an inside-the-park home run, as a ball getting past an outfielder had more distance that it could roll before a fielder could track it down.', u"With outfields much less spacious and more uniformly designed than in the game's early days, inside-the-park home runs are now a rarity.", u'They are usually the result of a ball being hit by a very fast runner, coupled with an outfielder either misjudging the flight of the ball (e.g., diving and missing) or the ball taking an unexpected bounce.', u'Either way, this sends the ball into open space in the outfield and thereby allows the batter-runner to circle the bases before the defensive team can put him out.', u'The speed of the runner is crucial as even triples are relatively rare in most modern ballparks.', u'If any defensive play on an inside-the-park home run is labeled an error by the official scorer, a home run is not scored; instead, it is scored as a single, double, or triple, and the batter-runner and any applicable preceding runners are said to have taken all additional bases on error.', u'All runs scored on such a play, however, still count.', u'An example of an unexpected bounce occurred during the 2007 Major League Baseball All-Star Game at AT&T Park in San Francisco on July 10, 2007.', u'Ichiro Suzuki of the American League team hit a fly ball off the right-center field wall, which caromed in the opposite direction from where National League right fielder Ken Griffey, Jr. was expecting it to go.', u'By the time the ball was relayed, Ichiro had already crossed the plate standing up.', u"This was the first inside-the-park home run in All-Star Game history, and led to Suzuki being named the game's Most Valuable Player.", u'== Number of runs batted in ==\nHome runs are often characterized by the number of runners on base at the time.', u'A home run hit with the bases empty is seldom called a "one-run homer", but rather a solo home run, solo homer, or "solo shot".', u'With one runner on base, two runs are scored (the baserunner and the batter) and thus the home run is often called a two-run homer or two-run shot.', u'Similarly, a home runs with two runners on base is a three-run homer or three-run shot.', u'The term "four-run homer" is seldom used; instead, it is nearly always called a "grand slam".', u"Hitting a grand slam is the best possible result for the batter's turn at bat and the worst possible result for the pitcher and his team.", u'=== Grand slam ===\n\nA grand slam occurs when the bases are "loaded" (that is, there are base runners standing at first, second, and third base) and the batter hits a home run.', u'According to The Dickson Baseball Dictionary, the term originated in the card game of contract bridge.', u'An inside-the-park grand slam is a grand slam that is also an inside-the-park home run, a home run without the ball leaving the field, and it is very rare, due to the relative rarity of loading the bases along with the significant rarity (nowadays) of inside-the-park home runs.', u'On July 25, 1956, Roberto Clemente became the only MLB player to have ever scored a walk-off inside-the-park grand slam in a 9\u20138 Pittsburgh Pirates win over the Chicago Cubs, at Forbes Field.', u'On April 23, 1999, Fernando Tat\xeds made history by hitting two grand slams in one inning, both against Chan Ho Park of the Los Angeles Dodgers.', u'With this feat, Tat\xeds also set a Major League record with 8 RBI in one inning.', u'On July 29, 2003 against the Texas Rangers, Bill Mueller of the Boston Red Sox became the only player in major league history to hit two grand slams in one game from opposite sides of the plate.', u'In fact, he hit three home runs in that game, and his two grand slams were in consecutive at-bats.', u"On August 25, 2011 the New York Yankees became the first team to hit three grand slams in one game vs the Oakland A's.", u'The Yankees eventually went on to win the game 22\u20139, after trailing 7\u20131.', u'== Specific situation home runs ==\nThese types of home runs are characterized by the specific game situation in which they occur, and can theoretically occur on either an outside-the-park or inside-the-park home run.', u'=== Walk-off home run ===\n\nA walk-off home run is a home run hit by the home team in the bottom of the ninth inning, any extra inning, or other scheduled final inning, which gives the home team the lead and thereby ends the game.', u'The term is attributed to Hall of Fame relief pitcher Dennis Eckersley, so named because after the run is scored, the losing team has to "walk off" the field.', u'Two World Series have ended via the "walk-off" home run.', u'The first was the 1960 World Series when Bill Mazeroski of the Pittsburgh Pirates hit a 9th inning solo home run in the 7th game of the series off New York Yankees pitcher Ralph Terry to give the Pirates the World Championship.', u'The second time was the 1993 World Series when Joe Carter of the Toronto Blue Jays hit a 9th inning 3-run home run off Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Mitch Williams in Game 6 of the series, to help the Toronto Blue Jays capture their second World Series Championship in a row.', u'Such a home run can also be called a "sudden death" or "sudden victory" home run.', u'That usage has lessened as "walk-off home run" has gained favor.', u'Along with Mazeroski\'s 1960 shot, the most famous walk-off or sudden-death homer would probably be the "Shot Heard \'Round the World" hit by Bobby Thomson to win the 1951 National League pennant for the New York Giants.', u"A walk-off home run over the fence is an exception to baseball's one-run rule.", u'Normally if the home team is tied or behind in the ninth or extra innings the game ends as soon as the home team scores enough runs to achieve a lead.', u'If the home team has two outs in the inning, and the game is tied, the game will officially end either the moment the batter successfully reaches 1st base or the moment the runner touches home plate\u2014whichever happens last.', u'However, this is superseded by the "ground rule", which provides automatic doubles (when a ball-in-play hits the ground first then leaves the playing field) and home runs (when a ball-in-play leaves the playing field without ever touching the ground).', u'In the latter case, all base runners including the batter are allowed to cross the plate.', u'=== Lead-off home run ===\nA lead-off home run is a home run hit by the first batter of a team, the leadoff hitter of the first inning of the game.', u'In MLB, Rickey Henderson holds the record with 81 lead-off home runs.', u'Craig Biggio holds the National League record with 53, second overall to Henderson.', u'In 1996, Brady Anderson set a Major League record by hitting a lead-off home run in four consecutive games.', u'=== Back-to-back ===\nWhen two consecutive batters each hit a home run, this is described as back-to-back home runs.', u'It is still considered back-to-back even if both batters hit their home runs off different pitchers.', u'A third batter hitting a home run is commonly referred to as back-to-back-to-back, the most recent occurrence on opening day, April 4, 2016 when Denard Span, Joe Panik and Buster Posey of the San Francisco Giants hit back-to-back-to-back home runs off Ariel Pena of the Milwaukee Brewers.', u'Four home runs in a row by consecutive batters has only occurred eight times in the history of Major League Baseball.', u'Following convention, this is called back-to-back-to-back-to-back.', u'The most recent occurrence was on August 11, 2010, when the Arizona Diamondbacks hit four in a row against the Milwaukee Brewers in Miller Park as Adam LaRoche, Miguel Montero, Mark Reynolds and Stephen Drew homered off pitcher Dave Bush.', u'Bush became the third pitcher to surrender back-to-back-to-back-to-back home runs, following Paul Foytack on July 31, 1963 and Chase Wright on April 22, 2007.', u'On August 14, 2008, the Chicago White Sox defeated the Kansas City Royals 9-2.', u'In this game, Jim Thome, Paul Konerko, Alexei Ram\xedrez, and Juan Uribe hit back-to-back-to-back-to-back home runs in that order.', u'Thome, Konerko, and Ramirez blasted their homers off of Joel Peralta, while Uribe did it off of Rob Tejeda.', u'The next batter, veteran backstop Toby Hall, tried aimlessly to hit the ball as far as possible, but his effort resulted in a strike out.', u'On April 22, 2007 the Boston Red Sox were trailing the New York Yankees 3\u20130 when Manny Ramirez, J. back-to-back home runs are a relatively frequent occurrence.', u'If a pitcher gives up a homer, he might have his concentration broken and might alter his normal approach in an attempt to "make up for it" by striking out the next batter with some fastballs.', u'Sometimes the next batter will be expecting that and will capitalize on it.', u'A notable back-to-back home run of that type in World Series play involved "Babe Ruth\'s called shot" in 1932, which was accompanied by various Ruthian theatrics, yet the pitcher, Charlie Root, was allowed to stay in the game.', u'He delivered just one more pitch, which Lou Gehrig drilled out of the park for a back-to-back shot, after which Root was removed from the game.', u'In Game 3 of the 1976 NLCS, George Foster and Johnny Bench hit instance.', u'=== Consecutive home runs by one batter ===\nThe occurrence of individuals hitting home runs in consecutive at-bats is not unusual, but three or more is rare.', u'If a player hits three home runs in a game, it is termed a hat-trick (which is also used for a player getting three strikeouts in a game).', u'The record for consecutive home runs by a batter under any circumstances is 4.', u'Of the sixteen players (through 2012) who have hit 4 in one game, six have hit them consecutively.', u'Twenty-eight other batters have hit four consecutive across two games.', u'Bases on balls do not count as at-bats, and Ted Williams holds the record for consecutive home runs across the most games, 4 in four games played, during September 17\u201322, 1957, for the Red Sox.', u'Williams hit a pinch-hit homer on the 17th; walked as a pinch-hitter on the 18th; there was no game on the 19th; hit another pinch-homer on the 20th; homered and then was lifted for a pinch-runner after at least one walk, on the 21st; and homered after at least one walk on the 22nd.', u'All in all, he had 4 walks interspersed among his 4 homers.', u'In World Series play, Reggie Jackson hit a record three in one Series game, the final game (Game 6) in 1977.', u'But those three were a part of a much more impressive feat.', u'He walked on four pitches in the second inning of game 6.', u'Then he hit his three home runs on the first pitch of his next three at bats, off of three different pitchers (4th inning- Hooten, 5th inning- Sosa, 8th inning- Hough).', u'He had also hit one in his last at bat of the previous game, giving him four home runs on four consecutive swings.', u'(His home run in game 5 was also hit on the first pitch, although this did not add to any significant streak.)', u'The four in a row set the record for consecutive homers across two Series games.', u'In Game 3 of the World Series in 2011, Albert Pujols hit three home runs to tie the record with Babe Ruth and Reggie Jackson.', u'The St. Louis Cardinals went on to win the World Series in Game 7 at Busch Stadium.', u'In Game 1 of the World Series in 2012, Pablo Sandoval of the San Francisco Giants hit three home runs on his first three at-bats of the Series, also tying the record with Pujols, Jackson, and Ruth.', u'Nomar Garciaparra holds the record for consecutive home runs in the shortest time in terms of innings: 3 homers in 2 innings, on July 23, 2002, for the Boston Red Sox.', u'=== Home run cycle ===\n\nAn offshoot of hitting for the cycle, a "home run cycle" is where a player hits a solo, 2-run, 3-run, and grand slam home run all in one game.', u'This is an extremely rare feat, as it requires the batter to not only hit four home runs in a game (which itself has only occurred 16 times in the Major Leagues), but also to hit those home runs with the specific number of runners already on base.', u"Although it is a rare accomplishment, it is largely dependent on circumstances outside the player's control, such as his preceding teammates' ability to get on base, as well as the order in which he comes to bat in any particular inning.", u'Another variant of the home run cycle would be the "natural home run cycle", which would require a batter to hit a solo, 2-run, 3-run, and grand slam home run in that order.', u'Though multiple home run cycles have been recorded in collegiate baseball, the only home run cycle in a professional baseball game belongs to Tyrone Horne, who stroked four long balls for the minor league, Double-A Arkansas Travelers in a game against the San Antonio Missions on July 27, 1998.', u'On May 20, 1998, the Triple-A Indianapolis Indians performed a feat possibly never before duplicated in professional baseball.', u'In the fifth inning of a game against the Pawtucket Red Sox, Indianapolis players hit for a "Homer Cycle".', u'Pete Rose, Jr. opened the inning with a solo home run, Jason Williams connected for a 3-run shot, Glenn Murray slugged a grand slam, and Guillermo Garcia finished the scoring with a 2-run blast.', u'The Indians won the game 11\u20134.', u'A major league player has come close to hitting for the home run cycle several times.', u'Recent examples include:\nApril 2, 1997, Tino Martinez of the New York Yankees, was a grand slam away from accomplishing this feat against his former team, the Seattle Mariners.', u'He hit 2015, Jarrett Parker of the San Francisco Giants hit three home runs against the Oakland Athletics: a solo home run in the second inning, a 2-run home run in the seventh inning, and a grand slam in the eighth inning.', u'== History of the home run ==\nIn the early days of the game, when the ball was less lively and the ballparks generally had very large outfields, most home runs were of the inside-the-park variety.', u'The first home run ever hit in the National League was by Ross Barnes of the Chicago White Stockings (now known as the Chicago Cubs), in 1876.', u'The home "run" was literally descriptive.', u'Home runs over the fence were rare, and only in ballparks where a fence was fairly close.', u'Hitters were discouraged from trying to hit home runs, with the conventional wisdom being that if they tried to do so they would simply fly out.', u"This was a serious concern in the 19th century, because in baseball's early days a ball caught after one bounce was still an out.", u'The emphasis was on place-hitting and what is now called "manufacturing runs" or "small ball".', u"The home run's place in baseball changed dramatically when the live-ball era began after World War I.", u'First, the materials and manufacturing processes improved significantly, making the now-mass-produced, cork-centered ball somewhat more lively.', u'Batters such as Babe Ruth and Rogers Hornsby took full advantage of rules changes that were instituted during the 1920s, particularly prohibition of the spitball, and the requirement that balls be replaced when worn or dirty.', u'These changes resulted in the baseball being easier to see and hit, and easier to hit out of the park.', u"Meanwhile, as the game's popularity boomed, more outfield seating was built, shrinking the size of the outfield and increasing the chances of a long fly ball resulting in a home run.", u'The teams with the sluggers, typified by the New York Yankees, became the championship teams, and other teams had to change their focus from the "inside game" to the "power game" in order to keep up.', u'Before 1931, a ball that bounced over an outfield fence during a major league game was considered a home run.', u'The rule was changed to require the ball to clear the fence on the fly, and balls that reached the seats on a bounce became ground rule doubles in most parks.', u'A carryover of the old rule is that if a player deflects a ball over the outfield fence without it touching the ground, it is a home run.', u'Also, until approximately that time, the ball had to not only go over the fence in fair territory, but to land in the bleachers in fair territory or to still be visibly fair when disappearing behind a wall.', u'The rule stipulated "fair when last seen" by the umpires.', u'Photos from that era in ballparks, such as the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium, show ropes strung from the foul poles to the back of the bleachers, or a second "foul pole" at the back of the bleachers, in a straight line with the foul line, as a visual aid for the umpire.', u'Ballparks still use a visual aid much like the ropes; a net or screen attached to the foul poles on the fair side has replaced ropes.', u'As with American football, where a touchdown once required a literal "touch down" of the ball in the end zone but now only requires the "breaking of the [vertical] plane" of the goal line, in baseball the ball need only "break the plane" of the fence in fair territory (unless the ball is caught by a player who is in play, in which case the batter is called out).', u"Babe Ruth's 60th home run in 1927 was somewhat controversial, because it landed barely in fair territory in the stands down the right field line.", u'Ruth lost a number of home runs in his career due to the when-last-seen rule.', u'Bill Jenkinson, in The Year Babe Ruth Hit 104 Home Runs, estimates that Ruth lost at least 50 and as many as 78 in his career due to this rule.', u'Further, the rules once stipulated that an over-the-fence home run in a sudden-victory situation would only count for as many bases as was necessary to "force" the winning run home.', u'For example, if a team trailed by two runs with the bases loaded, and the batter hit a fair ball over the fence, it only counted as a triple, because the runner immediately ahead of him had technically already scored the game-winning run.', u'That rule was changed in the 1920s as home runs became increasingly frequent and popular.', u"Babe Ruth's career total of 714 would have been one higher had that rule not been in effect in the early part of his career.", u'Major League Baseball keeps running totals of all-time home runs by team, including teams no longer active (prior to 1900) as well as by individual players.', u'Gary Sheffield hit the 250,000th home run in MLB history with a grand slam on September 8, 2008.', u"Sheffield had hit MLB's 249,999th home run against Gio Gonzalez in his previous at-bat.", u'The all-time, verified professional baseball record for career home runs for one player, excluding the U. S. Negro Leagues during the era of segregation, is held by Sadaharu Oh.', u"Oh spent his entire career playing for the Yomiuri Giants in Japan's Nippon Professional Baseball, later managing the Giants, the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks and the 2006 World Baseball Classic Japanese team.", u'Oh holds the all-time home run world record, having hit 868 home runs in his career.', u"In Major League Baseball, the career record is 762, held by Barry Bonds, who broke Hank Aaron's record on August 7, 2007, when he hit his 756th home run at AT&T Park off pitcher Mike Bacsik.", u'Only seven other major league players have hit as many as 600: Hank Aaron (755), Babe Ruth (714), Alex Rodriguez (696), Willie Mays (660), Ken Griffey, Jr. (630), Jim Thome (612) and Sammy Sosa (609).', u'The single season record is 73, set by Barry Bonds in 2001.', u'Other notable single season records were achieved by Babe Ruth who hit 60 in 1927, Roger Maris, with 61 home runs in 1961, and Mark McGwire, who hit 70 in 1998.', u'Negro League slugger Josh Gibson\'s Baseball Hall of Fame plaque says he hit "almost 800" home runs in his career.', u"The Guinness Book of World Records lists Gibson's lifetime home run total at 800.", u"Ken Burns' award-winning series, Baseball, states that his actual total may have been as high as 950.", u"Gibson's true total is not known, in part due to inconsistent record keeping in the Negro Leagues.", u'The 1993 edition of the MacMillan Baseball Encyclopedia attempted to compile a set of Negro League records, and subsequent work has expanded on that effort.', u'Those records demonstrate that Gibson and Ruth were of comparable power.', u'The 1993 book had Gibson hitting 146 home runs in the 501 "official" Negro League games they were able to account for in his 17-year career, about 1 homer every 3.4 games.', u'Babe Ruth, in 22 seasons (several of them in the dead-ball era), hit 714 in 2503 games, or 1 homer every 3.5 games.', u'The large gap in the numbers for Gibson reflect the fact that Negro League clubs played relatively far fewer league games and many more "barnstorming" or exhibition games during the course of a season, than did the major league clubs of that era.', u'Other legendary home run hitters include Jimmie Foxx, Mel Ott, Ted Williams, Mickey Mantle (who on September 10, 1960, mythically hit "the longest home run ever" at an estimated distance of 643 feet (196 m), although this was measured after the ball stopped rolling), Reggie Jackson, Harmon Killebrew, Ernie Banks, Mike Schmidt, Dave Kingman, Sammy Sosa (who hit 60 or more home runs in a season 3 times), Ken Griffey, Jr. and Eddie Mathews.', u'In 1987, Joey Meyer of the Denver Zephyrs hit the longest verifiable home run in professional baseball history.', u"The home run was measured at a distance of 582 feet (177 m) and was hit inside Denver's Mile High Stadium.", u"Major League Baseball's longest verifiable home run distance is about 575 feet (175 m), by Babe Ruth, to straightaway center field at Tiger Stadium (then called Navin Field and before the double-deck), which landed nearly across the intersection of Trumbull and Cherry.", u"The location of where Hank Aaron's record 755th home run landed has been monumented in Milwaukee.", u'The hallowed spot sits outside Miller Park, where the Milwaukee Brewers currently play.', u"Similarly, the point where Aaron's 715th homer landed, upon breaking Ruth's career record in 1974, is marked in the Turner Field parking lot.", u"A red-painted seat in Fenway Park marks the landing place of the 502-ft home run Ted Williams hit in 1946, the longest measured homer in Fenway's history; a red stadium seat mounted on the wall of the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minnesota, marks the landing spot of Harmon Killebrew's record 520-foot shot in old Metropolitan Stadium.", u'== Instant replay ==\n\nReplays "to get the call right" have been used extremely sporadically in the past, but the use of instant replay to determine "boundary calls"\u2014home runs and foul balls\u2014was not officially allowed until 2008.', u'In a game on May 31, 1999, involving the St. Louis Cardinals and Florida Marlins, a hit by Cliff Floyd of the Marlins was initially ruled a double, then a home run, then was changed back to a double when umpire Frank Pulli decided to review video of the play.', u'The Marlins protested that video replay was not allowed, but while the National League office agreed that replay was not to be used in future games, it declined the protest on the grounds it was a judgment call, and the play stood.', u'In November 2007, the general managers of Major League Baseball voted in favor of implementing instant replay reviews on boundary home run calls.', u'The proposal limited the use of instant replay to determining whether a boundary/home run call is:\nA fair (home run) or foul ball\nA live ball (ball hit fence and rebounded onto the field), ground rule double (ball hit fence before leaving the field), or home run (ball hit some object beyond the fence while in flight)\nSpectator interference or home run (spectator touched ball after it broke the plane of the fence).', u'On August 28, 2008, instant replay review became available in MLB for reviewing calls in accordance with the above proposal.', u'It was first utilized on September 3, 2008 in a game between the New York Yankees and the Tampa Bay Rays at Tropicana Field.', u'Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees hit what appeared to be a home run, but the ball hit a catwalk behind the foul pole.', u'It was at first called a home run, until Tampa Bay manager Joe Maddon argued the call, and the umpires decided to review the play.', u'After 2 minutes and 15 seconds, the umpires came back and ruled it a home run.', u'About two weeks later, on September 19, also at Tropicana Field, a boundary call was overturned for the first time.', u'In this case, Carlos Pe\xf1a of the Rays was given a ground rule double in a game against the Minnesota Twins after an umpire believed a fan reached into the field of play to catch a fly ball in right field.', u'The umpires reviewed the play, determined the fan did not reach over the fence, and reversed the call, awarding Pe\xf1a a home run.', u'Aside from the two aforementioned reviews at Tampa Bay, replay was used four more times in the 2008 MLB regular season: twice at Houston, once at Seattle, and once at San Francisco.', u'The San Francisco incident is perhaps the most unusual.', u"Bengie Molina, the Giants' catcher, hit what was first called a single.", u'Molina then was replaced in the game by Emmanuel Burriss, a pinch-runner, before the umpires re-evaluated the call and ruled it a home run.', u'In this instance though, Molina was not allowed to return to the game to complete the run, as he had already been replaced.', u'Molina was credited with the home run, and two RBIs, but not for the run scored which went to Burriss instead.', u'On October 31, 2009, in the fourth inning of Game 3 of the World Series, Alex Rodriguez hit a long fly ball that appeared to hit a camera protruding over the wall and into the field of play in deep left field.', u'The ball ricocheted off the camera and re-entered the field, initially ruled a double.', u'However, after the umpires consulted with each other after watching the instant replay, the hit was ruled a home run, marking the first time an instant replay home run was hit in a playoff game.', u"== See also ==\n\nList of Major League Baseball annual home run leaders (by year)\nMajor League Baseball {'sentences': [u'The Boston Red Sox are an American professional baseball team based in Boston, Massachusetts.', u'The Red Sox compete in Major League Baseball (MLB) as a member club of the American League (AL) East division.', u'The Red Sox have won eight World Series championships and have played in 12.', u"Founded in 1901 as one of the American League's eight charter franchises, the Red Sox' home ballpark has been Fenway Park since 1912.", u'The "Red Sox" name was chosen by the team owner, John I. Taylor, around 1908, following the lead of previous teams that had been known as the "Boston Red Stockings", including the forerunner of the Atlanta Braves.', u'Boston was a dominant team in the new league, defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates in the first World Series in 1903 and winning four more championships by 1918.', u'However, they then went into one of the longest championship droughts in baseball history, dubbed the "Curse of the Bambino" after its alleged beginning with the Red Sox\' sale of Babe Ruth to the rival New York Yankees two years after their world championship in 1918, an 86-year wait before the team\'s sixth World Championship in 2004.', u'The team\'s history during that period was punctuated with some of the most memorable moments in World Series history, including Enos Slaughter\'s "mad dash" in 1946, the "Impossible Dream" of 1967, Carlton Fisk\'s home run in 1975, and Bill Buckner\'s error in 1986.', u'Following their victory in the 2013 World Series, they became the first team to win three World Series trophies in the 21st century, including championships in 2004 and 2007.', u"Red Sox history has also been marked by the team's intense rivalry with the Yankees, arguably the fiercest and most historic in North American professional sports.", u'The Boston Red Sox are owned by Fenway Sports Group, which also owns the Liverpool F.C.', u'of the Premier League in England.', u'The Red Sox are consistently one of the top MLB teams in average road attendance, while the small capacity of Fenway Park prevents them from leading in overall attendance.', u'From May 15, 2003 to April 10, 2013, the Red Sox sold out every home game\u2014a total of 820 games (794 regular season) for a major professional sports record.', u'Neil Diamond\'s "Sweet Caroline" has become an anthem for the Red Sox.', u'== Nickname ==\nThe name Red Sox, chosen by owner John I. Taylor after the 1907 season, refers to the red hose in the team uniform beginning 1908.', u'Sox had been previously adopted for the Chicago White Sox by newspapers needing a headline-friendly form of Stockings, as "Stockings Win!"', u'in large type would not fit on a page.', u'The team name "Red Sox" had previously been used as early as 1888 by a \'colored\' team from Norfolk, Virginia.', u'The Spanish language media sometimes refers to the team as Medias Rojas, a translation of "red socks".', u'The official Spanish site uses the variant "Los Red Sox".', u'The Red Stockings nickname was first used by a baseball team by the Cincinnati Red Stockings, who were members of the pioneering National Association of Base Ball Players.', u'Managed by Harry Wright, Cincinnati adopted a uniform with white knickers and red stockings and earned the famous nickname, a year or two before hiring the first fully professional team in 1869.', u'When the club folded after the 1870 season, Wright was hired by Boston businessman Ivers Whitney Adams to organize a new team in Boston, and he did, bringing three teammates and the "Red Stockings" nickname along (Most nicknames were then only nicknames, neither club names nor registered trademarks, so the migration was informal).', u'The Boston Red Stockings won four championships in the five seasons of the new National Association, the first professional league.', u'When a new Cincinnati club was formed as a charter member of the National League in 1876, the "Red Stockings" nickname was commonly reserved for them once again, and the Boston team was referred to as the "Red Caps".', u'Other names were sometimes used before Boston officially adopted the nickname "Braves" in 1912; the club eventually left Boston for Milwaukee and is now playing in Atlanta, Georgia.', u'In 1901, the upstart American League established a competing club in Boston.', u'(Originally, a team was supposed to be started in Buffalo, but league ownership at the last minute removed that city from their plans in favor of the expansion Boston franchise.)', u'For seven seasons, the AL team wore dark blue stockings and had no official nickname.', u'They were simply "Boston", "Bostonians" or "the Bostons"; or the "Americans" or "Boston Americans" as in "American Leaguers", Boston being a two-team city.', u'Their 1901\u20131907 jerseys, both home, and road, just read "Boston", except for 1902 when they sported large letters "B" and "A" denoting "Boston" and "American."', u'Newspaper writers of the time used other nicknames for the club, including "Somersets" (for owner Charles Somers), "Plymouth Rocks", "Beaneaters", the "Collinsites" (for manager Jimmy Collins)", and "Pilgrims."', u'For years many sources have listed "Pilgrims" as the early Boston AL team\'s official nickname, but researcher Bill Nowlin has demonstrated that the name was barely used, if at all, during the team\'s early years.', u'The origin of the nickname appears to be a poem entitled "The Pilgrims At Home" written by Edwin Fitzwilliam that was sung at the 1907 home opener ("Rory O\'More" melody).', u'This nickname was commonly used during that season, perhaps because the team had a new manager and several rookie players.', u'John I. Taylor had said in December 1907 that the Pilgrims "sounded too much like homeless wanderers."', u'The National League club in Boston, though seldom called the "Red Stockings" anymore, still wore red trim.', u'In 1907, the National League club adopted an all-white uniform, and the American League team saw an opportunity.', u'On December 18, 1907, Taylor announced that the club had officially adopted red as its new team color.', u'The 1908 uniforms featured a large icon of a red stocking angling across the shirt front.', u'For 1908, the National League club returned to wearing red trim, but the American League team finally had an official nickname, and would remain the "Red Sox" for good.', u'The name is often shortened to "Bosox" or "BoSox", a combination of "Boston" and "Sox" (similar to the "ChiSox" in Chicago or the minor league "PawSox" of Pawtucket).', u'Sportswriters sometimes refer to the Red Sox as the Crimson Hose and the Olde Towne Team.', u'Recently, media have begun to call them the "Sawx" casually, reflecting how the word is pronounced with a New England accent.', u'However, most fans simply refer to the team as the "Sox" when the context is understood to mean Red Sox.', u'The formal name of the entity which owns the team is "Boston Red Sox Baseball Club Limited Partnership".', u'The name shown on the door on Yawkey Way, "Boston American League Baseball Company", as shown in this current-day photograph of the street-door to the stadium, is historical, predating the formation of the limited partnership on May 26, 1978.', u"The entrance also figures in Robert B. Parker's Spenser-and-baseball novel Mortal Stakes.", u'== History ==\n\n\n=== 1901\u20131919 ===\n\nIn 1901, the minor Western League, led by Ban Johnson, declared its equality with the National League, then the only major league in baseball.', u'Johnson changed the name of the league to the American League, leading teams in his league to be christened with the unofficial nickname "Americans".', u'This was especially true in the case of the new Boston franchise, which would not adopt an official nickname until 1908.', u'The upstart league placed franchises in Baltimore, Maryland and Buffalo.', u"After looking at his new league, Ban Johnson decided that he would need a team in Boston to compete with the National League team there, and so cancelled the Buffalo club's franchise, offering one to a new club in Boston.", u'The Boston franchise was purchased in 1903 by Milwaukee publisher, George Brumder who sold the team one year later.', u'Playing their home games at Huntington Avenue Grounds, the Boston franchise finished second and third before capturing their first pennant in 1903 and repeating the next year.', u"Those teams were led by manager and star third baseman Jimmy Collins, outfielders Chick Stahl, Buck Freeman, and Patsy Dougherty, and pitcher Cy Young, who in 1901 won the pitching Triple Crown with 33 wins (41.8% of the team's 79 games), 1.62 ERA and 158 strikeouts.", u'His 1901 to 1904 seasons rank among the best four-year runs ever.', u'In 1903, Boston participated in the first modern World Series, going up against the Pittsburgh Pirates.', u'The Pirates were heavily favored as they had won the NL pennant by 6\xbd games.', u'Aided by the modified chants of "Tessie" by the Royal Rooters fan club and by its stronger pitching staff, the Americans managed to overcome the odds, and win the best-of-nine series five games to three.', u'The 1904 club was almost as good as the previous team, but due to the surprise emergence of the New York Highlanders, the Boston club found itself in a tight pennant race through the last games of the season.', u'A predecessor to what would become a storied rivalry, this race featured such controversial moves as the trade of Patsy Dougherty to the Highlanders for Bob Unglaub.', u"The climax of the season occurred on the last, dramatic doubleheader at the Highlanders' home stadium, Hilltop Park.", u'In order to win the pennant, the Highlanders needed to win both games.', u"With Jack Chesbro, the Highlanders' 41-game winner, on the mound, and the score tied 2\u20132 with a man on third in the top of the ninth, a spitball got away from Chesbro and Lou Criger scored the go-ahead run on one of the most famous wild pitches in history.", u'Unfortunately, the NL champion New York Giants declined to play any postseason series, fearing it would give their New York rivals credibility (they had expected the Highlanders to win), but a sharp public reaction led the two leagues immediately to make the World Series a permanent championship, starting in 1905.', u'These successful times soon ended, however, as Boston lost 100 games in 1906.', u'However, several new star players helped the newly renamed Red Sox improve almost immediately.', u'By 1909, legendary center fielder Tris Speaker had become a fixture in the Boston outfield, and the team worked their way to third place.', u'However, the Red Sox would not win the pennant again until their 105-win 1912 season, finishing with a club record .691 winning percentage.', u"Anchored by an outfield considered to be among the finest in the game\u2014Tris Speaker, Harry Hooper and Duffy Lewis\u2014and superstar pitcher Smoky Joe Wood, the Red Sox beat the New York Giants 4\u20133\u20131 in the classic 1912 World Series best known for Snodgrass's Muff.", u'From 1913 to 1916 the Red Sox were owned by Joseph Lannin, who signed Babe Ruth, soon the best-known and one of the best players ever.', u'Another 101 wins in 1915 propelled the Red Sox to the 1915 World Series, where they beat the Philadelphia Phillies four games to one.', u'Following the 1915 season, Tris Speaker was traded to the Cleveland Indians.', u'His departure was more than compensated for, however, by the emergence of star pitcher Babe Ruth.', u'The Red Sox went on to win the 1916 World Series, this time defeating the Brooklyn Robins.', u'In 1918, Babe Ruth led his team to another World Series championship, this time over the Chicago Cubs.', u'=== Sale of Babe Ruth and Aftermath (1920\u201338) ===\n\nHarry Frazee bought the Red Sox from Joseph Lannin in 1916 for about $500,000.', u'A couple of notable trades involving Harry Frazee and the Yankees occurred before the Babe Ruth sale.', u'On December 18, 1918, outstanding outfielder Duffy Lewis, pitcher Dutch Leonard (who had posted a modern record 0.96 ERA in 1914), and pitcher Ernie Shore were traded to the Yankees for pitcher Ray Caldwell, Slim Love, Roxy Walters, Frank Gilhooley and $15,000.', u'As all three players were well regarded in Boston\u2014Lewis had been a key player on the 1910s championship teams, Shore had famously relieved Babe Ruth and retired 27 straight, and Leonard had only four years before setting a modern record for earned run average\u2014this trade was regarded as a poor one in Boston.', u'Then, on July 13, 1919, submarine-style pitching star Carl Mays was traded to the Yankees for Bob McGraw, Allan Russell and $40,000.', u'Mays would go on to have several good years for the Yankees, but had been a discipline problem for the Red Sox.', u'On December 26, 1919, Frazee sold Babe Ruth, who had played the previous six seasons for the Red Sox, to the rival New York Yankees (Ruth had just broken the single-season home run record, hitting 29 in 1919.)', u'Legend has it that Frazee did so in order to finance the Broadway play No, No, Nanette.', u'That play did not actually open on Broadway until 1925, but as Leigh Montville discovered during research for his book, The Big Bam: The Life and Times of Babe Ruth, No, No, Nanette had originated as a non-musical stage play called My Lady Friends, which opened on Broadway in December 1919.', u'My Lady Friends had, indeed, been financed by the Ruth sale to the Yankees.', u'During that period, the Red Sox, Yankees and Chicago White Sox had a d\xe9tente; they were called "Insurrectos" because their actions antagonized league president Ban Johnson.', u'Although Frazee owned the Boston Red Sox franchise, he did not own Fenway Park (it was owned by the Fenway Park Trust), making his ownership a precarious one; Johnson could move another team into the ballpark.', u'His club was in debt, but Frazee felt the need to purchase its playing site (which he did in 1920).', u'Further, providing the Yankees with a box office attraction would help that mediocre club, which had sided with him against Johnson and "the Loyal Five" clubs.', u'Finally, Ruth was considered a serious disciplinary problem, a reputation he amply confirmed while playing for the Yankees.', u'Frazee moved Ruth to stabilize Red Sox finances and cut distractions.', u'It was a straight sale, no players in return.', u'New York achieved great success after acquiring Ruth and several other very good players.', u'The sale of Babe Ruth came to be viewed as the beginning of the Yankees\u2013Red Sox rivalry, considered the "Greatest Rivalry on Earth" by American sports journalists.', u'After deciding to get out of baseball, Frazee began selling many of his star players.', u'In the winter of 1920, Wally Schang, Waite Hoyt, Harry Harper and Mike McNally were traded to the Yankees for Del Pratt, Muddy Ruel, John Costello, Hank Thormahlen, Sammy Vick and cash.', u'The following winter, iron man shortstop Everett Scott, and pitchers Bullet Joe Bush and Sad Sam Jones were traded to the Yankees for Roger Peckinpaugh (who would be immediately shipped to the Washington Senators), Jack Quinn, Rip Collins, Bill Piercy and $50,000.', u"On July 23, 1922, Joe Dugan and Elmer Smith were traded to the Yankees for Elmer Miller, Chick Fewster, Johnny Mitchell, and Lefty O'Doul, who was at the time a mediocre pitching prospect.", u'Acquiring Dugan helped the Yankees edge the St. Louis Browns in a tight pennant race, and the resulting uproar helped create a June 15 trading deadline that went into effect the next year.', u'Perhaps an even more outrageous deal was the trade of Herb Pennock, occurring in early 1923.', u'Pennock was traded by the Red Sox to the Yankees for Camp Skinner, Norm McMillan, George Murray and $50,000.', u'The loss of so much talent sent the Red Sox into free fall, even with the money Frazee earned from the trades.', u'During the 1920s and early 1930s, they were fixtures in the second division, never finishing closer than 20 games out of first.', u'The losses only mounted when Frazee sold the team to Bob Quinn in 1923.', u'During an eight-year period from 1925 to 1932, the Red Sox averaged over 100 losses per season, bottoming out in 1932 with a record of 43-111, still the worst record in franchise history.', u'One of the few bright spots on these teams was Earl Webb, who set the all-time mark for most doubles in a season in 1931 with 67.', u"The BoSox' fortunes began to change in 1933 when Tom Yawkey bought the team.", u'Yawkey acquired pitcher Wes Ferrell and one of the greatest pitchers of all-time, Lefty Grove, making his team competitive once again in the late thirties.', u'He also acquired Joe Cronin, an outstanding shortstop and manager and slugging first baseman Jimmie Foxx whose 50 home runs in 1938 would stand as a club record for 68 years.', u'Foxx also drove in a club record 175 runs.', u'=== 1939\u20131960: Williams Era ===\nIn 1939, the Red Sox purchased the contract of outfielder Ted Williams from the minor league San Diego Padres of the Pacific Coast League, ushering in an era of the team sometimes called the "Ted Sox."', u'Williams consistently hit for both high power and high average, and is generally considered one of the greatest hitters of all time.', u'The right-field bullpens in Fenway were built in part for Williams\' left-handed swing, and are sometimes called "Williamsburg."', u'Before this addition, it was over 400 feet (120 m) to right field.', u'He served two stints in the United States Marine Corps as a pilot and saw active duty in both World War II and the Korean War, missing at least five full seasons of baseball.', u'His book The Science of Hitting is widely read by students of baseball.', u'He is currently the last player to hit over .400 for a full season, batting .406 in 1941.', u'Williams feuded with sports writers his whole career, calling them "The Knights of the Keyboard", and his relationship with the fans was often rocky as he was seen spitting towards the stands on more than one occasion.', u'With Williams, the Red Sox reached the 1946 World Series, but lost to the St. Louis Cardinals in seven games in part because of the use of the "Williams Shift", a defensive tactic in which the shortstop would move to the right side of the infield to make it harder for the left-handed-hitting Williams to hit to that side of the field.', u'Some have claimed that he was too proud to hit to the other side of the field, not wanting to let the Cardinals take away his game.', u'His performance may have also been affected by a pitch he took in the elbow in an exhibition game a few days earlier.', u'Either way, in his only World Series, Williams gathered just five singles in 25 at-bats for a .200 average.', u'The Cardinals won the 1946 Series when Enos Slaughter scored the go-ahead run all the way from first base on a base hit to left field.', u'The throw from Leon Culberson was cut off by shortstop Johnny Pesky, who relayed the ball to the plate just a hair too late.', u'Some say Pesky hesitated or "held the ball" before he turned to throw the ball, but this has been disputed.', u'Along with Williams and Pesky, the Red Sox featured several other star players during the 1940s, including second baseman Bobby Doerr and center fielder Dom DiMaggio (the younger brother of Joe DiMaggio).', u'The Red Sox narrowly lost the AL pennant in 1948 and 1949.', u'In 1948, Boston finished in a tie with Cleveland, and their loss to Cleveland in a one-game playoff ended hopes of an all-Boston World Series.', u'Curiously, manager Joseph McCarthy chose journeyman Denny Galehouse to start the playoff game when the young lefty phenom Mel Parnell was available to pitch.', u'In 1949, the Red Sox were one game ahead of the New York Yankees, with the only two games left for both teams being against each other, and they lost both of those games.', u'The 1950s were viewed as a time of tribulation for the Red Sox.', u'After Williams returned from the Korean War in 1953, many of the best players from the late 1940s had retired or been traded.', u'The stark contrast in the team led critics to call the Red Sox\' daily lineup "Ted Williams and the Seven Dwarfs."', u'Jackie Robinson was even worked out by the team at Fenway Park, however it appeared that owner Tom Yawkey did not want an African American player on his team at that time.', u'Willie Mays also tried out for Boston and was highly praised by team scouts.', u'In 1955, Frank Malzone debuted at third base and Ted Williams hit .388 at the age of 38 in 1957, but there was little else for Boston fans to root for.', u'Williams retired at the end of the 1960 season, famously hitting a home run in his final at-bat as memorialized in the John Updike story "Hub fans bid Kid adieu."', u'The Red Sox finally became the last Major League team to field an African American player when they promoted infielder Pumpsie Green from their AAA farm team in 1959.', u'=== 1960s ===\n\nThe 1960s also started poorly for the Red Sox, though 1961 saw the debut of Carl "Yaz" Yastrzemski, Williams\' replacement in left field, who developed into one of the better hitters of a pitching-rich decade.', u'Red Sox fans know 1967 as the season of the "Impossible Dream."', u'The slogan refers to the hit song from the popular musical play "Man of La Mancha".', u'1967 saw one of the great pennant races in baseball history with four teams in the AL pennant race until almost the last game.', u'The BoSox had finished the 1966 season in ninth place, but they found new life with Yastrzemski as the team went to the 1967 World Series, only to lose the Series to the St. Louis Cardinals in seven games.', u'Yastrzemski won the American League Triple Crown (the most recent player to accomplish such a feat until Miguel Cabrera did so in 2012), hitting .326 with 44 home runs and 121 RBIs.', u'He finished one vote short of a unanimous MVP selection, as a Minnesota sportswriter placed Twins center fielder C\xe9sar Tovar first on his ballot.', u'But the Red Sox lost the series\u2014again to the St. Louis Cardinals, in seven games.', u'Legendary pitcher Bob Gibson stymied the Red Sox winning three games.', u'An 18-year-old Bostonian rookie named Tony Conigliaro slugged 24 home runs in 1964.', u'"Tony C" became the youngest player in Major League Baseball to hit his 100th home run, a record that stands today.', u'He was struck just above the left cheek bone by a fastball thrown by Jack Hamilton of the California Angels on Friday, August 18, 1967 and sat out the entire next season with headaches and blurred vision.', u'Although he did have a productive season in 1970, he was never the same.', u'=== 1970s ===\n\nAlthough the Red Sox were competitive for much of the late 1960s and early 1970s, they never finished higher than second place in their division.', u'The closest they came to a divisional title was 1972, when they lost by a half-game to the Detroit Tigers.', u"The start of the season was delayed by a players' strike, and the Red Sox had lost one more game to the strike than the Tigers had.", u'Games lost to the strike were not made up.', u'The Red Sox went to Detroit with a half-game lead for the final series of the season, but lost the first two of those three and were eliminated from the pennant race.', u'==== 1975 ====\nThe Red Sox won the AL pennant in 1975.', u'The 1975 Red Sox were as colorful as they were talented, with Yastrzemski and rookie outfielders Jim Rice and Fred Lynn, veteran outfielder Dwight Evans, catcher Carlton Fisk, and pitchers Luis Tiant and eccentric junkballer Bill "The Spaceman" Lee.', u'Fred Lynn won both the American League Rookie of the Year award and the Most Valuable Player award, a feat which had never previously been accomplished, and was not duplicated until Ichiro Suzuki did it in 2001.', u"In the 1975 American League Championship Series, the Red Sox swept the Oakland A's.", u'In the 1975 World Series, they faced the heavily favored Cincinnati Reds, also known as The Big Red Machine.', u'Luis Tiant won games 1 and 4 of the World Series but after five games, the Red Sox trailed the series 3 games to 2.', u'Game 6 at Fenway Park is considered among the greatest games in postseason history.', u'Down 6\u20133 in the bottom of the eighth inning, Red Sox pinch hitter Bernie Carbo hit a three-run homer into the center field bleachers off Reds fireman Rawly Eastwick to tie the game.', u'In the top of the eleventh inning, right fielder Dwight Evans made a spectacular catch of a Joe Morgan line drive and doubled Ken Griffey at first base to preserve the tie.', u'In the bottom of the twelfth inning, Carlton Fisk hit a deep fly ball which sliced towards the left field foul pole above the Green Monster.', u'As the ball sailed into the night, Fisk waved his arms frantically towards fair territory, seemingly pleading with the ball not to go foul.', u'The ball complied, and bedlam ensued at Fenway as Fisk rounded the bases to win the game for the Red Sox 7\u20136.', u'The Red Sox lost game 7, 4\u20133 even though they had an early 3\u20130 lead.', u'Starting pitcher Bill Lee threw a slow looping curve which he called a "Leephus pitch" or "space ball" to Reds first baseman Tony P\xe9rez who hit the ball over the Green Monster and across the street.', u'The Reds scored the winning run in the 9th inning.', u'Carlton Fisk said famously about the 1975 World Series, "We won that thing 3 games to 4."', u'==== 1978 pennant race ====\nIn 1978, the Red Sox and the Yankees were involved in a tight pennant race.', u'The Yankees were \u200a14 1\u20442 games behind the Red Sox in July, and on September 10, after completing a 4-game sweep of the Red Sox (known as "The Boston Massacre"), the Yankees tied for the divisional lead.', u"On September 16 the Yankees held a \u200a3 1\u20442 game lead over the Red Sox, but the Sox won 11 of their next 13 games and by the final day of the season, the Yankees' magic number to win the division was one\u2014with a win over Cleveland or a Boston loss to the Toronto Blue Jays clinching the division.", u'However, New York lost 9\u20132 and Boston won 5\u20130, forcing a one-game playoff to be held at Fenway Park on Monday, October 2.', u"The most remembered moment from the game was Bucky Dent's 7th inning three-run home run in off Mike Torrez just over the Green Monster, giving the Yankees their first lead.", u'The dejected Boston manager, Don Zimmer, gave Mr. Dent a new middle name which lives on in Boston sports lore to this day, uttering three words as the ball sailed over the left-field wall: "Bucky F**king Dent!"', u"Reggie Jackson provided a solo home run in the 8th that proved to be the difference in the Yankees' 5\u20134 win, which ended with Yastrzemski popping out to Graig Nettles in foul territory with Rick Burleson representing the tying run at third.", u'Although Dent became a Red Sox demon, the Red Sox would get retribution in 1990 when the Yankees fired Dent as their manager during a series at Fenway Park.', u'=== 1980s ===\n\nCarl Yastrzemski retired after the 1983 season, during which the Red Sox finished sixth in the seven-team AL East, posting their worst record since 1966.', u"==== 1986 ====\n\nHowever, in 1986, it appeared that the team's fortunes were about to change.", u'The offense had remained strong with Jim Rice, Dwight Evans, Don Baylor and Wade Boggs.', u'Roger Clemens led the pitching staff, going 24\u20134 with a 2.48 ERA, and had a 20-strikeout game to win both the American League Cy Young and Most Valuable Player awards.', u'Clemens became the first starting pitcher to win both awards since Vida Blue in 1971.', u'Despite spending a month and a half on the disabled list in the middle of the season, left-hander Bruce Hurst went 13-8, striking out 167 and pitching four shutout games.', u'Boston sportswriters that season compared Clemens and Hurst to Don Drysdale and Sandy Koufax from the 1960s Los Angeles Dodgers.', u'The Red Sox won the AL East for the first time in 11 seasons, and faced the California Angels in the ALCS.', u'The teams split the first two games in Boston, but the Angels won the next two home games, taking a 3\u20131 lead in the series.', u'With the Angels poised to win the series, the Red Sox trailed 5\u20132 heading into the ninth inning of Game 5.', u'A two-run homer by Baylor cut the lead to one.', u'With two outs and a runner on, and one strike away from elimination, Dave Henderson homered off Donnie Moore to put Boston up 6\u20135.', u'Although the Angels tied the game in the bottom of the ninth, the Red Sox won in the 11th on a Henderson sacrifice fly off Moore.', u'The Red Sox then found themselves with six- and seven-run wins at Fenway Park in Games 6 and 7 to win the American League title.', u'The Red Sox faced a heavily favored New York Mets team that had won 108 games in the regular season in the 1986 World Series.', u'Boston won the first two games in Shea Stadium but lost the next two at Fenway, knotting the series at 2 games apiece.', u'After Bruce Hurst recorded his second victory of the series in Game 5, the Red Sox returned to Shea Stadium looking to garner their first championship in 68 years.', u'However, Game 6 would go down as one of the most devastating losses in club history.', u'After pitching seven strong innings, Clemens was lifted from the game with a 3\u20132 lead.', u'Years later, Manager John McNamara said Clemens was suffering from a blister and asked to be taken out of the game, a claim Clemens denied.', u'The Mets then scored a run off reliever and former Met Calvin Schiraldi to tie the score 3\u20133.', u'The game went to extra innings, where the Red Sox took a 5\u20133 lead in the top of the 10th on a solo home run by Henderson, a double by Boggs and an RBI single by second baseman Marty Barrett.', u'After recording two outs in the bottom of the 10th, a graphic appeared on the NBC telecast hailing Barrett as the Player of the Game and Bruce Hurst as World Series MVP.', u'A message even appeared briefly on the Shea Stadium scoreboard congratulating the Red Sox as world champions.', u'After so many years of abject frustration, Red Sox fans around the world could taste victory.', u'With the count at two balls and one strike, Mets catcher Gary Carter hit a single.', u'It was followed by singles by Kevin Mitchell and Ray Knight.', u'With Mookie Wilson batting, a wild pitch by Bob Stanley tied the game at 5.', u"Wilson then hit a slow ground ball to first; the ball rolled through Bill Buckner's legs, allowing Knight to score the winning run from second.", u'While Buckner was singled out as responsible for the loss, many observers\u2014as well as both Wilson and Buckner\u2014have noted that even if Buckner had fielded the ball cleanly, the speedy Wilson probably would still have been safe, leaving the game-winning run at third with two out.', u'Many observers questioned why Buckner was in the game at that point considering he had bad knees and that Dave Stapleton had come in as a late-inning defensive replacement in prior series games.', u'It appeared as though McNamara was trying to reward Buckner for his long and illustrious career by leaving him in the game.', u'After falling behind 3\u20130, the Mets then won Game 7, concluding the devastating collapse and feeding the myth that the Red Sox were "cursed."', u'This World Series loss had a strange twist: Red Sox General Manager Lou Gorman was vice-president, player personnel, of the Mets from 1980 to 1983.', u"Working under Mets' GM Frank Cashen, with whom Gorman served with the Orioles, he helped lay the foundation for the Mets' championship.", u'=== 1988\u20131991 ===\nThe Red Sox returned to the postseason in 1988.', u'With the club in fourth place midway through the 1988 season at the All-Star break, manager John McNamara was fired and replaced by Walpole, Massachusetts, resident and longtime minor-league manager Joe Morgan on July 15.', u'Immediately the club won 12 games in a row, and 19 of 20 overall, to surge to the AL East title in what would be referred to as Morgan Magic.', u'But the magic was short-lived, as the team was swept by the Oakland Athletics in the ALCS.', u'Ironically, the MVP of that Series was former Red Sox pitcher and Baseball Hall of Fame player Dennis Eckersley, who saved all four wins for Oakland.', u'Two years later, in 1990, the Red Sox would again win the division and face the Athletics in the ALCS.', u"However, the outcome was the same, with the A's sweeping the ALCS in four straight.", u'In 1990, Yankees fans started to chant "1918!"', u'to taunt the Red Sox.', u'The demeaning chant would echo at Yankee Stadium each time the Red Sox were there.', u"Also, Fenway Park became the scene of Bucky Dent's worst moment as a manager, although it was where he had his greatest triumph.", u'In June, when the Red Sox swept the Yankees during a four-game series at Fenway Park, the Yankees fired Dent as their manager.', u'Red Sox fans felt retribution to Dent being fired on their field, but the Yankees used him as a scapegoat.', u'However, Dan Shaughnessy of The Boston Globe severely criticized Yankees Owner George Steinbrenner for firing Dent\u2014his 18th managerial change in as many years since becoming owner\u2014in Boston and said he should "have waited until the Yankees got to Baltimore" to fire Dent.', u'He said that "if Dent had been fired in Seattle or Milwaukee, this would have been just another event in an endless line of George\'s jettisons.', u'But it happened in Boston and the nightly news had its hook."', u'"The firing was only special because ... it\'s the first time a Yankee manager\u2014who was also a Red Sox demon\u2014was purged on the ancient Indian burial grounds of the Back Bay."', u'=== 1992\u20132001 ===\n\nTom Yawkey died in 1976, and his wife Jean R. Yawkey took control of the team until her death in 1992.', u'Their initials are shown in two stripes on the left field wall in Morse code.', u"Upon Jean's death, control of the team passed to the Yawkey Trust, led by John Harrington.", u'The trust sold the team in 2002, concluding 70 years of Yawkey ownership.', u'In 1994, General Manager Lou Gorman was replaced by Dan Duquette, a Massachusetts native who had worked for the Montreal Expos.', u"Duquette revived the team's farm system, which during his tenure produced players such as Nomar Garciaparra, Carl Pavano and David Eckstein.", u'Duquette also spent money on free agents, notably an 8-year, $160 million deal for Manny Ram\xedrez after the 2000 season.', u'The Red Sox won the newly realigned American League East in 1995, finishing seven games ahead of the Yankees.', u'However, they were swept in three games in the ALDS by the Cleveland Indians.', u'Their postseason losing streak reached 13 straight games, dating back to the 1986 World Series.', u'Roger Clemens tied his major league record by fanning 20 Detroit Tigers on September 18, 1996 in what would prove to be one of his final appearances in a Red Sox uniform.', u'After Clemens had turned 30 and then had four seasons, 1993\u201396, which were by his standards mediocre at best, Duquette said the pitcher was entering "the twilight of his career".', u'Clemens went on to pitch well for another ten years and win four more Cy Young Awards.', u'Out of contention in 1997, the team traded closer Heathcliff Slocumb to Seattle for catching prospect Jason Varitek and right-handed pitcher Derek Lowe.', u'Prior to the start of the 1998 season, the Red Sox dealt pitchers Tony Armas, Jr. and Carl Pavano to the Montreal Expos for pitcher Pedro Mart\xednez.', u"Mart\xednez became the anchor of the team's pitching staff and turned in several outstanding seasons.", u'In 1998, the team won the American League Wild Card, but again lost the American League Division Series to the Indians.', u'In 1999, Duquette called Fenway Park "economically obsolete" and, along with Red Sox ownership, led a push for a new stadium.', u'On the field, the 1999 Red Sox were finally able to overturn their fortunes against the Indians.', u'Cleveland took a 2\u20130 series lead, but Boston won the next three games behind strong pitching by Derek Lowe, Pedro Mart\xednez and his brother Ram\xf3n Mart\xednez.', u"Game 4's 23\u20137 win by the Red Sox was the highest-scoring playoff game in major league history.", u"Game 5 began with the Indians taking a 5\u20132 lead after two innings, but Pedro Mart\xednez, nursing a shoulder injury, came on in the fourth inning and pitched six innings without allowing a hit while the team's offense rallied for a 12\u20138 win behind two home runs and seven RBIs from outfielder Troy O'Leary.", u'After the ALDS victory, the Red Sox lost the American League Championship Series to the Yankees, four games to one.', u'The one bright spot was a lopsided win for the Red Sox in the much-hyped Martinez-Clemens game.', u'=== 2002\u2013present: John Henry era ===\n\n\n==== 2002\u201303 ====\n\nIn 2002, the Red Sox were sold by Yawkey trustee and president Harrington to New England Sports Ventures, a consortium headed by principal owner John Henry.', u'Tom Werner served as executive chairman, Larry Lucchino served as president and CEO, and serving as vice chairman was Les Otten.', u'Dan Duquette was fired as GM of the club on February 28, with former Angels GM Mike Port taking the helm for the 2002 season.', u'A week later, manager Joe Kerrigan was fired and was replaced by Grady Little.', u'While nearly all offseason moves were made under Duquette, such as signing outfielder Johnny Damon away from the Oakland Athletics, the new ownership made additions such as outfielder Cliff Floyd and relief pitcher Alan Embree.', u'Nomar Garciaparra, Manny Ram\xedrez, and Floyd all hit well, while Pedro Mart\xednez put up his usual outstanding numbers.', u'Derek Lowe, newly converted into a starter, won 20 games\u2014becoming the first player to save 20 games and win 20 games in back-to-back seasons.', u'After failing to reach the playoffs, Port was replaced by Yale University graduate Theo Epstein.', u'Epstein, raised in Brookline, Massachusetts, and just 28 at the time of his hiring, became the youngest general manager in MLB history.', u'The 2003 team was known as the "Cowboy Up" team, a nickname derived from first baseman Kevin Millar\'s challenge to his teammates to show more determination.', u'In the 2003 American League Division Series, the Red Sox rallied from a 0\u20132 series deficit against the Athletics to win the best-of-five series.', u'Derek Lowe returned to his former relief pitching role to save Game 5, a 4\u20133 victory.', u'The team then faced the Yankees in the 2003 American League Championship Series.', u'In Game 7, Boston led 5\u20132 in the eighth inning, but Pedro Mart\xednez allowed three runs to tie the game.', u'The Red Sox could not score off Mariano Rivera over the last three innings and eventually lost the game 6\u20135 when Yankee third baseman Aaron Boone hit a solo home run off of Tim Wakefield.', u'Some placed the blame for the loss on manager Grady Little for failing to remove starting pitcher Mart\xednez in the 8th inning after some observers believe he began to show signs of tiring.', u"Others credited Little with the team's successful season and dramatic come-from-behind victory in the ALDS.", u"Nevertheless, Boston's management did not renew Little's contract, and hired former Philadelphia Phillies manager Terry Francona.", u'==== "The Idiots": 2004 World Series Championship ====\n\nDuring the 2003\u201304 offseason, the Red Sox acquired another ace pitcher, Curt Schilling, and a closer, Keith Foulke.', u'Due to some midseason struggles with injuries, management shook up the team at the July 31 trading deadline as part of a four-team trade.', u"The Red Sox traded the team's popular, yet oft-injured, shortstop Nomar Garciaparra and outfielder Matt Murton to the Chicago Cubs, and received first baseman Doug Mientkiewicz from the Minnesota Twins, and shortstop Orlando Cabrera from the Montreal Expos.", u'In a separate transaction, the Red Sox acquired center fielder Dave Roberts from the Los Angeles Dodgers.', u'Following the trades, the club won 22 out of 25 games and qualified for the playoffs as the AL Wild Card.', u'Players and fans affectionately referred to the players as "the Idiots", a term coined by Damon and Millar during the playoff push to describe the team\'s eclectic roster and devil-may-care attitude toward their supposed "curse."', u'Boston began the postseason by sweeping the AL West champion Anaheim Angels in the ALDS.', u"In the third game of the series, David Ortiz hit a walk-off two-run homer in the 10th inning to win the game and the series to advance to a rematch of the previous year's ALCS in the ALCS against the Yankees.", u'The ALCS started very poorly for the Red Sox, as they lost the first three games (including a crushing 19-8 home loss in game 3).', u'In Game 4, the Red Sox found themselves facing elimination, trailing 4\u20133 in the ninth with Mariano Rivera in to close for the Yankees.', u'After Rivera issued a walk to Millar, Roberts came on to pinch run and promptly stole second base.', u'He then scored on an RBI single by Bill Mueller, sending the game into extra innings.', u'The Red Sox went on to win the game on a two-run home used to stabilize the tendon in Schilling's right ankle bled throughout the game, famously making his sock appear bloody red.", u'The Red Sox completed their historic comeback in game 7 with a 10-3 defeat of the Yankees.', u'Ortiz, who had the game-winning RBIs in Games 4 and 5, was named ALCS Most Valuable Player.', u'The Red Sox joined the 1942 Toronto Maple Leafs and 1975 New York Islanders as the only professional sports teams in history at the time to win a best-of-seven games series after being down three games to none.', u'The 2009\u201310 Philadelphia Flyers (against the Boston Bruins) and the 2013\u201314 Los Angeles Kings (against the San Jose Sharks) would also accomplish the feat.', u'The Red Sox swept the St. Louis Cardinals in the 2004 World Series.', u"The Red Sox never trailed throughout the series; Mark Bellhorn's hit a game-winning home run off Pesky's Pole in game 1, and Schilling pitched another bloodied-sock victory in game 2, followed by similarly to Boston's championship season, on the night of Game 4 a total lunar eclipse colored the moon red over Busch Stadium.", u'The Red Sox earned many accolades from the sports media and throughout the
